### Description

On a few viewport heights, the content stops being vertically aligned in the middle. This happens at 868px. Not at 869px (it jumps back being vertically aligned in the middle) but then it happens again at 870px height. I did not make any adjustments in the core code and didn't apply more CSS classes. 

### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
You can see our staging website here. It happens on the second slide. 
Besides fullPage.js and an extension of it, scrolloverflowJS, jQuery and jQuery Rotate are loaded.  

### Versions 
Chrome Version 56.0.2924.87 (64-bit)
macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Although this problem isn't a dealbreaker, I thought it was interesting enough to share to see what we can do about it.

Well, that's clearly not an isolated reproduction :) Lot of external JS and CSS to fullPage.js.

I can only say that this is happening because you are using `scrollOverflow:true` and somehow fullPage.js believes it needs to create an internal scrolling for your slide. 
I can see how it is indeed necessary in [the 3rd slide of the section](http://wespire.nl/klanten/floriaan/djbus/#section/clients) on 1040px width. Avoid that, and you'll probably solve your issue. 

You are probably doing something funny with your CSS styles in the 1st slide and making fullPage.js believe it needs scrollbar.

WordPress 4.7.3

fullPage.js-master

fullPage.js is a jQuery plugin and a Javascript library, not a Wordpress one.
Nevertheless, you can easily find other wordpress themes out there using it such [this one](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/utils/wordpress.html).

Find more components [at the resources section of the docs](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#resources).

On mobile devices or in webkit browsers, the inputs do not lose focus when pressed outside them. This problem occurs when connecting to the scrolloverflow extension

http://codepen.io/anon/pen/zZRPYp

### Steps to reproduce it
1. Open this link for example in chrome
2. Find the input field and click on it to get the focus
3. Now try to remove the focus by clicking on any place outside the input field

I've [reported it now in iScroll.js issues forum](https://github.com/cubiq/iscroll/issues/1139).

It is definitely a iScroll.js issue and not a fullpage.js one as can be seen in [this demo](https://jsfiddle.net/vhc3bmmk/1/) without fullPage.js
Yes, for sure, I also noticed that you can not select text, as well as select the checkbox or radio

### FullPage Conflicting with Flexslider's `slide` class
I'm rebuilding a website and came across an issue where the slide class conflicts with Flexslider. But I'm hoping the solution might be built in to FullPage.js... On mobile I'm currently using Flexslider to scroll horizontally through a list of images. Then on desktop I simply display them in a row.

Now I've adopted FullPage.js but Flexslider's `slide` class conflicts with FullPage.js' `slide` class. Is there a built in way to have horizontal scrolling limited to mobile only? Then on larger screens I can simply layout each image (slide class) without the horizontal scrolling effect?

### Link 
The second page on [this codepen](http://codepen.io/joe-watkins/pen/rFzcf) shows the horizontal effect I'd like to use on mobile only. But I am not seeing a way to stop it from functioning that way on desktop (or > 1024px)

Perhaps there's an option to change the classname `slide` from being used and I could continue to use Flexslider on mobile?

Any advice would be great, because I'd love to forget Flexslider and use FullPage exclusively.
Use the option `slideSelector` as detailed in the docs.

### Description
I am having a problem with iOS 10 iPhone and iPad Safari and Chrome Browser, the Slides can be slided from bottom to top but it does not work from top to bottom. Also in the hamburger menu if the menu is shown on iPhone SE iOS 10.2 you can't touch scroll it its just not moving. I tested the menu and page slide on the Samsung S7 Chrome and it works perfect also on Chrome and Safari on MacOS and on Windows 10 Chrome.

### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
Isolated case here: http://alliancesfordiscovery.org

### Steps to reproduce it
Try to touch slide from bottom to top and then slide from top to bottom of the screen it will not work. Also for hamburger menu if on the smaller device iphone 6 or iphone SE  you cant scroll the menu up and down.

### Versions 
iOS 10.2 Safari and Chrome iPhone 6S and iPhone SE, latest version of fullPage 2.9.3

As detailed in the [reporting issues guidelines](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#reporting-issues)

> An isolated reproduction of the issue will be required. Make use of jsfiddle or codepen for it if possible.

And as detailed in the issue skeleton:

> links to personal websites won't be reviewed unless isolated

Closed until an isolated reproduction with no external CSS or JS is provided.

Look like a problem with your `g-navigation` element. 

This is a duplicate of #1912
Was also treating the same issue hours ago here #2614

Easy solution?
Make the `g-navigation` element much smaller (it has huge paddings)... Or....use css3:false and use a fixed element inside the fullPage.js wrapper.

Other than that, you'll have to modify the library as suggested in a comment in #1912

I got the page content moving it was padding, but i have still problem with the hamburger menu, i tried this:
css3:false,
normalScrollElements: '#g-offcanvas',
normalScrollElementTouchThreshold: 1

i also changed the functions

> You could solve the problem by changing in both functions $(WRAPPER_SEL) for $(document).

After i did this the content start moving and not the menu. I need the menu to slide up and down if the window is smaller then menu.
Use a higher `normalScrollElementTouchThreshold` value.  Try 10.
Also, place inside the `#g-offcanvas` element inside `#g-fullpage` .

This worked ;) Thanks
> Use a higher normalScrollElementTouchThreshold value. Try 10.

Hello,

Thank you for the plugin, it's really awesome!

I have a question, I'm using your plugin to make a full page website, the page has sections of all heights (browser height, smaller than browser and bigger than browser). When I have a full section on screen, and the next section is a smaller section, when I scroll down, that smaller section appears aligned to bottom (if I'm scrolling from top to bottom), is it possible to make that section appear on top?

Thank you very much!

> is it possible to make that section appear on top?

No.
Duplicate of https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/2149
The most you can try is using the [Offset Sections extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/offset-sections.html) for that.

### Description
Opening a Modal wich has its own scrollbar can not be Scrolled on Iphone 6 and lower in Safari and Chrome.

### Link to isolated reproduction
http://fiddle.jshell.net/o46332j6/21/show/light/

### Steps to reproduce it
1. Get an Iphone6 or Lower (Browserstack)
2. Try to "Touchscroll" the left Modal

### Versions 
Safari and Chrome on Iphone 6 and lower

Use `$.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(false)` when opening the modal and ` `$.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(true)` when closing it. 

Or try using `normalScrollElements.` 

Google some answer, it has been treated multiple times:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38264469/block-scroll-on-modal-open

I dont think this helps for my problem. I dont have the problem that it keeps scrolling when the modal is open. I just cant scroll the Modal content itself. It dose work fine on an Iphone 7 but not lower or.

Yeah right. This is a duplicate of #1912
Was also treating the same issue minutes ago here https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/2614

Easy solution? 
Use `css3:false` and use a fixed element inside the fullPage.js wrapper. 
Then use `normalScrollElements`.

Other than that, you'll have to modify the library as suggested in a comment in #1912
Thank you for your quick answer. I will look into the threads you sent me.

Hi There,

I have two Sections. The second Section includes Slides.
If iam scrolling down from "Section One" to "Section Two" it will allways show "Slide1" first.

But what i need is to change the behavior in this Way:
If the User scrolls down from "Section One" to "Section Two" it should show "Slide3" as default.

I know i can link to a specific Slide like "http://website.com/#SectionTwo/Slide3". But how can i tell fullPage.js to use "Slide3" as the "Default Slide" to start with?

Best regards.

Read the [Required HTML structure](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#required-html-structure)

> If you want to define a different starting point rather than the first section or the first slide of a section, just add the class active to the section and slide you want to load first.
THX <3

### Description
I have a Fullpage.js wrapper and a special overlay or footer wrapper. My problem now is, that i can't scroll the content inside the footer div on IOS. It works on Android (Chrome) and all major browsers, but not on IOS (Iphone and Ipad). 
Any ideas how i can get this to work? As soon as i destroy fullpage, it works like a charm. So i think there are some problems with the bubbeling of touchevents in IOS.

Maybe you can provide something like a "disable fullpage events" and "enable fullpage events" method without destroy fullpage itself :)

### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
https://jsfiddle.net/t5eu2hdc/9/

### Steps to reproduce it
1. Open the Fiddle on IOS
2. Try to Scroll the Text in the white box on the bottom

### Versions 
Actual fullpage.js @ 2.9.4
IOS Devices with versions 9.x /10.x (lower versions not testet). Used an older Ipad 3 and an Iphone 7 Plus.

> Maybe you can provide something like a "disable fullpage events" and "enable fullpage events" method without destroy fullpage itself :)

Use [`destroy()`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#destroytype) for that.
Or just use `$.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(false)`.

Duplicate of https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1912

@alvarotrigo Thank you for the answer. But unfortunately it didn't work. I still can't scroll on ios devices. When i use destroy() it also removes the translate3d values, which i need in this moment (i just destroy when the footer is open, and rebuild after close, so the user dosent see any changes).

Thanks.

The destroy feature won't scroll your page at all. Not if you just use `$.fn.fullpage.destroy()` with no parameter `all`. It will remove the `translate3d`, but it will keep the site in its place.
It just turns autoScrolling to false enabling the scroll bar as in any site, but the active section should stay in the viewport.
Try using `normalScrollElements` anyways.

As you can see in this [fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/t5eu2hdc/11/), it is still not possible to scroll inside the div, even if i move the footer inside the fullpage wrapper and set normalscrollements and fixedelements to .footer
Try to reproduce the issue in your site in an isolated page. Dealing with iframes in jsfiddle is far from perfect.
You can find an exact copy of the fiddle code on [my site here](http://marcoschaer.com/demos/fullpage/slides.html). it's still not possible to scroll on IOS.

Remove `<script type="text/javascript" src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/fullPage.js/2.9.4/jquery.fullpage.js"></script>
`. You only need to include fullpage.js once and you are doing it with `jquery.fullpage.extensions.min.js`

Not an easy solution. 
I would suggest you to use `css3:false` and place the element within the fullPage.js wrapper. 

Then use `normalScrollElements`. 

Other than that...  you would have to modify the library and change a few things as suggested [in this comment](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1912#issuecomment-199222246).
Also, use a higher value in `normalScrollElementTouchThreshold` just in case. Go for 10 or so.

Hey Alvaro
Unfortunately, nothing suggested by you worked in my case. So i moved over to IScroll for scrolling on IOS devices. Now it works pretty good. For Android and normal browsers i can still use the native scrolling.

@NONNNNN probably because of the call to [this function.](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L1103)
Necessary for fullPage.js in iOS.

> Or is there another way to somehow detect the child of the active section?

Use callbacks such as `afterLoad` or `onLeave`. Read more about callbacks [in the docs](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#callbacks).
Or just use something like `$('.section.active)`

No. You should be using the logic based on the parameters the callback provides.

Like can be seen in the examples at the docs.
Use comething like `if(index === 1)` or `if(anchor === 'mySectionAnchor')`

Anyway, although I was not importing the css. The main error remains. As can be seen in the image below, when the semantic-ui stacking mode is activated, section 2 overlaps section 1 by hiding part of the yellow div.
![screencapture-127-0-0-1-8000-teste-1488890429362](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16987558/23657075/2d9be612-031b-11e7-929b-607a17e527df.png)

That's totally normal. That's how fullPage.js works. Using full screen sections. 
If you content is bigger than your sectinon you'll have to use `fp-auto-height`  or `scrollOverflow:true`.

> Even in responsive mode?

Yeah, the reponsive mode only turns off auto scrolling. 
You should be using `fp-auto-heigh-responsive`. Check the docs for more info and examples.

Hi Alvaro, i recently used your plugin.

I have a slide into section, the first item has an image and a lot of text, second has a list of images. In mobile, the second slide has more content (taller with inner height) and the first has a lot of white space under content.

I hope i was specific.

An example of that is in http://testcloug.gq/gastro

It's possible to change parent height (section element) fit to slide item?

Regards

You have a few options:

- Use [the responsive slides extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/responsive-slides.html) to turn slides into sections on responsive. Then use `fp-auto-height-responsive`
- Use `scrollOverflow:true` in your slide with long content.

Thanks Alvaro.

I don't like `scrollOverflow:true` behavior  because i have scrollbar enabled. The second option is great, but is not considered by administration project to pay for plugins unfortunately.

I'll make it with css waiting for good behavior.

Thanks, regards!

I'm trying to handle responsive design by using media queries. Until I use the desktop version everything works fine, but as soon as I use "Mobile" (even in chrome dev tools) page height becomes doubled and every element gets smaller...

Is there a way to disable this behavior?

There's no such thing as "mobile" version nowadays. 
There are touch desktop computers, tablets with bigger screens than some laptops and mobile phones with bigger resolutions than some desktops. 

Responsiveness is based in resolution, not on the type of device. 

Use the `responsiveWidth` and `responsiveHeight` options of fullPage.js as well as `fp-auto-height-responsive` if necessary.

Take a look at the examples in the examples folder on the ones available online.

Just for reference, my problem was fixed by adding this meta tag:
`<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">`

### Description
When `scrollingSpeed` is set to 0, horizontal navigation between slides is jumpy and arrows advance two slides with one tap.

### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
http://codepen.io/waissbluth/pen/dvbaBj

### Steps to reproduce it
1. Open in a touch device
2. Change slide with arrows or with touch gestures
3. Advance two slides with one tap

### Versions 
Bug is present in iOS Chrome and Chrome touch device emulation at least.
And don't you have exactly the same issue with the vertical movement?
Yes, actually.

Related with https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1654, which was never solved. 
I'll make it as an enhancement in this case. fullPage.js is an scrolling library, so it is not supposed to be used with speed 0 in any case.  

The only solution to it might be using a timeout and force the user to wait 600 or 700 milliseconds between slides. But that won't create a great user experience.

I see that now. I think that not solving the `scrollingSpeed: 0` skipping bug by itself is fine. It was extensively discussed and it seems there is no clear solution.

However, I noticed this problem with `autoScrolling: false`. That is why I reported the horizontal problem and not the vertical. I isolated the problem and found it to be the `scrollingSpeed`, but now I realize. [Here](http://codepen.io/waissbluth/pen/PpomBx) you can see the problem I am having exactly, where the vertical skipping is not a problem, just the horizontal.

I know this is a scrolling library, but if it have the option of `autoScrolling: false`, this seems like a valid use case.

Yeap, but the issue still being the same. 
Touch events will still be detected after you finish your slide in 0 milliseconds and therefore they'll trigger the movement to another slide.

Some people opt to make use of the [Fading Effect extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/fading-effect.html), which still having a scrollingSpeed time but replacing the scrolling animation for a fading one.

And others they just get rid of horizontal slides in small screen devices using the [Responsive Sliders](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/responsive-slides.html) extension.

You might want to consider them.

Can I use scrolling magic with fadingEffect?

http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/fading-effect.html

No. when using the fading Effect extension there's no scroll bar and therefore there's no scroll even being propagated. 
You should be using [fullpage.js callbacks](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#callbacks) or [fullPage.js state classes](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#state-classes-added-by-fullpagejs) to create animations. See [this video tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qiCVPpI9l3M) 

And check the [callbacks examples](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/tree/master/examples) as well as [the online one](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/callbacks.html).

Bootstrap 3.3.7
fullPage 2.9.2

Problem 1.
If Bootstrap modal is inside the section it doesn't work/display correctly. Only backdrop works.
Temporary solution is to place modal elements outside of the sections for Bootstrap modals to work correctly.
Is it possible to fix this without not messing up the logical order of the information?

Problem 2.
Background keyboard navigation and screen scrolling are still attached to fullPage elements.

> Temporary solution is to place modal elements outside of the sections for Bootstrap modals to work correctly.

And that's the correct way of doing it. Fixed elements outside fullpage.js wrapper. 
That's because of [browsers' bugs](http://stackoverflow.com/a/15256339/1081396) dealing with translate3d elements and fixed elements. 
You can also use `scrollBar:true` or `css3:false` to solve it, but it will have performance repercussions. 

> Problem 2.
> Background keyboard navigation and screen scrolling are still attached to fullPage elements.

Totally normal. You'll have to disable them yourself by using the fullPage.js functions such as `setAllowScrolling(false)`.
Thanks!

### Description
When viewing a Fullpage-powered site on an Android device, typing into an input field causes the section sizes to become messed up. It only occurs when you start typing, which drags the input field into view, forcing the page to scroll and break the Fullpage plugin.

Here is an example:

![fullpage_android_keyboard_problem](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7820108/22380500/973bc71a-e4b5-11e6-82b1-9557ad0841f0.jpg)

The problem is worsened if the device is in landscape mode. Often the next slide simply becomes fully visible:

![fullpage_android_keyboard_problem_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7820108/22380663/1855bf04-e4b6-11e6-994e-0421b69c8467.jpg)

Scrolling the page manually afterwards does not remove the effect; the offset created by this issue persists until the page is reloaded. If setAllowScrolling is false, this prevents page transitions all together, as both the original and newly visible sections will scroll but not initiate a page change.

Invoking $.fn.fullpage.reBuild() resolves the issue sometimes, but only when I call it manually from dev tools. Triggering the function on window resize and orientationchange events does not work.

### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
JS Fiddle: https://jsfiddle.net/ho5f6mex/

### Steps to reproduce it
1. Ensure there is a text input on your section.
2. Focus on text input to cause keyboard to appear.
3. Start typing to force the input field into view.
4. Close the keyboard
5. The section should be stuck in a "scrolled up" position, partially showing the following slide.

### Versions 
Confirmed on Nexus 5, Nexus 7 and Galaxy S5 devices.
Possibly related with https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/145
I always recommend to use the responsive options for small screen devices.
Another possible solution is using `scrollBar: true`.
Thanks, I'll give that a try. Cheers!

### Description
On a page with full-width/height video's in fullpage.js and scrollbars enabled in config; in most times, the video will stop after hiding scrollbars (autosetting in OSX) in Firefox 50 and 51.

### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/1694/

### Steps to reproduce it
1. Scroll down
2. Wait until scrollbar dissapear
3. Video stop...

### Versions 
Firefox 50 and FIrefox 51 on OSX (Sierra) with scrollbars hiding after a second or something.

Your issue is in `.js-section` which is setting an height of 500px making it bigger than the viewport in jsiddle,. 
Then, fullPage.js tries to adjust itself using `fitToSection` what is causing the issue.

If you use `fitToSection:false` or just remove the `min-height` property from the `.js-section` style you'll solve the issue. 

In any case, I'll keep it open as an issue with `fitToSection` with the pausing of a video.

First of all, thank you for creating this super awesome plugin! 
I encounter the same issue as well. On your example page, just add `autoScrolling: false` and `fitToSection: true`, the video will stop playing.
Fixed in the dev branch 2.9.4. Will get merged soon in the next release.
Fixed in the latest release 2.9.4

As detailed in the docs regarding the option `fadingEffect`:

> . Possible values are `true`, `false`, `sections`, `slides` It can therefore be applied just vertically or horizontally, or to both at the time. 

Meaning you can only apply it for all slides, for all sections or for all sections and slides.

If you want to only enable it for some slides and not for others, then yeah, you'll have to make use of the functions `$.fn.fullpage.fadingEffect.turnOn();`  and `$.fn.fullpage.fadingEffect.turnOff();`.

Fix for issue #941 .Add scroll-end-prevent function

in [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/941#issuecomment-269897045) I display a demo and some intro to fix this problem, it use the delay with the user's option to solve it.

in [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/941#issuecomment-272885647), @bogdan-r test it works great with MacBook trackpad.

The usage with fullPage's option, like `scrollOverflowEndPrevent: { delay: 500, reversal: false }`


The scroll-end-prevent function works in the situation: when scroll bar is not reached the page end (top or bottom) named status (1), if the scroll bar is reached the page end (top or bottom) named status (2), 

when status (1) => (2), the scroll-end-prevent will work, it will prevent section-move, if status (1) => (2) plus the mousewheel is not terminate, it will trigger the section-move when the time greater than or equal to the delay, which time is started when status becomed (2), 
but if delay setted with 0, it will trigger section-move when status (1) to (2). 
if the scroll bar is in status (2), it meaning the scroll bar is reached the page end (top or bottom), when mousewheel happend it like the status (2) => (2), well this would trigger section-move.

the option `scrollOverflowEndPrevent` has two attributes named `delay` and `reversal`, `delay`(unit:ms) used to set delay time for section-move with the incessancy mousewheel when scroll bar reached the page end (top or bottom) likes status (1) => (2)
You can also set the value with your fact. if you set it `-1`, it meaning always prevent section-move when scroll bar reached the page end (top or bottom) when status (1) => (2). 
the default value is 0, it likes the same effects with fullpage before.

the `reversal`(boolean) attribute is set to switch the situation like this: when scroll bar is in status (2), and the mousewheel dirction let it leave the page end plus change the mousewheel dirction let it reached the page end again without mousewheel terminate, 
like status (2) => (1) => (2), when `reversal` is false, it will prevent section-move, when `reversal` is true, it will trigger section-move.
the default value is true.

### Hi, I am trying to get fixed a background image into a section but I get some issues that I don't understand why...

If you check the codepen, you will see what I'm saying. You will see only the first background but not the other ones... But if you enable the option "scrollBar: true" in the JS screen then you will see all backgrounds fixed. Why is this happening? Can I get all backgrounds fixed whitout enabling scrollBar?

Another alternative is disabling scrollBar and modifying the line 93 of CSS screen. Change 'fixed' by 'scroll' and all backgrounds will appear... but not fixed, of course.

**I would like to achieve all fixed backgrounds with the scrollBar option disabled.**

### Here is the code http://codepen.io/anon/pen/GrZyMm

That's a bug of some browsers that won't support the css3 property translate3d over fixed elements. It is clearly not a fullpage.js bug. 
See [this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23571578/chrome-issue-with-background-attachment-fixed-and-position-fixed-elements) in case it helps. Or [this other](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20268962/fixed-attachment-background-image-flicker-disappear-in-chrome-when-coupled-with).

To solve it you can:
- Use `css3:false`  (see the [backgruondsFixed example](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/tree/master/examples) provided with the library)
- Or use `scrollBar:true`, 
- Or use `autoScrolling:false`
- Or wait a few days for a new [fullPage.js extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/) that will solve that.
Asked multiple times: https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues?q=is%3Aissue+background-attachment+is%3Aclosed

### Description
hi! I just bought extension fadingEffect. And I have 2 questions:
1. It works only if `fadingEffect: true` but how to apply it only for special slides. I was trying to do something like this: `fadingEffect: '#fade, #fade1'` but it doesn't work.
2. Then I still getting message "Unlicensed fullPage.js Extension" but I inserted key which I got after I paid.

Thank you!

1 - You can't apply it to specific selectors.
But what you can do is turn it off an on by on on section load (by using a callback, for example) using the fullPage.js functions `$.fn.fullpage.fadingEffect.turnOn();` and `$.fn.fullpage.fadingEffect.turnOff();` as can be seen on the buttons of the [demo page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/fading-effect.html).

You can also apply to only vertical sections or to only horizontal slides as detailed in the docs.

2- You need the activation key as detailed [in the documentation](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#use-extensions). Follow the instructions that were sent to your email address after purchasing the extension in order to get it.
Ok. Thank you!

No. 
The most you can do is make use of `scrollOverflow:true` as in [this example](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html).

As soon as Edge keeps only 2 decimal numbers(for instance 3.33% instead of 3.33333%) then slide's computed width becomes less then 100% of viewport on Edge(because 3.33% is less than 3.33333%) and if slides have different background colours then you can observe vertical line with different colour on the right edge of the active slide which is normally only 1px width but still it doesn't look nice.
One of the solution came to my mind is to hide(make opacity: 0) to all inactive slides and show active only but may be you can advice better workaround based on your experience. Thank you.

Hi Alvaro,

I noticed that the `onLeave` callback was firing too soon, which caused my implementation to break when pressing down (next slide) multiple times. The callback would fire, even though the previous animation was not completed yet.

So I added this check in the `keydownHandler()` function. It's not in the same if-statement as the others, because this would sometimes cause a normal "down" event to fire, scrolling the page one tick, showing a piece of the next section, and then centering on the proper section again.

Hope you find this helpful.

Regards,
Jorn

Can you please add a reproduction of the issue?
I don't seem to get any issue on [this example page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/callbacks.html#secondPage/2).

See this page: https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2016/11/09/ongeloof-bij-hillary-fans-a1530890
What happens?
- On pageload the first element is duplicated and some html added.
- When dom manipulation is ready, fullpage.js will be initialised.
- When you scroll from 1 to 2, the first element is fixed, so you get the effect of a layer being removed. `afterLoad` this element won't be fixed anymore, but since the second image is the same it appears to keep standing.
- When you scroll from 2 to 1, the first element will be fixed again on `onLeave` for the "layer over" effect.

Reproduce:
- Start at the topmost section and tap the down key multiple times in quick succession
- Also, move to down to (ie. the 4th) section and tap the up key multiple times in quick succession

The `onLeave` function gets fired too soon (this is production, so no console.logs), so the first element doesn't get toggled `fixed` at the right time.

Note: Currently my fix is being put in production, so the error might not be visible for very long.

My recommendation? Do what [require.js recommends](http://requirejs.org/docs/start.html#optimize) and do not use require.js for production. 
Use minification + combination and this would solve your issue.

Code snippet: $body.height()
Problem: returns the height of viewport not the actual height of document
File: https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L922
Browser: IE 11

Recommendation: instead use $(document).height()

Can you please explain what is the problem that you are getting from it? 
 Isolated reproduction? Steps to reproduce it?

Problem is caused by the mentioned code snippet that makes the variable "isAtBottom" get wrong value.
For example when the document height is 2000 pixels and the window height is 1000 pixels the named code snippet return 1000 pixels.
Continuing the example when the scroll is on top of the page the evaluation of the formula is like this:
1000 - 1000 === 0 ($body.height() - $window.height() === currentScroll)
After the evaluation the "isAtBottom" variable gets the "true" boolean value which is incorrect.

Maybe  I didn't express myself properly.

I'm asking you to show me a use case where this leads to any kind of bug or issue. 
Isolated reproduction of it? jsfifdle? Codepen? 

The issue will stay closed until a reproduction is provided.

I investigated the problem further and discovered the real source of problem.
Here is the test code: https://jsfiddle.net/m3wp4uo4/4/
So the basic problem is: The initial keyword is not supported in Internet Explorer 11 and earlier versions.
When the plugin is switching to scroll view the code sets the html and body height to initial but IE doesn't support it and leaves the height: 100% css setting;
In the linked test code you will see the result of height: 100% setting and the problem caused by it.

What do you mean by *initial keyword* ?
In any case, I'm expecting to see a reproduction of it making use of fullPage.js, So I'll wait for it from you.

The fiddle you provided doesn't deal with fullPage.js directly.

I fixed the problem in our project with the solution i mentioned in first message.

If you have interest fixing the problem you can understand it by using the examples i given.

Hi!

I've encountered a scrolling problem on high resolution displays. When more than one section is present in the viewport, all present sections has to be scrolled through... even though there's nothing to scroll.

Have a look over here for a better understanding:
https://jsfiddle.net/15s3rjjn/6

As detailed in the docs:

> This is ideal for footers. It is important to realise that it doesn't make sense to have all of your sections using this feature. **If there is more than one section in the initial load of the site, the plugin won't scroll at all to see the next one as it will be already in the viewport.**

The issue with this approach of having multiple sections totally visible on the viewport at the same time is that fullPage.js can not know which is the active section at the moment.

- Which anchor should it use in the URL? 
- Which state class should it apply to the body element? 
- Which `afterLoad` callback should it fire?  
- To which section, navigation bullet or menu element should it apply the `active` class? 
- Which media elements should it autoplay /pause if they all contain any?

So, the problem is not in forcing fullPage.js to move to the right section on scroll, but in all it entails regarding the state of the website.

Suggestions will be more than appreciated on the matter.

Have you considered using the [Offset Sections](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/offsetSections.html) extension for it? 
This way no matter the resolution you'll always have the same amount of sections in the viewport.

Why not using `paddingTop`?

Padding top places a the padding-top value to the top of each section, which creates a gap between sections that you can see in the scrolling transitions. 

Take a look at this page: https://na.merch.riotgames.com/en/landing/2016/battle-for-baron

That page is using the current unmodified 2.8.8 version

Each section has a unique graphic backdrop that requires seamless transitioning, while also maintaining the need to have a fixed header at the top and not cropping off areas of the section due to the fixed position element.

This offset allows for the fixed position header at the top to more or less feel as though it's a part of the math that determines scrolling positioning and screen height.

I do not have the modified version on a production website at the time, but having the offset will allow for framing design elements to be present on the very top of each section without getting cutoff.

Hopefully that context helps.
Also, happy to add an example file to the repo later tonight.

The height of a section is not set correctly on iOS Safari. You may try this out in Xcode Simulator. For example on iPhone 7 Plus the height of the viewport (without toolbar) is 370px, but the fullpage.js height of a section(set by `$(window).height()`) is 414px which includes the toolbar(address bar).

To show this i added a header and a footer which are positioned absolute (top:0 / bottom:0).

Initial:
![bildschirmfoto 2016-11-17 um 18 40 15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5103210/20400530/5c91120c-acf5-11e6-9af8-d93a084876d4.png)

Using `$(window).scrollTop(1000)`:
![bildschirmfoto 2016-11-17 um 18 40 34](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5103210/20400532/5c93fde6-acf5-11e6-80e9-bcae2bb19c72.png)

A solution would be to use window.innerHeight. Interestingly it gives 414px (height with toolbar) on start, but with a timeout of 50ms it gives 370px (correct height without toolbar):

1. Replace all `$(window).height()` with `window.innerHeight`
2. Add a timeOut:
<S_CODE_TOKEN>
3. Additionally we need to listen for window changes. For example on rotation sometimes the toolbar gets hidden. Or if the toolbar is hidden and we tap into top screen and the toolbar shows. Or when opening a new tab in iPhone Plus Landscape or on rotation:
<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I added an additional timeOut within the on resize which only affects iPhone Plus with multiple tabs opened(tab bar visible). In this case again window.innerHeight is wrong until an amount of time. 400ms was the minimum i discovered.

With this 3 changes the height stays always perfect.

If not using the option `verticalCentered: false`the height changes needs to be done to `.fp-tableCell`, too.

If you find a proper solution feel free to create a PR and I'll review it. 
First of all, for what kind of initialisation is the proposed solution? autoScrolling:false? scrollBar:true? 

This topic has been treated multiple times, some people [suggesting innerHeight](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/1660), others [outerHeight](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/1678)... 
None of them ended up convincing me and none of them were fully tested in all devices/OS. 

Moreover, this address bar behaviour changes depending on the browser, its version  and OS. For example. [iPhone 4 or 5 and users have a different behaviour](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1659). 

Lets not forget also about portrait vs landscape. The latest safari in iPhone 7:
- Won't show the address bar on landscape when coming from a portrait mode.
- Will show it when accessing directly 
- Will show it when coming from landscape mode **if the cursor was on the address bar**
- And of course, it will only show the top address bar, unlike iPhone 4 that will show both top and bottom.

And this is just one single browser in one single OS. I'm sure others might have their funny behaviours too.

I see also you are talking about `scrollTop`.  I guess you were using `autoScrolling:false`?
This is another point to take into account. The browser (safari) will behave differently depending if you use `scrollBar:true` or `autoScrolling:false` (or the responsive mode gets fired), or if you use `autoScrolling:true`. 
The 1st cases will fire the scroll event and the 2nd won't. Which causes the hiding or showing of the scroll bar while scrolling. 

And again, when firing the scroll event:
- The address bar gets minified (not hidden) when scrolling down
- The whole address bar is shown again when scrolling up quickly
- A minified address bar is shown when scrolling up slowly

Regarding your pictures, simulators might not be accurate. Can you please use a real device or a connection to one from sites such as browserstack.com. And when doing so, specify the version of iOS you are testing it in?

Hey,

a PR may be appropriate but i don't have the time familiarize with all of fullpage.js right now.

The behavior is not fixed to any setting like autoScrolling:false. It is just a fact that the height of a section (which should be 100% height of viewport) is wrong on any iOS device. In my case i needed to have perfect height to position absolute elements(without using position: fixed which is buggy on iPhone Plus).

I tested my approach on all iOS devices: iPhone 5, 6, 6 Plus with and without tabs. iPhone 5 for example has a exclusive bottombar. Also i tested rotating, adding/removing the tab bar, etc and it seems to work perfectly. This covers all points you mentioned. 

I added scrollTop(0) because when you rotate sometimes the iPhone removes the toolbar and leaves a little scroll on the body so it needs to be readjusted to 0. Also the Simulator is very accurate if not 100% like a real device. The OS i used was 10.1.

As I described innerHeight is not always perfect unless using a timeOut. I added fixes for this and an additional fix for iPhone x Plus with toolbar which needs an additional timeOut.

I figured out that the window doesn't always gets updated when the tab-bar comes in/gets removed until a scroll happens. Therefor no resize-event is fired. I needed to add a setInterval using `$(window).scrollTop(-1);` which updates window if tab-bar came in. I don't see any disadvantages in other browsers. This interval is probably not what you want in your project, but it is the only way to detect and update the real height of the viewport on Mobile Safari.

I tested on iPad Air 2, iPhone 7 Plus (Simulator) and on a Android Marshmallow Phone in Chrome and default browser.

My final script looks like this:

window.innerHeight is good. But it doesn't delivers the right value from the start. Also following cases change the viewport: - After Rotation - Statusbar visible - Statusbar collapsed (on scroll) - Bottombar (iPhone 5) - Tabbar visible (iPhone x Plus) The problem is that the viewport, readable by window.innerHeight, does not update immediatly. And in some cases it doesn't update at all until there is a scroll (e.g. when the tabbar comes in). Thats why i added all those fixes, timeouts and scrolling to fix all of those problems and different behavior of devices. Also i could write a little script that always gives the right height and you can subscribe to viewport-changes.

Thanks @alvarotrigo it worked!

### Description

Apple clickpads have "momentum" which continue sending scroll events for a period of time after the user stops scrolling and can cause fullPage.js to move through multiple sections when the user only intended to move through one. This is a solution to the problem that still allows users to quickly scroll through sections.

The solution is written to work with fullPage.js externally, and while I've ported it from a slightly more project-specific implementation using es6, I don't have the time to learn the fullPage.js codebase and integrate the solution there. Maybe someone more capable would be willing to take the task on, but it seemed useful to have a working solution out there either way.

The logic is to have a mouse scroll event trigger two timeouts and prevent scrolling until one of them finishes:

1. The first timeout is 100 milliseconds long and gets cleared + restarted each time a scroll event takes place, meaning it only concludes once the user has stopped scrolling for 100ms.
2. The second timeout is 1.1 seconds long and ensures that if momentum and the user's scroll pattern is preventing scroll events from ever stopping, fullPage.js will move to the next section every 1.1 seconds.

When either timeout finishes, the other is cleared and the `mouseScrolling` flag is set to false, resetting things until the next scroll event occurs.

There's an initial check to ensure the delta is either `1` or `-1` before running any functionality. This is because at least some configurations with the latest Apple OS trigger a wheel event with a delta starting at 0 before ramping up.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

### Versions
This is an issue on any browser using an Apple clickpad on OSX/macOS to scroll through sections.

### Description

- If you resize the window when on the first slide, the slide does not move, just its content resizes.
- If you do that from the second slide, that causes the slide to slip on the left outside the viewport before re-centering again.

Is there any solution to have every slide behaving like the first one?

### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
http://www.alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/#secondPage

> Is there any solution to have every slide behaving like the first one?

Nop.

FullPage.js needs to calculate the width and height of each section and slide, and then fix the position of the slides in the slider. ( and check if scrollbar is necessary when using scrollOverflow)

This is done every [300 milliseconds](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L2067) to improve performance. 
You can try to change it to 0, but manually resizing the window will create a laggy experience (most noticeable yet in old or slow computers ). 
This is because when you manually resize the window hundreds of resize events are being fired. Which will imply having to calculate and modify the dom hundreds of times per second. 

Related with https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/64

Sorry to reopen this, but I found out the cause of my problem. Apparently, I was misreading `setAllowScrolling()` as `setAutoScrolling()`, so the pen is actually correct as the one I set to `false` is the `setAllowScrolling()`.  :)

The problem is due to `autoScrolling` check in `preventBouncing()` function. When it's `true`, in touch devices, it will `preventDefault()` `touchmove` event from `body`, which is why any scrollable div won't work out of the box. I commented out the code and haven't seen any downside/bug (except probably for the obvious bouncing -in iOS- which I believe the reason of why the function exist...)

Just a suggestion, but maybe add an option to enable/disable this or a note in the docs that the user will need custom handler to handle the scrolling in inner div for mobile?

Thanks!

> The problem is due to autoScrolling check in preventBouncing() function. When it's true, in touch devices, it will preventDefault() touchmove event from body, which is why any scrollable div won't work out of the box. I commented out the code and haven't seen any downside/bug (except probably for the obvious bouncing -in iOS- which I believe the reason of why the function exist...)

The bouncing is quite a big problem that affects many people. 
Instead It seems to me yours is a more isolated case and that very few people will have to deal with. 

I won't take any action here so far. It is quite possible that a near future release of fullPage.js (probably the next one) won't require the `preventDefault`.

@reddo possible related with [this topic](https://github.com/WICG/EventListenerOptions/issues/54) and therefore with [this issue in Chrome issues tracker](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=658847).

According to [Chrome docs](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5093566007214080) events are treated as passive by default. In fact, this is why [this other fullPage.js issue ](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/2311) was raised.
It seems your Chrome is interpreting the event listener as passive. But clearly mine doesn't and neither the ones in Browserstack.  I would say that a default installation of Chrome wouldn't treat events by default as passive.

So the problem is clearly in your Chrome.
Check out [this docs](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1II7oSIpd8pK91V5kEM3tDLKcIj398jOJn8Niqy6_loI/edit) and see how you can change the default behaviour of Chrome for passive events by accessing your chrome flags: `chrome://flags` and changing the property `
Passive Event Listener Override` to `Default`.

What you're seeing is probably the result of an experiment @dtapuska ran on a tiny subset of Chrome users, sorry for the confusion, we know such experiments make the platform less [predictable](https://www.chromium.org/blink/platform-predictability)).

But we've decided to try [launching](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5093566007214080) this [behavior](https://github.com/WICG/interventions/issues/35) to all users in Chrome 56.  So trying on current Chrome dev channel I see it reproduces reliably.  We're working on a blog post for this, but the short answer is to use the [touch-action CSS property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/touch-action) to indicate declaratively where you don't want scrolling to occur, and then avoid calling `preventDefault` when you see `TouchEvent.cancelable` is false (it's guaranteed to be a no-op).

Oh, I see the `fullpage` div already has `touch-action: none` (as is already required to work well on Edge) so really the warning is entirely noise in your case.  We'll [try to get that fixed in Chrome 56](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=667799).
@RByers thanks for the insight! Hopefully the change will be smooth for the fullPage.js :)

Hi, is it possible to add support for srcset and sizes for responsive images using the `` or `` element? Best regards David
I guess you can do that using media queries? What exactly is the issue?

It's about lazyloading the images. By using srcset="" and sizes="" the browser looks for the best image size and loades the image immediately. This mechanism is executed although fullpage.js is set to lazyload the images via data-src. Therefore fullpage.js should be extended for maybe "data-sizes" and "data-srcset" i guess.

Thank you.

@EarlofArgyle why can't you just do the following? 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

@alvarotrigo because the browser immediately looks for the best fitting image (in the srcset) and loads it, ignoring the data-src attribute and the lazy load technique in the script and creates an own src attribute. The lazy loading has NO effect. It's even bad, because the image, which was chosen by the browser, got overwritten with the one defined in data-src. It's a problem with img and picture/source element as well.
Is there any lazy loading library you know that deals with this issue?

Yeah this one https://github.com/aFarkas/lazysizes. But i would rather try to use only one library (fullsize.js). Lazysizes calculates the sizes attribute as well, but its not really performant, certainly not if you have a lot of images in your longpage. It monitors the page for changes via CSS/JS or scrolling which is not necessary for fullpage, because you have your own triggers.

### Description

**For a project we needed the resetSLides plugin. In order for this to work we included the fullpage.extensions.min.js. This caused HTML5 video's to keep playing after you switch sections (vertical). It pauses the video's when you shift slides (horizontal).**

1. Used standard code for HTML5 video using the fullpage docs data-src and data-autoplay features with fullpage.js included > everything works fine.

[Chrome, OSX 10.12, MacbookPro mid 2015, Codekit2, Coda2]

This might not have a solution in case of using `scrollBar:true` as fullPage.js prevents the default wheel action [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L1245).

According to the [Passive event listeners explanation](https://github.com/WICG/EventListenerOptions/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md) the passive events only make sense when not calling `preventDefault`.

> Smooth scrolling performance is essential to a good experience on the web, especially on touch-based devices. All modern browsers have a threaded scrolling feature to permit scrolling to run smoothly even when expensive JavaScript is running, but this optimization is partially defeated by the need to wait for the results of any touchstart and touchmove handlers, which may prevent the scroll entirely by calling preventDefault() on the event. While there are particular scenarios where an author may indeed want to prevent scrolling, analysis indicates that the majority of touch event handlers on the web never actually call preventDefault(), so browsers often block scrolling unneccesarily. 

And I guess they prefer to show a warning when calling preventDefault ?

Closed until an isolated reproduction is provided as detailed in the [reporting issues guidelines](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#reporting-issues) and the [issue skeleton](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md).

### Description

I needed to group several pages under same Menu item. I searched a bit how to approach it and found Issue with the same problem (#1354), where it was recommended to use callbacks to achieve this. So I started to work on it, but I found out that with the order of calls of the callbacks it is not really possible to implement it.

The thing is that `activateMenuAndNav()` is called after the callbacks are fired, which completely cancel out effects on active class on Menu of `onLeave()` callback (which I think is natural place to put such a code to). If you use `afterLoad()` callback than it works, but there is really ugly moment when the Menu item doesn't have Active class assigned during animation period, which is not really possible to use such a solution.
### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS

https://jsfiddle.net/AuHau/gc3gnb7c/
### Steps to reproduce it
1. Go to next page
2. The first menu item, should stay active, but there is small period when it blinks "off" and "on".
### Versions

Linux, Chrome, fullPage.js edge
### Proposed solution

Since I was going through the code I immediately wrote a fix for my webpage and I would like to make PR with the fix, but I didn't really managed to cover all cases.
[Here is link](https://github.com/AuHau/fullPage.js/commit/c21c993cc335662c820ae8025fa861e5b2577e4a) to my commit. 

I reordered the `activateMenuAndNav()` and now it works for cases when the `autoScrolling = true`, then it also works as expected when `autoScrolling = false` and `fitToSection = false`, but with `autoScrolling = false` and `fitToSection = true` there is an issue that when the `scrollPage()` is called in the `fitToSection` phase, the callbacks are not fired. That will again delete the active class from the Menu item. Since I don't really know the code by heart, I am not sure how to fix it, so suggestions would be appreciated.

### Description

On Windows, the [`$window.outerWidth()`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/8be3a53ffae635d5cbb368afeebe642e659de7d3/jquery.fullPage.js#L2113) method isn't accurate due to the presence of the scrollbar. This occurs when you hit the `responsiveWidth` or have `scrollBar` enabled.
### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS
- [When scrollbar is enabled](http://codepen.io/anon/pen/JREgRZ?editors=1111)
- [When scrollbar is disabled, but `responsiveWidth` is set](http://codepen.io/anon/pen/mARNKV?editors=1111). Hit the `responsiveWidth` breakpoint, then increase the width by a pixel doesn't work.
### Versions

Chrome 53.0.2785.116, Windows 10.
### References:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8339377/how-to-get-screen-width-without-minus-scrollbar
http://stackoverflow.com/a/28096943
And what is the problem that is causing to you as a consequence?

I just thought that I'd file the bug since the `responsiveWidth` isn't necessarily always accurate and would make sense to either include that caveat in the documentation or use the correct screen width/height values.

The problem which this is causing me is that the `responsiveWidth` is triggered at the wrong breakpoint which interferes with some of the styling/behaviour of the page in that small breakpoint window (size of the scrollbar).

E.g. if you're meant to disable the fullpage.js functionality at `768px`, if the scrollbar is visible, it's only disabled at `756px - scrollBarWidth`.

If you're inside the `responsiveWidth` breakpoint, the scrollbar is also visible, which makes increasing the screen width to `769px` (1px over the breakpoint) not trigger the full screen scrolling.

Hope that all makes sense.
Do you have any fix suggestion?

Proposed solutions are available inside the references section of the original post.

My proposed solution would be something along the lines of:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

and call that for all references to `$window.outerWidth()`. That way, it's much easier to refactor if you need to make further changes.

It'd be advisable to do something similar for the responsive height too (not relevant to my current use-case however).

Relevant [jquery ticket](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/1729) - it doesn't look like there are any plans in the near future to change the API behaviour.

Have you tested the behaviour of `window.innerWidth`  in mobile devices/browsers?
I have [a feeling](http://stackoverflow.com/a/15539660/1081396) it won't work that smooth.

The outerWidth() solution [was adopted](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/1678) to solve the problem between CSS3 media queries and the responsive mode. But it seems it didn't solve it for all cases.

Here's a [test page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/mediaqueries.html) in case you want to play a bit.

> It'd be advisable to do something similar for the responsive height too (not relevant to my current use-case however).

We [tried that already](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/1660). The result was far from perfect.

Hmm, I see. It's somewhat difficult to say as I haven't tested it yet myself.

But I think using `window.outerWidth` rather than `window.innerWidth` was the wrong approach in the first place as that "[includes the window borders, resizing handles, and sidebars](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12066093/what-is-the-difference-between-window-innerwidth-window-outerwidth)".

I think the proposed solution should still work with #1678, because it should fallback to [$window.outerWidth()](http://stackoverflow.com/a/17845094/4857127) if `window.innerWidth` does return 0 (we could amend the code to check for non-positive values too).

The height is probably best left alone in that case until someone raises a ticket for it.

I'm not able to reproduce your issue. 
Swiping up will go to the previous section unless I swipe over the address bar.

Could you record a video with your issue? 
Can you reproduce it on the [demo page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/)?

Right... I was able to reproduce it now. Thanks for reporting it!
It seems Chrome tries to reload the website when swiping down (to go up) around the middle half area of the viewport.

I'll have to check it with time, meanwhile I would encourage you to use the `responsiveWidth` or `responsiveHeight` options for small viewport devices.

Thanks, I really want to make it work as a fullPage site even on mobile so responsiveWidth/Height won't really work for me.

In testing this out with various solutions found online the root of the issue seems to stem from the fact that window.pageYOffset is always 0, regardless of where the user is on the page. This seems central to how fullPage.js operates which makes sense; however, Chrome detects for a scroll up when the window.pageYOffset=0 and enables the pull to refresh at that time.

Yeap. It doesn't sound like an easy thing to solve. Found [this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/29313685/1081396) regarding it, but not quite sure if that would solve anything.
fullpage.js is already preventing the default touchMove event (to solve the issue in Safari iOS) and it seems Chrome doesn't care about it.

Also, it is interesting the fact that I couldn't reproduce the bug in [this page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/prueba/examples/demoPage.html#about-info) which I used to test the issue. 
Is Chrome only doing it with small `width` websites? This one is not using the `viewport` meta tag and its width is therefore bigger than the [main fullpage.js page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/) which is optimized for mobile devices with media queries.

I am able to reproduce the issue normally with the link you provided (http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/prueba/examples/demoPage.html#about-info) same misbehavior as any other site. It works clearest if you try to scroll very slowly.

Seems the crux of the issue is the yOffset always being 0 in a fullPage.js site and Chrome's decision on what to do when that's the case, since it thinks it's at the top of the site...

I was able to preventDefault for all touchMoves, which works as written; however... this breaks all scrolling as it prevents fullPage from capturing the event. Maybe there's to tack that onto the end for touchmove (if going up, if not at top, do fullPage scroll up and then preventDefault)

Have you considering destroying fullpage.js for small screen devices  and initializing it again with `scrollBar:true` and `autoScrolling:true`? 
That would probably solve the issue while maintaining the autoScrolling that you want.

> I was able to preventDefault for all touchMoves, which works as written;

fullpage.js is suppose to be doing that in any case. Check the code [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L1148) in line 1148.
Ah and so it should, odd. Oh well your solution with scrollBar:true and autoScrolling:true works like a charm!! Thanks so much
That way it might not work as smooth as when using css3 transformations, so feel free to just use it for Mobile Chrome or mobile devices in general in order to solve the Chrome issue.

@joshuaohana good news! The issue have been solved in the [dev branch](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/dev/jquery.fullPage.js) and will be merged into the next release. 
It is related with [this other issue regarding iOS 10](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/2285) and has been solved by using `preventDefault()` not only on `touchmove` but also in `touchstart`.

> If I now pass a selector in snap, iScroll starts to look in every(!) scroller for there objects and throws an error if it can't find any.

Can you please provide an isolated reproduction of the issue in jsfiddle or codepen?

http://codepen.io/janein/pen/QKEEvq

note the `scrolloverflow.min.js:44 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined` wrror message.
This origins in `.overflow-section` not being present in all sections which are overflowing.

Not possible at the moment and to be honest I don't I'll add this feature in a near future. Therefore I'll close the issue. 

My recommendation to you is to destroy fullpage.js and reBuild it again without the  `snap` option whenever you land in a page which is not the one with the snapping scrolling. (or the other way around, just do it for that single section)
This should be transparent for the end user. 

You can take a look at [my answer here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/36643702/1081396) to get inspired.

In javascript version of fullpage.js there is no option to lock anchors like in the jquery version.So I just deleted 1259th line on which you are calling setState function, and anchors are Locked.
So you can add variable called LockAnchors and give a value false just like in jquery version and on line 1259 write this
if(LockAnchors==false){
setState(slideIndex, slideAnchorLink, v.anchorLink, v.sectionIndex);
}

Hello, I'm the colleague of the guy who raised this issue.

We have prepared some examples:

Example 1: http://demo.gisdata.si/fullPage/example.html
fullPage is not included and the dropdown works correctly

Example 2: http://demo.gisdata.si/fullPage/example1.html
fullPage is included but with scrollOverflow set to its default value of false, the click event registers and the drop down works

Example 3: http://demo.gisdata.si/fullPage/example2.html
fullPage is included and the property scrollOverflow is set to true, in scrollOveflowOptions click is set to true if it's a touch device and false if it's not, I removed the slide in this example god knows why(it logs the success into the console instead), on the emulator it registers the clicking events(unless in landscape mode) but while testing on my phone it does not work at all

Example 4: http://demo.gisdata.si/fullPage/example3.html
this is the same as above except preventDefault: false is added to scrollOverflowOptions, it reproduces the same behavior

Example 5: http://demo.gisdata.si/fullPage/example4.html
same as the above but the click in scrollOverflowOptions is set to false, now the click events start working as expected

> Should any issues with scrolling be reported to the iScroll GitHub page or do you have any information on it?

I would suggest so. 
As I said, this is [a known iScroll bug](https://github.com/cubiq/iscroll/issues/783).

In any case, I personally wouldn't use scrollOverflow. 
A real responsive site shouldn't need it. I would go for the `responsiveWidth` option combined with [`fp-auto-height-responsive`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#responsive-auto-height-sections).

Hi Alvarotrigo

First of all, got to say we love your work ... keep it up.

New versions of Chrome and Firefox browsers on Android mobile devices (eg Samsung Galaxy S7), do this silly thing where the address bar drops down or hides when you change scrolling direction. This has the effect of changing the browser height.

So when FullPage is running in responsive mode on these devices, we observe an issue where the first scroll in a direction, causes the address bar to appear/hide, which then causes FullPage to try to re-anchor. This results in a disrupted scroll from a user perspective.

you can see this on your demo when run using one of these new style browsers: http://www.alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/responsiveSlides.html#firstPage2

Maybe we've missed a pre-existing switch in your initialisation settings. But it would be great if we could set an switch on FullPage instantiation to prevent re-anchoring of pages when in responsive mode.

Thanks again.

Edit 1: Oh I should have added, we're now on your latest version 2.8.6.

> you can see this on your demo when run using one of these new style browsers: http://www.alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/responsiveSlides.html#firstPage2

I guess you can also reproduce it in this other demo?
http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html

> which then causes FullPage to try to re-anchor. This results in a disrupted scroll from a user perspective.

Oh ok ... so to show you an example, you can reproduce the behaviour on a desktop.
1. Go to the link above
2. Resize the screen to responsive mode ... similar to the size of a mobile browser
3. scroll the half way between slide 1.2 and 1.3 ... so the text 1.2 is disappearing of the top of the page and 1.3 is just appearing at the bottom of the page
4. Now resize the vertical hight of the window by just a couple of pixels.
5. The resulting behaviour is that the nearest slide is centered on the window again.

So now imagine your on a mobile device scrolling down and the address bar disappears, increasing the size of the window. Now the scroll gets interrupted as Full page tries to centre the nearest content on the page.

Hope that makes sense

> Is it possible to have a section: 1) taller than the viewport and

Yeah. When using `autoScrolling:false` you can use `fp-auto-height` to create smaller or bigger sections as pointed out in [Creating smaller or bigger sections](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#creating-smaller-or-bigger-sections)

If you want to keep autoScrolling, the only option is using scrollOverflow:true as [in this demo](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html).
Want to remove the scroll bar? Just check [iScroll.js options](http://iscrolljs.com/) and you'll probably be able to turn it off by passing the custom options in the `scrolloverflowOptions` option provided by fullpage.js

The other option is you can yourself create an scrollable element, assign to it the `normalScrollElements` option and then detect with your own javascript code if the user reached the top or bottom of it so you can manually call `moveSectionUp` or `moveSectionDown`.
This last option might not work as well for touch devices tough.

### Description

I working on web aplication, and we have mobile version of it. So we use ur library and we have sections that have full screen size. In mobile devices with landscape orientation we can`t use full screen size of sections, cause of small height - our content does not fit. So for landscapes we decide switch off autoscroll between sections with $.fn.fullpage.setAutoScrolling(false); and set height to sections the same as portrait orientation, so our content fit well.

So we look at event orientationchange, and when is triggered, we check this is landscape or not?
When it become landscape, we remember the hash. And afterResize event (this is full page js event)  we change height of sections and go to section with hash that we have remembered earlier.

On android devices - is all right.

The problems come true in Ios devises, like iPhone 6s. The event afterResize is triggered earlier then orientationchange event. And this is crazy, cause orientationchange must trigger 
instantly when we change the device orientation. And afterResize must trigger, when the ful page js done resizing (This callback is fired after resizing the browser's window. Just after the sections are resized.)

I made workaround of that problem by setting the timeout in afterResize callback function. Also i create new variable for landscape mobile hash, that can`t be change when the section is not correct. That var get value only when we  change orientation on our mobile device.
### Link to isolated reproduction with no external CSS / JS

[script.js.tar.gz](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/files/445369/script.js.tar.gz)
### Steps to reproduce it
1. [First step] - take ios device, like iPhone 6s
2. [Second step] - turn to landscape
3. [and then...] - u go to the dark screen or to the first slide, cause events goes wrong.

Also we have swiper slider on our page, but i don`t think that it give any matter.
### Versions

iPhone 6s
Why not use the `responsiveHeight` option ?

Because it just stop autoscrolling. The problem is that content does not fit to the sections on mobile devices in landscape orientation. Fullpage forcibly change height sections to device height.
So we we needed to change that.

So, my suggested solution is:
- Use the `responsiveHeight` option.
- Use the class `fp-auto-height-responsive` for those sections. Read more about it in the docs.

 yes 

> and set height to sections the same as portrait orientation, so our content fit well.

So we could save our portrait height of sections on landscape orienttation

http://codepen.io/anon/pen/ORLjgm

Even though the content is in the middle, since the inner table height is full screen, the content is shifted.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16402717/18102003/a8ee059a-6ef9-11e6-9fcc-2b160371434b.png)

This happens because of "fp-tableCell" div height is full screen, instead paddings should be subtracted from the height. It is calculated in getTableHeight function, which only considers the paddingTop and paddingBottom options only, instead of the CSS.

See the last comment in this topic: https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1319

Use a wrapper for your content.

Anyway, it was just a mere suggestion to remove dependency from height calculation.

Thanks.

Background images can only be added with CSS. With inline or external styles. This is not a fullpage.js restriction but how background images work anywhere. 

Same for colors.

You can always use whatever attribute you want and process it with javascript to assignt it as a style. But that's not something fullpage.js will deal with.

### Description

I want to change active anchor when I scrolled exactly to the top of next section, not to middle of current section.
### Steps to reproduce it
1. Switch to mobile view on this [example](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/responsive.html#firstPage)
2. You can see that anchor "Second slide" change class to "active" when green section scrolled just to middle of the screen. http://take.ms/ev6ui
### How to fix

We can add new option, like `scrollRatio` . Anchor should change class to "active" when page scrolled to the top of next section (`scrollRatio: 0`). Default would be `scrollRatio: .5`.

**We can change this code**
`var screen_mid = currentScroll + ($window.height() / 2.0);`
**to**
`var screen_mid = currentScroll + ($window.height() * options.scrollRatio);`

Not a bad idea. 
The problem with that is that there are more things depending on the section's `active` class, such as `fitToSection`, the play or pause of media elements, the section to fit in the viewport when passing from `autoScrolling:false` to `autoScrolling:true`, which slider to slide when using horizontal arrows or invoking the `moveSlideRight` or `moveSlideLeft` functions etc. 
And that can lead to undesirable results. 

I believe it would be much more simple to just add a class such as `fp-entering`.
This way it would also be consistent with the existing state class `fp-completely`, which is not yet documented and probably needs a change of name anyways.
It would be great!
Will the additional class be implemented soon?

- Fixed bug with scrollOverflow:true. Now scrollbars are interactive #2187
- Fixed bug with autoPlay and youtube videos in page load
- Added support for [fullpage.js extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/) (continuousVertical, scrollHorizontally, interlockedSlides, resetSliders)
- Improved horizontal swiping in touch devices when using smaller sections with auto-height.
- Documentation: Added explanation of `fp-noscroll` to use when using scrollOverflow:true #2190

Hi,

I've read the FAQ and a couple of kind of related issues, but I can't seem to find a feasible answer for the problem I'd like to solve. Heres what I'd like to do:
- imagine 3 sections.
- the first section is just a normal section. you scroll down to the next section using your mouse wheel.
- on the 2nd section if you keep scrolling instead of jumping to the 3rd section right away, you want to do some parallax/animation according to your scrollpos just within that section.
- as soon as you scroll to a certain threshold and your animation is finished you jump to section 3 and go back to fullpage.js "normal" scroll/jump behaviour to go to the next section.

I feel like I'd need `scrollBar: true` and potentially also `slideOverflow: true` for this but I don't really know how to combine those or how to use parallax just within one section and not the whole page. Any hints?

Cheers,
Christian

`scrollBar:true` won't help you here as it won't allow you to scroll inside the same section. 
`scrollBar:true` would only help if you want to have parallax effects when moving between sections. This is, causing jumps from one to another section and stopping. (similar to what you see in [this site](http://medoff.ua/en/)) Which seems it is not what you want in this case.

You can try it by using `scrollOverflow:true` for that parallax section. This way you'll be able to "scroll" inside the section and stop whenever you want.
scrollOverflow uses a forked and modified version of iScroll.js as detailed in the docs.
This means you should use iScroll.js in order to get the position of the scroll.

Unfortunatelly it seems the default iScroll.js doesn't provide such option and you'll have to go for the `iscroll-probe.js` version as detailed in [the custom events section of its docs](http://iscrolljs.com/#custom-events).

And I say unfortunatelly because this means you'll have to modify a single line I modified when forking iScroll.js. Check [this issue](https://github.com/cubiq/iscroll/issues/1041) to know which line I'm referring to.

Hope this helps!
There's now a [parallax extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/parallax.html) to create parallax effects!

When clinking an anchor for a slide in another section, the page scrolls vertically to the section and then slides horizontal to the requested slide. 

Is it possible to have the vertical and horizontal slides scroll at the same time?

> Is it possible to have the vertical and horizontal slides scroll at the same time?

Nop. And I believe it would look quite weird :)

They wouldn't need to scroll at the same speed, just to initiate scroll at the same time. I got some feedback during testing a new site that users we're finding it bothersome to have the page scroll to content they didn't request, pause and then scroll again to the content they did request.

I'll mark it as an enhancement in case I think about doing it in a future.

- History API [is not supported by old browsers](http://caniuse.com/#feat=history) to which fullpage.js still giving support (IE 8, Opera 12, Opera mini...)
- I never managed to make the back and forward buttons work properly with the history API.

Feel free to commit a pull request if you are able to:
- Do it providing a fallback for old browsers
- Keep the back and forward browser buttons functionality

have you considered using [https://github.com/browserstate/history.js/ ](https://github.com/browserstate/history.js/)?. Except for a few issues, it does the job. It gracefully fallbacks to hashes in older browsers. It'd be great if you could contribute to it
I would prefer not to add dependencies. And if so, they should be optional.

### Description

In my application, I've got a series of sections. These scale to the size of the screen. Inside each of these sections, there's an inner-div, which has a `overflow-y: auto'`.

This means that if there's more content than the box will support, then it will turn into a scroller. However, most of the time, the scrollbar is not visible. 

I'm currently using `normalScrollElements: '.section-main'` to pause when there's a scrollbar. However, this also seems to pause when there's a div with overflow-y: auto. This means that if an end-user has their mouse over this div, and there's no scrollbar, there will be no scrolling action. I understand this behaviour, but they might not.

> This means that if an end-user has their mouse over this div, and there's no scrollbar, there will be no scrolling action.

That's how it is suppose to work in any case. There's no way for fullpage.js to know if you want to use an scrollable element or use normal scroll elements for any other reason. 

You'll have to add a class to elements depending on your needs and add that element in the normalScrollElements. 
In your example, you should only have the class `.section-main` in the element that you want to prevent auto scrolling.

No, callbacks are independent from each other. 
Both will get fired in some scenarios. 

> I would be able to hide the prev or next arrow. I managaed to do
> this with the afterSlideLoad callback

You can do it easier with CSS by using the fp-viewing-X-Y class added to the body element.
If you use the default arrows, just use `loopHorizontal:false` to make the arrows disappear in the 1st and last slides.

### Description

If you destroy the fullpage.js instance with an active responsive option (fp-responsive class added to body) the the class is not removed with it (even when using the 'all' argument).
This causes another created instance (with the same responsive option) to be non-responsive and thus still having the auto-scrolling active. Is this a bug or intended?
This happens because the `setResponsive` function only disables auto-scrolling if the class is not already present:

Why are you using matchMedia? Why not the `responsiveWidth` or `responsiveHeight` options?

In all honesty I had forgot the option existed and it completely solves the problem.

The reason I didn't use it before was because fullpage.js was still imposing heights on to the sections which I don't want, I tried looking for the solution, and that's why I think I just destroyed it in the first place. Have I missed an option that can turn this height behaviour off too?

> all of the height and table-cell stuff was being imposed

Nothing is imposed. 

Don't want imposed height? Use `fp-auto-heigh` or `fp-auto-height-responsive`.
Don't want table-cell? Use `verticalCentered:false`.
