> Well, i don't think it's a good idea to use it directly on code... you assigned every "fp-" class with plugin, best way is to continue assigning classes with it, don't you agree?

No, I do not agree. That's the whole purpose of that class. It is not used by the library otherwise.
`fp-` classes are just prefixed like so to avoid interference with any external library or developer classes. But they are mean to be used when necessary as stated in the docs.

> because the window.load() should be first after the document.ready(

Window load will always fire after document ready. If you want to remove the scroll bar while the site is loading, you'll have to do it on document ready, not on windows load. And threfore between the `<head>` elements of your site. 

You can do it with CSS or your own javascript.

Or easier, just take a look at all the fullpage.js examples provided here. Use fullpage.js on document ready on the header, not before the closeing '<body>' (which is after the site has loaded)

I would suggest getting rid of scrollOverflow as a real responsive site shouldn't need it. 
Using `fp-auto-height` or `fp-auto-height-responsive` seems like a much better option to me together with `responsiveWidth` and `responsiveHeight`.

Regarding your question, the `resize` event gets called hundreds of times on resize. You'll have to know when to call the function and when not as you won't be able to call the destroy function after you destroy fullpage.js.

But that's more a matter of Javascript knowledge and you should ask those questions in stackoverflow.com.

Alright, I have figured this out. Caveat, I am a designer, not a programmer, so i really don't know what I am doing, I have cobbled this together from various snippets of js found on stack overflow.

The issue is set out in the OP: position: fixed fails when the fixed element is within a 3d transformed element. FullPage's #fullpage div is such. Per my post above, I wanted fixed previous/next arrows on my long scrolling slide. If I put those arrows within the slide's div, they scroll with the slide. If I set the arrows outside #fullpage div, they will be position fixed, but they appear at the top of the page, on the cover. 

This is how I fixed it. Arrows outside the full page div, but set initially to display none. When the body acquires the slide's class, css tells the arrows to display block. Then they are positioned via javascript on the afterSlideLoad callback.

This pull request is in response to the issue I recently posted (issue #2075). 

Essentially, calling `$.fn.fullpage.destroy();` on the container at anytime would disable the plugin on that page permanently until refresh. 

The added function `$.fn.fullpage.recreate()`, when called, re-initializes the plugin on the page without the need to reload the page. 

The plugin is reinitialized to having all the default events handled by the plugin bound. During re-initialization, this function also defaults the values of auto scrolling and keyboard scrolling in all directions to true.

Thanks, but it doesn't make much sense to add an unnecessary function. 
Just placing your initialisation inside a function would do it.

It was after trying your suggested code and having it not work in the both the latest Chrome and the latest Edge versions that I posted the issue and subsequently added the function.
You need to use `destroy('all')` to destroy the whole. You only destroyed the events and as expected, fullpage.js will tell you on the js console that you an not initialise it more than once.

Youtube videos can only be paused or played using javascript when they are loaded with the parameter `enablejsapi=1`. 

fullpage.js deals with this by automatically adding the parameter in any youtube iframe src by using the the [function `enableYoutubeAPI`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L841)

It seems you are somehow modifying the `src` attribute of the videos and you are removing the required `enablejsapi=1` parameter.

Symptom: when you turn off `autoScrolling` and turn on `fitToSection`, then try to navigate using the scrollbar, the page doesn't transition smoothly, it always try to fit section to screen and ignore scrollbar dragging, creates some kind of flickering effect. The same sometimes occurs on mobile when user tries to scroll the page up/down.

You can reproduce the issue here on your example page: http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html

Reproduction: Drag the scrollbar so that the section's edge is in the middle of the screen (don't release the scrollbar yet), then as soon as the page starts fitting the section to the screen, start dragging the scrollbar again, you'll see the problem. (It's actually easier to see if you set the fitToSectionDelay to 100).

Side note: I tried to detect the scrollbar mousedown by using `e.target !== $('html').get(0)`, but that doesn't work on Mac, so I'm using mousedown on `$(document)` instead.

Thanks for it!

But with your solution the scrolling will stop if the user clicks anywhere in the document (even by mistake), which I believe shouldn't happen.

Yeah, it's a tradeoff, but it's still better than having that flickering effect on the website. Besides, I believe that when user clicks on the website while it is scrolling, they actually want it to stop if there's something interesting bump into their eyes so they can see it. I sometimes do that to take a look at some details in the edge of a section when they're about to go pass the middle of the screen.

Maybe we should add it as an option?

There should be a better approach to it. 
For example:
- Detect mousedown 
- Detect site scrolling while mouse still down (user is dragging the scroll bar)
- Do not fire fitToSection until they release the mouse

Detect mousedown -> detect site scrolling while mouse still down (user is dragging the scroll bar) approach has a flaw. If user simply mousedowns on the scrollbar but not dragging, then fitToSection comes into effect, at that point the position of the page is already different from its previous position which is **remembered** by the scrollbar. Well because fitToSection cannot move the scrollbar which is being hold by the mouse. Then when user starts to drag the scrollbar, flickering will occur, because first the page will jump to the previous position which the scrollbar **remembers**, only then it will start to move to the position user drags the scrollbar to.
Then we need to keep looking for alternatives.

> Any thoughts on how to implement the animations then? A different method perhaps?

Call fullpage.js `reBuild` method once the animation finishes.  Fullpage.js needs to know the final position of the elements to see if it needs to create an scrollbar or not. 

Another option is having a container with a set `height` value equals to the resulting one once the animation finished.

@Vemon that has nothing to do with the problem.

In my case the `IScroll` was undefined so the `wheelOn` and `wheelOff` function weren't added to the `IScroll.prototype`, thus causing the exception. I guessed the `scrolloverflow.min.js` wasn't included before Fullpage so I went and override the order in my bower.json file, then it all worked out.

@Vemon the problem can be reproduced without even using `scrollOverflow:true`. Where IScroll is not even necessary. In fact, even when including it you'll still getting the error as you can see [here](http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/1286/).

Anyways, I've solved it on the `dev` branch and would probably release a new version of fullpage.js soon.
Thanks, and awesome library btw.

Fullpage is an awesome script. 
The problem with it is that when you have 40 and more sections, the page load may end up being quite slow even when your website is Grade A and you take advantage of the lazy load.

The problem, according to me, is that there should be a way to reduce DOM elements.
Maybe hiding all the sections that are not active and showing them just when you scroll can be an idea?

F.

> The problem with it is that when you have 40 and more sections, the page load may end up being quite slow

That's not a fullpage.js issue but an issue with your very specific scenario. 
You should be using AJAX to load content in that case. You can keep 40 empty sections and you won't suffer from any lag as you can see [here](http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/1287/).

Using `display:none` won't work. Fullpage.js needs to where where the destination section is.
It seems much easier to solve it from your side.

Yeah, just use [`setAutoScrolling(false)`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#setallowscrollingboolean-directions) to remove the autoScroll behaviour for sections.

I'll just add a summary of my solution...  (and here is the page, if anyone is interested in seeing:  http://www.coffeerepublic.com.au/products/cafina/  -  just click on any of the "Enquire" buttons to see the anchor working)

Basically, I needed to go through the loop of my "product detail" sections that appear above the "Enquiry" form section.  While the loop is going, I needed to add an incrementing "data-anchor" property to each section.  Once that was incrementing and adding a "data-anchor="product-detail-x" to each one, then I could effectively link to the "enquiry" section (data-anchor="enquiry").  There was no need for an array of anchors in the "anchors" property of the fullpage.js function.

So then because of my floating sticky header, (and the fact that fullpage.js wants to scroll so that the bottom of the anchored section hits the bottom of the viewport) - I needed to add a custom function in the "afterLoad" callback:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The enquire section needed a unique ID different than the (data-anchor="enquiry") on that section in order for me to run a scrollTop on it.
Also, "headerHeight" is obviously a variable that is set higher up - which basically takes a reading on how tall the header is.

I don't know if that will help anyone, but that's what I had to do to get it to work.

Lines 580 and 587 use this code to select elements with data-anchor attribute:

`$(options.sectionSelector + '[data-anchor]')`

In case if there are comma separated values like 'header, section', the resulting selector will be 'header, section[data-anchor]'). In this case elements without data-anchor attribute will be selected and this will cause an error on lines 581 and 588:

> Cannot read property 'toString' of undefined

I don't see why anybody would use a comma separated selector.

If you have the following HTML for each section:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Just use a single selector in fullpage.js selector option:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

If you have other elements in your site using the same `section` selector but which shouldn't be considered as sections, then just add another class to your sections to have a unique CSS selector for them.
Yes, I agree, that it is not very common use case. But that would make more bullet-proof code. Or at least it is worth to mention about it in the docs.

> the resulting selector will be 'header, section[data-anchor]').

The resulting selector would be `.header.section`, not comma in between in any case. So it shouldn't be a problem.

Why? 

`options.sectionSelector + '[data-anchor]'`

, where **options.sectionSelector** is _'header, section'_
Nop.
options.sectionSelector should be `.header.section` That's how jQuery and Javascript selectors work.
That will select elements, that have both _header_ and _section_ classes. That is not what I was talking about in original post.

> That is not what I was talking about in original post.

Your original post wasn't very explanatory. Please add the HTML markup you are referring to.

Ok. fullPage has and option to put custom section selector called _sectionSelector_. Users might expect to be able to put there any selector unless it is stated otherwise in the docs. If someone has HTML markup like the one bellow:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

, and wants both classes _section-foo_ and _section-bar_ to be treated by fullPage as sections, his selector will look like:

`.section-foo, .section-bar` (contains comma in it)

_setOptionsFromDOM()_ modifies this selector by adding attribute part '[data-anchor]'. Now we have:

`.section-foo, .section-bar[data-anchor]`

This will get all elements with class _section-foo_ (either with _data-anchor_ attribute or not) and all elements with class _section-bar_ and _data-anchor_ attribute. But the code that follows expects all elements with _data-anchor_ attribute and throws TypeError in this case. The correct selector would be:

`.section-foo[data-anchor], .section-bar[data-anchor]`

I see what you mean. 
But not planning to take any action in the code regarding it. 

Feel free to commit a PR to modify the documentation regarding `sectionSelector` and `slideSelector` options. (on the `dev` branch)

Why? Solution is very simple. jQuery provides _.filter()_ method. So, Instead of concatenating selectors:

`$(options.sectionSelector + '[data-anchor]')`

, just use the original and _.filter()_:

`$(options.sectionSelector).filter('[data-anchor]')`

Anyway, its up to you!

Regarding your 1st problem, you would have to reproduce it in jsfiddle or codepen, as the available [demo online](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/methods.html) as well as [the one in codepen](http://codepen.io/alvarotrigo/pen/EjeNdq) provided in the documentation works as expected. 

> I also tried: $.fn.fullpage.reBuild(); after a destroy and that wouldn't work either.

Rebuild doesn't do what you expect. Read the docs: 

> Updates the DOM structure to fit the new window size or its contents. Ideal to use in combination with AJAX calls or external changes in the DOM structure of the site.

You will have to initialize fullpage.js again after destroying it. Rebuild is only used to deal with scrollOverflow and update the sections and slides dimensiones.

Yes, `$(function(){...})` is a shortcut for `$(document).ready(function(){...})`, just shorter.

You have 4 options:
- [`scrollOverflow:true`](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html)
- [`fp-auto-height`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#creating-smaller-sections) with `autoScrolling:false`
- Use the beta feature `hybrid:true` as detailed [in this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/36618771/1081396). (notice the feature won't get support at this state yet)
- Do not use fullpage.js. Sometimes it makes no sense with large content.

Smart lazy loading would load neighbouring images/slides based on the direction of the userâ€™s movement.

Perhaps the amount of images/slides to be smart lazy loaded could be controlled through an option setting of the smart lazy loading function so that developers can adjust the amount of images to load before and after the current slide.

Can you specify where exactly is the conflict with bootstrap? Which element in bootstrap uses the active class that can be used at the same time for sections or slides?

If we are talking about the 2nd case, then we can create a new class for the navigation elements. Otherwise then you will have to wait for fullpage.js v3 for that. Changing the "active" class applied to sections and slides is a major change that can break many websites using fullpage.js.

For our use case we have a section with slides, and we have some normal scroll elements in some of the slides which take up most of the screen. ([example](http://www.codestar.nl/#team/galleryA))

This works as expected for vertical scrolling, but also disables horizontal scrolling. On desktop browsers this is acceptable (keyboards and arrow navigation still works), but prevent swiping on mobile unless you start the swipe from outside of the normal scroll element. fullpage.js provides the option `scrollOverflow:true` for those cases in which the content is bigger than the viewport as you can see in [the online example](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html).

Thanks!

If you are on your last section set on fp-auto-height (to mimic a footer) and then switch orientation from portrait to landscape the section fills up the whole viewport (footer gets moved to the top leaving the whole blank area below visible).

The orientation switch is what trigger this behaviour on both mobile and desktop, but it also happens on desktop when you just resize vertically.
Scrolling up and the down again fixes the issue.

Hello, I'm doing a website using your plugin fullPage.js and I've got almost everything working pretty well but when I reload the page or I change to another page, for a moment, some of the content of the page is shown all messed up before it rerenders all how it should be... See [this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/36061842/1081396)

I'll quote myself:

I always recommend people to use load fullPage.js in the header contrary to the popular trend which adds JS files in the body.

**Why?**
Because I consider fullPage.js is essential for the correct visualization of your site. Without fullpage.js, your sections won't be of the correct size, they will be overlapping as you mention, slides content will be visible when it shouldn't...

Some of those things require of fullpage.js to run, detect dimensions of your content, set the slides to the right position etc.

You can check this in any of [the demo pages](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/) provided by fullPage.js and you'll see there's no such blink. 

**If you still don't want to go for this solution to speed up the loading of your site.**, what I would recommend is to use the critical CSS technique to set the size of your sections as fast as possible (even when fullpage.js is not initialized yet) and without any HTTP request (to speed it up even more)

Use the following inline styling in the header of your site:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This will solve the problem with the blinking sections.

**Some of the possible problems**
- If you are using a conditional initialization of fullpage.js, this will still be applied even when you don't need it.
- If you destroy fullpage.js dynamically, this will still be applied when you don't need it.
- Sections with bigger content than the viewport won't have scroll bar until the plugin is loaded and initialized. 
- Slides will be accessible for the user even when you don't want it by using `setAllowScrolling(false)` in some slides.
Well, thank you for your answer, I'll try out!
Added a static url option, to give the possibility to leave the url unchanged when switching between sections and slides.

There's an option for that already, it is called `lockAnchors`.

> **lockAnchors:** (default false). Determines whether anchors in the URL will have any effect at all in the plugin. You can still using anchors internally for your own functions and callbacks, but they won't have any effect in the scrolling of the site. Useful if you want to combine fullPage.js with other plugins using anchor in the URL.

Hi. I'm building a portfolio site. I want 3 sections that scroll vertically. Section 1 will have a slider with numerous slides showing art projects. Section 1, slide 1 will contain a bunch of thumbnails with links for all the art projects, and when you click on one of the thumbs, you will scroll to the corresponding slider page for that project.

For example, let's say you click on thumbnail 25 on the first slide. Normal behavior is to scroll to the right and past 24 slides and stop on slide 25. I would like it to scroll right but for only one slide. I know you can do this be disabling animations, but I want to keep the animation, just have it appear that the target slide is always only one slide away.

Is this possible? I've gone through all the documentation and the issues/requests, and I can't see how it might be done. If not currently possible, could the feature be added to fullpage at some point? Thanks in advance!

> but I want to keep the animation, just have it appear that the target slide is always only one slide away.

Nop.

See your callbacks example: http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/callbacks.html

If you are moving to section two which includes slides only the afterLoad callback is fired, but not the afterSlideLoad which should be fired also, because you are going to a slide.

Usage example: if you change e.g. fixed header styles depending on sections and(!) slides background, you would like to use the afterLoad and/or afterSlideLoad callbacks to identify the current loaded slide to change the header style. That works for slides when you change them (moving left or right) but not if you are landing on a slide via a section change (moving up or down).

afterSlideLoad should be fired whenever a slide is loaded, even if you change to a section that contains slides.
Duplicated: https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1124

Nop, that would be a new feature request.
I'll mark it as an enhancement. 

If you really need it now you can [contact me](http://alvarotrigo.com/#contact-page) for an urgent request.
This is possible now with the [new fullpage.js extension Responsive Slides](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/responsiveSlides.html) and the option `responsiveSlides`.
Great, thanks mate! One more to confirm b4 purchase this extension, is there any conflict if combine **Responsive Slide + Continuous Horizontal Scroll + Scroll Horizontally** ? Please advise.

> is there any conflict if combine Responsive Slide + Continuous Horizontal Scroll + Scroll Horizontally ?

Well, I don't really know what you expect, but there's some kind of conflict between continuousHorizontal and scrollHorizontally.
If you use continuousHorizontal you expect to always scroll back to the 1st slide of the slider when sliding right on the last slide.
But if you also use scrollHorizontally to be able to slide with the mouse wheel, this would create a loop from which you would never be able to escape.

So in this case, what fullpage.js does is scroll DOWN to the next section **when using the mouse wheel** on the last slide instead of sliding back to the 1st slide.
This way there won't be a loop when using the mouse wheel. 

But, on the other hand, when using the arrows in the slider or the keyboard to slide right on the last slide, **it will slide back to the 1st slide** using the continuous horizontal extension. 

It shouldn't be any problem with the responsiveSlides one.

I [uploaded a demo for you](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/3.html) of those 3 extensions together so you can see it in action.

Thanks but the point is to have the element always fixed on top of the scrollable sections so it can't be in the wrapper because that makes it scroll out of the window frame...

> it can't be in the wrapper because that makes it scroll out of the window frame...

That's because [browsers won't allow `translate3d` over `fixed` positioned elements](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15194313/webkit-css-transform3d-position-fixed-issue)
Use `css3:false` to solve the issue.

The problem is in [this two functions](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L2410) `addTouchHandler` and `removeTouchHandler`.

Some guy [wanted to do exactly the opposite to you](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1088) not propagating fullPage.js touch events outside the plugin's wrapper and since then the plugin changed it behavior regarding this cases.

You could solve the problem by changing in both functions `$(WRAPPER_SEL)` for `$(document)`.

I might make the change for the next release. Maybe I should add an option like `propagateTouchEvents` additionally to `normalScrollElements`. This way we can keep the mouse events while disabling only the touch ones when required.

> You could solve the problem by changing in both functions $(WRAPPER_SEL) for $(document).

> Is there a way to let the cotrol arrows scroll right - left but disable only gestures?

That's something that has to be improved and make more consistent. 
But right now, the solution is to assign the methods `moveSlideRight` or `moveSlideLeft` to the arrows by yourself.

Right now `setAllowScrolling` will disable the touch and mouse scrolling. But:
- It won't disable `moveSectionUp`, `moveSectionDown`, `moveSlideRight` or `moveSlideLeft` functions.
- It **will** disable the click event on the arrows.

thank you.

I'll catch the click event on the arrows.
For now it's perfect.

Luca

 if(!activeElement.is('textarea') && !activeElement.is('input') && !activeElement.is('select'),  &&

I would recommend you to deal with padding by yourself by using CSS. Just create a container in the section and use the padding you want for it. 

The paddingTop option was mainly created to deal with scrollOverflow. But I always recommend people to deal with it by themselves if they can. 

I won't add a conditional padding option. I believe that's belong the plugin's scope and the paddingTop option is just for people who don't know CSS or who want to deal with scrollOverflow.

Make sure you are not overriding the fullpage.js `anchors` options with a custom `data-anchor` tag in the section before initialization.

I have solved this issue! I was becoming increasingly frustrated because when I put my mark up into the JSFiddle, it worked exactly as it should.. so I copied that code into my project and it no longer worked again!

Turns out, I likely had some invisible characters from when I was copy/pasting in my JS file for the controller I am using on this page in Angular. I debugged it down to a $http declaration in my controller to be the issue, and once I removed it, and readded it, the entire page worked as the captain's flow.

Thanks a lot, love the library. Once the project goes live I will be sure to send you a follow up.

> **menu:** (default false) A selector can be used to specify the menu to link with the sections. This won't generate a menu but will just add the active class to the element in the given menu with the corresponding anchor links. Here is something I'm trying to do when using **fullPage.js _with_ scroll inside section**:

#### So I did this step by step

I just want two slides auto change using "$.fn.fullpage.moveSlideRight();" . This method will cause the slide change faster and faster when I leave that slide and then back. I do not know what the problem is. Code like bellow:[https://jsfiddle.net/fiddleoutout/9z4yn9hb/12/](url)

@alvarotrigo

If section 3 is never loaded, no intervals will be cleared and multiple, new intervals will keep on adding thereby increasing the net frequency of moveSlideRight(). To fix this, the interval should be cleared unconditionally on each section load.

When you open a site directly in a section (as specified in the URL, e.g. #4thpage) then Fullpage scrolls to that section once the site is loaded.

It waits until everything is loaded, including all elements and startup scripts, and then it scrolls to the right section.

You can see this for example if you open a Fullpage site like this:
http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/#4thpage
As requested in the URL it needs to open in the fourth section (scroll to that section on site open).

But when there is a delaying startup script in your document, you might want Fullpage to firstly scroll to the right section and then finish loading of the delaying script (such as a chat box that is starting up).

For example in my case I have a chat box which is just an extra support feature to help people who have trouble on the site or who want to ask a question about what they see on the site. In that case it's more important that all main parts of the site are loaded and Fullpage has scrolled to the right section. After that I would like to startup my chat box script.

If you could add a feature to specify a script or element so that Fullpage will not wait for it on startup, and scrolls to the section directly, that would be much appreciated. On that way these scripts or elements are not delaying the page anymore.

As the maker of Fullpage.js (@alvarotrigo) explained [on another place](http://stackoverflow.com/a/35653296/1081396):

> Probably what's taking time is the loading of the JS, CSS or SWF files required for that script to run. Fullpage.js waits until all elements from the site have loaded to scroll to the section. The reason to do this is due to the use of images in section when using scrollOverflow:true, as fullpage.js needs to determine if the section needs scroll bar or not depending on the size of the loaded image.

Hallo,
for mobile divices with small screens I set `$.fn.fullpage.setAutoScrolling(false)`.
I have sections in which the height is more than screenheight, when I use the menu to skip to a section, fullPage.js animates to the bottom of these section. But I want to go to the top of  the section. I don't want to use `$.fn.fullpage.setFitToSection(true)` because than I at first go to the bottom and than the script jumps to the top of the section.

Is there a way that fullPage.js animates to the top of a section and not to the bottom?

Best regards
Niklas

> Is there a way that fullPage.js animates to the top of a section and not to the bottom?

fullPage.js will animate to the top if you come from a section above the destination one.
It will animate to the bottom if you come from a section below the destination one.

Make sure you use the latest fullpage.js (2.7.8) to get this result.

I find a solution which works for me, but I don't fi it works for everyone because I don't know all dependencies:
I change line 1294 from
`if(element.outerHeight() > windowsHeight){`
to 
`if(element.outerHeight() > windowsHeight && options.autoScrolling){`
and line 1302 from
`else if(isScrollingDown){`
to 
`else if(isScrollingDown && options.autoScrolling){`

Beste regards 
Nikls

Hola Alvaro, hay algun forma de usar fullpage sin que todas las section sean hermanas, es decir se podrÃ­a hacer la siguiente estructura html y seguir teniendo las propiedades de fullpage?

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This is not really problem with fullPage.js (@alvarotrigo, I'm a fan of yours, you may close it)
This is a problem with jquery, in case someone finds it that the fullPage is rendering the page really really long, with `windowsHeight = 1603px` or 50px I realized the issue was with Jquery's `$window.height();` This cannot work correctly if you don't have `<!DOCTYPE html>` in your html. Reference: http://viralpatel.net/blogs/jquery-window-height-incorrect/

_Adding it here, thinking it might be useful for others._

Yeah, exactly.
But note that the `DOCTYPE` declaration [is compulsory](http://www.corelangs.com/html/introduction/doctype.html). It defines the document type definition and every developer should add a doctype in their websites. 

Quoting your link:

> Our HTML document doesnâ€™t have DOCTYPE declaration. **So itâ€™s not a valid HTML so to speak.**

It doesn't have to be the HTML 5 doctype, it can be any other. 

But I guess I'll have to add it in the documentation somehow, it seems other people also had the same problem. I'll add it as a documentation enhancement. Thanks for pointing it out.
Solved in fullpage.js 2.7.8.

How can I enable the standard touch device incremental scrolling behavior when swiping between slides? See http://fantasy.co for instance on touch device. Pressing down and moving your finger up or down slowly will animate the slides to move with your finger. See https://github.com/darsain/sly/blob/master/docs/Options.md elasticBounds option for instance.

You can't yet. This would be a feature requests. 
I'll add it as an enhancement for the future. 

The most you can do now is using `autoScrolling:false` and `fitToSection:true`. This way the user will be moved to the nearest section if they ended up in between sections. You can adjust the delay by using the option `fitToSectionDelay`.
If you really need this feature as soon as possible [contact me](http://alvarotrigo.com/#contact-page) for an urgent request.
This has been implemented in the [Drag And Move extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/dragAndMove.html).

Probably related with https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/803. 
Do not use iframes, they are not usually friendly... 

I dont think we can have access to iframe touch events for security reasons. I'll close the issue as there's probably not a solution for it.

How are you going to destroy a plugin that was not initialized in the first instance ?
You are only initializing fullpage.js if the width resolution is larger than 1204px. But you said you have the problem width smaller resolutions, which makes total sense, the plugin was not initialized, you can not call a function that doesn't exist. 

My recommendation is to check if the plugin was initialized by using one of the [**state classes**](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#state-classes-added-by-fullpagejs) added by fullpage.js: `fp-enabled`.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

`fp-enabled` won't exist if the plugin was not previously initialized, this makes sure you only call the `destroy` function if the plugin was previously initialized.

Hi mate... any ideas how to approach this problem  ?
I did some tests catching EventListener and it turned out **IE** on Surface only reacts on following events:
`'pointerdown'
'pointermove'

It is detailed in the docs:

> scrollOverflow: (default false) defines whether or not to create a scroll for the section in case its content is bigger than the height of it. When set to true, your content will be wrapped by the plugin. Consider using delegation or load your other scripts in the afterRender callback. In case of setting it to true, it requires the vendor plugin jquery.slimscroll.min and it should be loaded before the fullPage.js plugin. For example:

And you have an [example online](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html).

> Also, similar question, is there any way to make something like http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/oneSection.html but with auto scroll only on the first section?

You can try using a new option which haven't been yet tested: `hybrid:true` in combination with the addition of the class `fp-normal-scroll`in the sections you want to have normal scrolling.

@sohrabzia there's [an open issue about this topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1854).
The default behavior at the moment is:

> fullPage.js will animate to the top if you come from a section above the destination one.
> It will animate to the bottom if you come from a section below the destination one.

Hi guys, I had had the same problem and finally I've found the way to fix it. The problem is with section that contains scrolling, so in scrolling method you need to add additional line of code: 

**$('.fp-scroller').css('transform','translate(0px, 0px) translateZ(0px)');**

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This fix reset transformation coordinates of scrolling object before move to specific section.

I know that there is some strange calculation of the viewport dimensions on iOS devices. So If you use 100vh for instance, you probably get wrong values. If verticalCentered is turned on, there is some kind of recalculation to the section containers on rendering to get the proper 100% size. Unfortunately it does not work when you turn off this option.

Anyway, I would love to set the proper height to my containers by css already. I am using some kind of lazy JS loading with fullPage.js and I want to prevent the the section to be resized on rendering.

Sorry - I was wrong that this has something to do with the verticalCentered option. In fact the height is also recalculated when this option is turned off. But on iOS (and very likely on other mobile devices, too), the viewport height is obviously different as there are UI elements of the browser changing its height / appearance on scrolling. I noticed that this behavior seems to be suppressed when fullPage.js is running. Is there any way to run it in the "normal" way where the browser UI elements hide on scrolling? Especially on small devices it takes a lot of space to keep them always visible.

> Is there any way to run it in the "normal" way where the browser UI elements hide on scrolling?

You can take a look at this two topics:

https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/1690
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1660

I haven't merged it yet, but there's a possible solution there. 

> Especially on small devices it takes a lot of space to keep them always visible.

There's no way to decide whether to "keep them visible" or not. That's just the way each browser deals with it. The only way you can make the browser navigation bars to work in their usual way is when you use `autoScrolling:false` (or the responsive options firing it) or `scrollBar:true`.

No. We don't have control over the address bars.

I don't know what is the `minimal-ui` thing you are talking about. 
Using `scrollBar:true` the plugin scrolls the page normally, which means the scroll event is being fired.

Showing or hidding the address bar will depend on the browser and we developers have no direct control over it.

It seems that the transforms get removed on the slides, but not on the wrapper itself when setAllowScrolling is set to true. The translateZ hack used here can make problems with position fixed children.

Which translateZ are you talking about? fullpage.js only uses `translate3d`.
Also, why do you mention setAllowScrolling? That only allows or denies the scrolling. It has no effect over any `translate` property.

My fault. The setAllowScrolling has no effect on any translate value, you are right. 
What I meant with translateZ is the last value of translate3d. A setting of 0 is a setting (default is none). So hardware acceleration is activated, which is good during animations.

But I noticed the behaviour of position: fixed realigning occurs in all forms of transform properties. Under normal scroll (`autoScrolling: false`), when a section is longer than the window height, the active flag in navigation can be wrong. This PR fixes this issue.

The current logic (in the base fork) calculates the difference between the `section.offsetTop` and `$window.scrollTop()` for each section and pick the one with the smallest diff as active. However, this can be wrong. For example, suppose there are two sections A and B, where section A is much longer than the window height. Consider the case when you have _just_ scrolled B entering the viewport. At this point, section B occupies very little area of the window, whereas section A still dominates. However, `diff(A.offsetTop, window.ScrollTop) < diff(B.offsetTop , window.ScrollTop)` as A is very long and the top of B is much closer to the window scrollTop. This will select section B as the current active section _wrongly_.

To fix this issue, I changed the logic to explicitly find _which section passes the middle line of the screen_. This will work correctly for the scenario above, where the top of section B obviously does not pass the middle line. 

Corner cases:
- If section B is short and there is a section C coming, selecting section B as active when it passes the middle line is still acceptable because it is the section at the screen center (which is the center of attention).
- In the case of `autoScrolling: true`, my modification works as well. So there is no negative side-effect.

Thanks for it @hang-qi! 
I'll take a look at it.

When fullpage.js has a window width trigger, the responsiveWidth setting it does not perform as it should.

$(window).width() does not take window scrollbar into consideration, while CSS media queries do. So if the page is responsive, CSS media queries and fullpage.js does not perform in sync. As different browsers have a different pixel amount for the scrollbar width, the only option is to use the window.outerWidth to perform calculations.
I probably agree with the outerWith. But not quite sure about the outerHeight. It might create problems with mobile browsers and their top and bottom bars.
Take a look at [this is a similar topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/1660) in an attemp to change the `$(window).height();` for `window.innerHeight`.
Agree. I'll revert the window.outerHeight to the jquery function $window.height() for a new pull request.
Thanks for it! I'll test it before merging it with the next release.

Seems to be giving problems with phones... I'll probably have to roll it back.
See https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1768

When fullpage.js has a window width trigger, the responsiveWidth setting it does not perform as it should.

$(window).width() does not take window scrollbar into consideration, while CSS media queries do. So if the page is responsive, CSS media queries and fullpage.js does not perform in sync. As different browsers have a different pixel amount for the scrollbar width, the only option is to use the window.outerWidth to perform calculations.

Thanks for it!
Can you commit the changes to the `dev` branch instead?
Sure, I'll change the branch.

Something I noticed:

1) On an iPhone 6, $(window).height() returns 559 which reflects the actual viewport (minus the Safari header and footer elements). This works great.
2) On an iPhone 4, $(window).height() returns 480, which reflects the full canvas (with the header and footer elements included). This causes extra room on the top and the bottom which messes with vertical alignment and can potentially allow the user to wiggle the page. 

I think window.innerHeight is a better solution. It returns 372 on the iPhone 4 which is the correct value. 

-Max

> This causes extra room on the top and the bottom which messes with vertical alignment and can potentially allow the user to wiggle the page.

Yes, we are. This is with iOS 9, specifically â€” but I think the difference exists from iOS 7 forward (when they started using the semi-transparent overlay style for the Safari menus). You could actually scroll the page only if you included an element that wasn't capturing the touch events.

@alvarotrigo i recently experienced the same issue on a recent project, but found a solution on stack overflow

Issue: Upon scrolling vertically and horizontally on safari iOS, the content would appear only after 1 - 1.5 seconds. 

Solution: added -webkit-transform: translate3d(0,0,0) to each fullpage section

Solution Reference:  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9807620/ipad-safari-scrolling-causes-html-elements-to-disappear-and-reappear-with-a-delay

Hope this helps someone :)

@daltonpereira I would need a reproduction so I can see the problem by myself .

If you use the touchpad of the macbook pro and a small value for scrollingSpeed property (for fast scrolling animation) â€”Â it is very difficult to scroll only one page, often one page (or several pages) is skipped.

Default scrollingSpeed value is 700 which doesn't seem to have this problem, but the less value you will set the stronger this problem will be. For instance, with scrollingSpeed = 100 it will scroll several pages even on small gentle swipe.

I'll take a look at some point, but bare in mind the solution will be to force a 700 milliseconds pause between swipe and swipe. 

Meaning once you reach a section your swipes won't have any effect until 700 milliseconds pass from the last recorded scroll. Which is a solution many people disliked time ago.

As far as I understood, magic number 700ms is a swipe duration on OS X (and probably other platforms). In this case say I set scrollingSpeed = 250, then I don't need 700ms pause after scroll, 700 âˆ’ 250 = 450ms will be enough, please correct me if I'm wrong.

> 700ms is a swipe duration on OS X

Not exactly. It depends on the inertia. It won't assure 100%  to avoid double scrolls if you scroll pretty fast. But as it is not common to scroll that fast, its a number that won't super annoy users but will assure to avoid most of the double scrolls.

700 has proven to be a good number in the past. That's all.

OK, I found a bunch of similar issues created and closed earlier. 
I don't think that force pause after page scroll will be good solution since it will annoy users with mouse wheels and keyboards.

Many developers use small scrollingSpeed values (because it looks cool and fast) but they don't use touchpads, so they even don't know that touchpad users will experience scrolling problem on their websites.

I would suggest adding "Known issues" section to documentation or a note about this issue to section describing "scrollingSpeed" property â€”Â at least it will decrease the amount of opened tasks about this problem and warn developers about risks :)

> I don't think that force pause after page scroll will be good solution since it will annoy users with mouse wheels and keyboards.

If you have any better solution I would welcome it :) 

> I would suggest adding "Known issues" section to documentation or a note about this issue to section describing "scrollingSpeed" property â€” at least it will decrease the amount of opened tasks about this problem and warn developers about risks :)

The number of people reporting or asking for this kind of issue has decreased significantly since the new solution was adopted time ago.
It seems not many people opt for a faster scrolling and they don't usually have problems with it. 

In any case, I prefer to keep track of the issues or bugs here in the issues forum. That's why I also try to keep it to a low number of opened issues. Easy to look at 60 issues to have a quick overview of the known issues or possible enhancements.

I came on here to report the issue but seems someone beat me to the punch. 

Here's what I've found.

1) 500 seems to be the "breaking" point. 600 will work fine but 500 won't. 
2) It depends on the length of stroke on the trackpad. As was said, a short quick stroke will scroll two pages. A long stroke won't. I can reproduce it fairly consistently and on a Dell trackpad as well.
3) For me the only reason it would be an issue is responsiveness. In beta testing my site some users complained that 700 felt "too unresponsive" or "slow". I changed to 400 and that was much better received but then some had issues with scrolling two sections instead of one. For now I've limited the scroll speed to 600. I think from a user experience standpoint it is preferable to have as slightly slower scroll speed than to have two sections scroll past.

`autoScrolling:true` would solve it. [Demo online](http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/913/)

I tried to implement a fix here: https://github.com/cygery/fullPage.js/commit/8db320daf3fb16bd0448d6f0f5e80008778fce80. The general idea is to check if we scrolled to the bottom (or at most 1px from it) and then always select the last section as the active one. Needs an additional check when using the scroll bar (see commit).
I did some tests and can't find any issues with that approach so far. However, I don't know what issues it might cause in other configurations although I can't think of any.
Also, a similar approach could be used for an auto height top section.

The question is. Why do you care that much?

There are still a large chunk of internet users who live on a very slow connection. Depending on what's your target market / demographics, even 10kB could mean a lot, esp. on mobile. As a side note, see why Facbeook is experimenting with [2G tuesdays](http://www.theverge.com/2015/10/28/9625062/facebook-2g-tuesdays-slow-internet-developing-world) . > But scrollbar still appear on the page!

Because you didn't read the documentation carefully.

autoScrolling: (default true) Defines whether to use the "automatic" scrolling **or the "normal"** one. It also has affects the way the sections fit in the browser/device window in tablets and mobile phones.

This means, normal scrolling will ALWAYS have scroll bar. So you should use the default  `autoScrolling: true` and the default `scrollBar:false` as in the [demo page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/) which, by the way, is available in the examples folder.

Or, if you just want keyboard, use the method `setAllowScrolling(false)` but that will work with autoScroll

Hi Alvaro,

Is it possible to center some content bigger than the viewport?

For example, from this link http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/894/, 

after clicking on click here,
if you go from the side navigation to Floor Plans
 and then click for example on number 13 or 14,

the content obviously doesn't center properly as it is bigger than the viewport. Ideally I would need to have the content push outside of it's container, having a top negative position.

Does it make sense and would that possible with your plugin?

Thank you for your amazing plugin!

> Does it make sense and would that possible with your plugin?

No it doesn't really. Vertically to what? Your section is not even using `scrollOverflow` and therefore will only have the viewport height.

You would have to use some scrollbar or use `scrollOverflow:true` and then `reBuild` once you open your row. But that wouldn't center it vertically. It would just allow you to scroll to the content.
Ok thank you for your help. I will use scrollOverflow:true and then center vertically it to the viewport with javascript. Thank you again.

> So... is there any easier way to accomplish this?

Yeah. Use the `menu` option. 
You can create any kind of menu / nav with it and it will add the active class where it should. 

From [the documentation](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js):

> **menu:** (default false) A selector can be used to specify the menu to link with the sections. This way the scrolling of the sections will activate the corresponding element in the menu using the class active. **This won't generate a menu but will just add the active class to the element in the given menu with the corresponding anchor links**. In order to link the elements of the menu with the sections, an HTML 5 data-tag (data-menuanchor) will be needed to use with the same anchor links as used within the sections. Example:

You are probably initializing fullpage.js multiple times. Check it out.
Yea i gotta have to, i am using it with angular js as well. So i am initialling fullpage js everytime i reload the new page. but somehow it keeps adding incorrect number of navigation.

> Yea i gotta have to

No, you don't have to. And if you are doing it, that's wrong. 

The plugin only requires one initialisation per page load.

The navigation problem occurs when you initialize the page/plugin and change views, but you don't correctly call the destroy method when your view switches. This happens when you call fullPage.js in the controller, and solving it as part of a controller can be a bit of a hassle.

I created an [angular directive](https://github.com/hellsan631/angular-fullpage.js) and that was one of the problems that I solved. When ever your view changes it will correctly destroy the old html (navigation) and re-initialize it again when ever the directive appears again.

Hey all,

I have the following website setup:

![photo_2015-10-09_13-15-50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6825057/10392499/e9d98886-6e87-11e5-9456-43d9b56f5284.jpg)

Every fullpage section has two slides. On the first slide, the amount of content is small enough to fit inside the dimensions of one screen. On the second slide, the amount of content is way bigger, so scrollOverflow is set to true to make scrolling possible.

I would like to disable setAllowScrolling on each second slide, therefore I used the following javascript in the onSlideLeave callback.

> $.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(nextSlideIndex == 0);

On Chrome and Firefox, this works like a charm. On Safari however, scrolling on a second slide doesn't work. It does work after you manually grab the slimscroll bar and move it a little bit with your mouse pointer. It also works if you change the $.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling value in the console of the browser directly. I think something goes wrong while initializing the slimscroll plugin in Safari using this setup.

Yep, they are not suppose to. 

> I would like to disable setAllowScrolling on each second slide

Why would you do that?
It makes no sense to have two scroll bars from the UX perspective.

I am not convinced that we are talking about the same concept. Let me try to explain it in greater detail.

I'd like the second slide to act as a 'more information' page for each first slide. The idea is to add a 'back' button in the upper left corner and the bottom of each second slide to return to the first slide.

> Why would you do that?

It's very confusing if a user scrolls to the bottom of a 'more information' second slide, whereafter he get's a transition to the next 'more information' second slide. That's why I want to make it impossible to switch sections if a user is looking at a second slide. At the bottom of the slide the user sees a clear visual cue that the bottom of the slide is reached, with a button to return to slide 1 of the current section.

> It makes no sense to have two scroll bars from the UX perspective.

My idea does not involve two scroll bars. It only involves one scroll bar on each second 'more information' slide, being the slimscroll one. This is the correct usage of the scrollOverflow option.

The only problem is that prohibiting a user from switching sections when he is on a second slide, using the setAllowScrolling method, seems to break the scrollOverflow function in Safari.

Long story short: I am looking for a way to enable scrolling in one slide of a section, but disable switching between sections from that slide. The obvious way to handle this works in Chrome and Firefox, but breaks the scrollOverflow scrolling functionality in Safari.

> I am not convinced that we are talking about the same concept.

Nop, we are not. My fault. I read it very fast and I though you said `$.fn.fullpage.setAutoscrolling(false)`  instead of `$.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(false)`.

I'll open the issue again. 
In any case, it seems a slimScroll problem again. Have you tried using an scrollable element instead ? `overflow-y:scroll`.
I made a demo here: http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/888/

The demo works as expected, although I found one improvement. You toggle setAutoscrolling in the afterSlideLoad callback, but it's more consistent if you toggle it in the onSlideLeave callback.

Thank you for your quick response!

> You toggle setAutoscrolling in the afterSlideLoad callback, but it's more consistent if you toggle it in the onSlideLeave callback.

Yep, unless you go from Section 1 to Section2 slide 2 :)
But that might not be your case.

If you add `data-anchor` attributes to sections as well as to slides and you set `showActiveTooltip:true` then the tooltips for all sections following a section with slides will vanish.

Here is a slightly modified version of the example file  _navigationV.html_  that demonstrates the problem if you scroll down to the third section (which comes after a section containing slides). For that third section no tooltip is shown.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Thanks for reporting it. 

Reproduction online: http://jsfiddle.net/imac/97tbk/884/
Just found that it is not only the tooltip disappearing, but also the third navigation dot not being highlighted. So the tooltip not appearing is probably only an inherited error of that.

Another side effect:  Any sections after the section with the slides cannot be jumped to using `#sectionName` links. This affects for example any menu links within the page but also calls through external links containing a `#sectionName`. For the same reason a browser reload when a section after the slide section is active does not navigate back to that section.

I fixed the problem with the mixed section and slide anchors by editing a little piece in the js.

I added the options.sectionSelector previous to the [data-anchor] attr so the navigation only selects the anchors of the sections. Be sure to add a data-anchor for all sections.

Yep, that's totally normal. 
The plugin needs your DOM structure to be ready in order to get initialized. And meanwhile, your content will be visible in the order it should.

Instead of using fullpage.js at the bottom of your page before the cosing `</body>` I would recommend you to load it on your header `<header>` of your site.

Same as with any other plugin or script you use. 
**Why?**
Because the only reason to add the plugins at the bottom of the site is to prevent the site to be "blocked" until they load.
But if your main purpose is to **only show the site content** once the plugin is initialized, then there's no reason at all to add them at the bottom of your site. 

That should solve your problem. 
Just place all of this in your header:

> <S_CODE_TOKEN>

You can test it with any example provided in the plugin. You'see how you don't see the flickering. Basically because the plugin is loaded in the header.
You can test it here as well: http://jsfiddle.net/813euvy2/

@d13 I'm not used to work with sass or scss but there's something wrong on the gulp file.

You said in the read me

> // Only compile the SCSS
> gulp scss

But `gulp sass` is what its required instead.
Not quite sure what are you doing there though.
The mistake is in the documentation, I should have written `sass` as the task name as that is technically what is being compiled. `.scss` is just the file extension for SASS.
I'll push a fix for this shortly.

@d13 what are you really doing with the SCSS file? Compiling it to `.css`?

In that case we should better get rid of it, as I usually work directly on the CSS file. I have the SCSS for other developers who might be interested in playing with it.

@alvarotrigo - Yes, the `sass` task compiles the SCSS to `.css`. If you're providing a SCSS file, you should provide the means to build it in the way you expect the final CSS to look. 

What I suggest as a middle ground is to remove it from the `default` task and just have the developer run the sass task manually before running the compression tasks.
Yep, removing it from the global task should do it as I wouldn't personally use it.

On mobile browsers when you scroll down the header auto hides itself to give more space to view the content. But with fullpage.js it is not working. Could it be because the scrolling is "artificially" done?

How could i make this work?

> On mobile browsers when you scroll down the header auto hides itself to give more space to view the content.

On some.

> Could it be because the scrolling is "artificially" done?

Try not using anchor or using  `lockAnchors:true`. Otherwise, you'll have to use `autoScrolling:false` or `scrollBar:true`.

In any case, there's nothing that can be done in the plugin deal with that. That depends on each browser and we have no access to the address bar controls.

> As in the picture above you can see, scrolling does not autohide the header. This is important for me because my fullpage implementation is a "gallery" where each page is an image. So it is important that the header is hidden to have a fullscreen effect.

I'm afraid you won't have your ideal effect in many other browsers, or Operative Systems. Not all hide the address bar.

Also, it depends if you load the site when the phone is in landscape or if you load it in portrait and change to landscape.

Hey Ãlvaro,
## Delta and scrolling on Mac OS X

Thanks for creating this awesome script! I noticed that scroll will often trigger unexpectedly on Mac OS X so I added a minDelta value to work around that. Itâ€™s set to a default of 20 which seems like a nice balance between not having to scroll too hard and not accidentally causing unwanted scrolling.
## Node modules

I noticed that node_modules weren't excluded from the repo so I went ahead and did that.
## Minification

I couldn't find any minification task so the didn't compress the code. _That probably means you shouldn't accept this pull request just yet_, but if you tell me how you prefer the code to be compressed (Which tool to use and any options I should enable)  then I'll send a new pull request your way.

When I upgraded from 2.6.0 to 2.7.2, this functionality changed in a way I didn't expect. My site had been structured like this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I had `normalScrollElements` set to `.slide-content`.

In 2.7.2, that structure produced behavior where I could scroll from the first section to the second, but once I got to the second, scrolling stopped. When I went to the second slide in the second section (.slide-content), I still got the expected behavior (content scrolling, but locked so as not to scroll to other sections).

The way that I worked around the issue was to change the structure to this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Once I did that, I could scroll between sections as desired, as well as having the `.slide-content` slides scroll through their content but not to other slides (as desired).

You are not suppose to use `normalScrollElements` in any section or slide element.

which consolidates all code related to scrollOverflow and
allows it to be swapped out with different functionality.

By default, it will use the existing jquery.slimScroll handling
of scroll overflow.

This should make it easier for users to either customize the
slimScroll handling or replace it with other code just as wrapping
content in a div with overflow: scroll or utilizing iscroll.js
as requested in issues #506, #612 and others.

This pull request is a re-opening of #1498 against the new "dev" branch.
Thanks!

Hello,

Apparently this is a well known bug, but backgrounds on iOS scale to the body div and not screen size with size:cover. What effectively happens is the image gets rendered at full-scale, thus only showing the top-left corner of it, zoomed in (depending on size of image)

The solution that is often given (https://css-tricks.com/forums/topic/full-page-backgrounds-on-ios-background-size-cover/page/3/) is to make div fixed and size: 100% 100%, but with fullpage.js, if I want my second slide down to have a background image, that solution won't work.

I searched the web and this forum to see if anyone else had come across this problem, and I was surprised to not find anything.

Has anyone come across this problem before and may know of a solution?

The website I'm working on, for reference, is: http://nickaxel.com/foam/index_test.html

Thank you.

It doesn't seem to be a fullpage.js related problem.
Also, the topic is from 2012 and probably the bug doesn't exist in modern phones or iOS anymore. 

I can see [the background demo](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/backgrounds.html) as expected on my iPhone 5 with the latest iOS.

You can get the scrolling event and the direction of it by using the [`onLeave` callback](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#onleave-index-nextindex-direction).

Then, [you can cancel the scroll before it takes place](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#cancelling-the-scroll-before-it-takes-place) and do whatever you want instead. 

But of course, the animation you want to do, or whatever you have in mind, would have to be done by yourself.

Hi.

I configured fullPage with `responsiveWidth` set to `801`. Unfortunately, below 801px in width, the plugin works normally, as above 801px. How can I turn it off then?

I would also disable the plugin from firing on all pages but homepage. How to do it?

This is my actual code:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The responsive option is not to turn it off.
Please read the documentation regarding the responsive options:

> **responsiveWidth:** (default 0) A normal scroll (autoScrolling:false) will be used under the defined width in pixels. A class fp-responsive is added to the plugin's container in case the user wants to use it for his own responsive CSS. For example, if set to 900, whenever the browser's width is less than 900 the plugin will scroll like a normal site.
> 
> **responsiveHeight:** (default 0) A normal scroll (autoScrolling:false) will be used under the defined height in pixels. A class fp-responsive is added to the plugin's container in case the user wants to use it for his own responsive CSS. For example, if set to 900, whenever the browser's height is less than 900 the plugin will scroll like a normal site.

You would need to manually destroy it by listening the `resize` event and then calling the `destroy` function.

You'd better ask in other place such as http://stackoverflow.com/ in which they'll provide you a better answer regarding the procedure of listening the resize event and check the site width.

@kaiserhase How are you loading content into your app? Are the slides initializing with ng-repeat? I [made an angular directive](https://github.com/hellsan631/angular-fullpage.js) that might interest you, and should cover most basic support for using fullpage with angular. I've been able to solve some issues, but the one I have trouble with is dynamic DOM changes and how to react to them.

Angular can dynamically change the DOM based on what ever events the developer wants. In order to react to these changes, I currently have to [destroy and re-initialize](https://github.com/hellsan631/angular-fullpage.js/blob/master/angular-fullpage.js#L25) the entire plugin. I've looked at the docs for `$.fn.fullpage.reBuild()` and I would imagine this might work, but I haven't had any luck with it actually updating the DOM structure. 

Example: I want to bind a click event to a button that adds a slide dynamically on page. In order for fullPage.js to recognize that this new slide (added to the DOM after a click event) exists, my thoughts are that I should be calling `$.fn.fullpage.reBuild()` instead of `destroy('all')`, correct?

Yet when I do this, nothing happens. Currently, I am using a work around that tracks the current page/slide and after a destroy/build cycle, it will move to the last page/slide, but this takes up several plugin functions and the animations still happen (even though i'm using a silent move-to for some reason). 

An example of this can be [found here](http://hellsan631.github.io/angular-fullpage.js/), under second slide.

Any insights into this, @alvarotrigo?

@hellsan631 maybe I should be more specific on the documentation for `reBuild`. 
That function will only take into account changes you made inside sections / slides. Not in the number of slides or sections you have.
The purpose of the function is mainly to provide users who use `scrollOverflow:true` a way to update the DOM and then tell fullpage.js that the scroll bar for that section needs to be updated. 

Destroying it and initializing it again is the way to go for it for now.

I believe you are talking about your `thmlvCaptionWrapper` element.

You should place it within the section, not outside the fullpage.js wrapper. 
The reason is fullpage.js only catches the touch events on the plugin wrapper. not on the whole document. (to avoid problems with menus, headers or even external plugins with touch detection... )

Sorry I misunderstood your problem.
It seems you are trying to scroll within a section to a certain internal anchor by its `id`.

I would say you can not use internal anchors to scroll to anywhere in your site, as this is a full page plugin and therefore the browser scrolling to the `id` element will move all the sections in the wrong position. 

You can only fix it if you decide to use fullpage.js with the option `scrollBar:true` or `autoScrolling:false`.

Resizing process (`resizeMe()`) should be done also at `init()`.
As it is not, with `resize: true`, initial screen is not resized through that process, and resizing window a little makes a big difference.

There's no way for the plugin to know how you want to display your text.

Read [this answer](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/492#issuecomment-45110427).

I would encourage you to use other plugin for that such as [Flowtype](http://simplefocus.com/flowtype/)

Solved in 2.7.2

This update adds a new option called 'scrollOverflowHandler'
which consolidates all code related to scrollOverflow and
allows it to be swapped out with different functionality.

By default, it will use the existing jquery.slimScroll handling
of scroll overflow.

This should make it easier for users to either customize the
slimScroll handling or replace it with other code just as wrapping
content in a div with `overflow: scroll` or utilizing iscroll.js
as requested in issues #506, #612 and others.
Created a [gist](https://gist.github.com/rmarscher/5f3a62b960f5f903a6af) with a potential alternative iscroll-based handler for scrollOverflow.

Thanks for it!!
Looks like we have some beautiful code out there! :)

I'll take a deeper look at it, maybe not that much as a way to expect other developers to create their own handler, but more as a way to allow them to choose between using iScroll.js or slimScroll.js. (or even use a fallback for IE < 10 if slimScroll.js is present)
Thanks, @alvarotrigo! I'm sure maintaining this library is a lot of work. I hope this helps.

Duplicated of https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1281

One thing is for sure: you can not have a whole section with a draggable map. Or you won't be able to swipe up or down your site. 

If you want to do so, what I would recommend is disabling the scroll in all directions with `setAllowScrolling` once your reach the map section ( by using a callback such as `afterLoad`).

Then, in order to move up or down I would add two arrows (or whatever you prefer) to which you can bind the `moveSectionDown` or `moveSectionUp` functions.

Is it possible to use navigation without hash in the URL and use the browser history instead?

Yeah sure. Just don't use any `data-anchor` attribute in your sections and get rid of the `anchors` option as [in this example](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/noAnchor.html). 

However, you can block the anchors for browser history but still using them in your page for direct access to sections or slides, for callbacks or even for aesthetics. 
Check the option `lockAnchors` [in the docs](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js):

> **lockAnchors:** (default false). Determines whether anchors in the URL will have any effect at all in the plugin. You can still using anchors internally for your own functions and callbacks, but they won't have any effect in the scrolling of the site. Useful if you want to combine fullPage.js with other plugins using anchor in the URL.

You can even lock them dynamically with [`setLockAnchors`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#setlockanchorsboolean) as you can see in [this other demo](http://codepen.io/alvarotrigo/pen/yNxVRQ).

Not sure this will help in your case, but I needed to disable fitToSection on a project but it would still kick in on resize, rotate and sometimes on nav click (the section would be refitted over and over despite autoScrolling and fitToSection set to false). My workaround for that was to set fitToSectionDelay to 3600000 which I believe is one hour in milliseconds. That way the current section doesn't scroll to fill the screen, it stays where you want it, which is very good when you have a lot of content in sections and want to be able to view it all on a phone.

> Is there any optimal setting that can be used ?

Nop. I would encourage you to get rid of `scrollOverflow` and use the `responsive` option instead combined with [`fp-auto-heigh`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#creating-smaller-sections) or [similar](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1044#issuecomment-75812112).

This question might be better suited for [Stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14304494/responsive-web-design-is-working-on-desktop-but-not-on-mobile-device) (because it doesn't directly relate to the plugin itself). Regardless, I believe if you place this in the `<head>` of your HTML it will allow your viewport to be responsive: `<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">`

A good spot for this would be under `<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />` ... although it is not required to be there. Just as long as it is between your `<head> ... </head>` tags you should be alright.

This is a fix for issue #1442 

Moved the local variable cache assignment out of `requestAnimationFrame` to avoid them being overwritten before being saved.

Also changed `!isResizing` to `!v.localIsResizing` in first check inside `requestAnimationFrame`.

Re-sizing bug no longer occurs, although the slides do animate after re-size instead of instantly snapping into position. I'm not sure if this was the original intended effect or not, so I'm leaving it as-is. The `css3: false` was for testing, it works with both CSS3 and JQuery animations.
I believe this will produce [the popular bug in Chrome 44](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1389).
Will test for it and make adjustments if possible.

I would probably wait until the next version of Chrome is released before taking any deeper look at it. 
If the next Chrome version fixed its bug, then we won't have to worry about this bug either as it will automatically dissappear when removing `requestAnimationFrame`

It shouldn't conflict with Chrome bug, because we just creating object and doesn't assign any translate3d anywhere.
Also if you want to remove animation you should change this in performMovement function:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
The issue was solved in 2.7.1.

> fp-auto-height ignored when first section

From the docs: 

>  It is important to realise that it doesn't make sense to have all of your sections using this feature. **If there is more than one section in the initial load of the site, the plugin won't scroll at all to see the next one as it will be already in the viewport.**
This means at least the first section of your site will have to be FULL PAGE.

> Any tip :) ?

The plugin doesn't provide any way to do it. You'll have to do it yourself.
You would have to attach and event to the mouse wheel scrolling when you reach a section with slides.
Then you would have to disable the plugin scrolling with `setAllowScrolling` and then you'll have to call `moveSlideRight`or `moveSlideLeft` depending on the direction of the scrolling.

> There is a clear issue with your plugin when using google maps on any section of it, on mobile devices when the user touches the map it scrolls back to the previous section which is really annoying.

It is just the way it is. You won't be able to use maps unless you use `normalScrollElements` for it. But then, you won't be able to scroll to any other section if you are using it in fullscreen and using `autoScrolling:true`. 

If you are in fact using `normalScrollElements` [there's another bug regarding it which is has been opened for a while](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1281).

No solution was found I'm afraid.

Again, thank you very much for your help. When I get my payment I promise I will make a little donation to encourage your work and dedication, which I admire.

There's an [open topic for that problem](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/506).

No solution for it yet. I would recommend you to really adapt your site to your device by removing content or directly by destroying fullpage.js or [overriding the size of the sections](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1044#issuecomment-75812112).

Hello.
Vertical window resizing causes a bug with slides: active slide gets out beyond the browser window. Scrolling to next slide fixes the problem.
Tested in chrome and firefox last versions (ubuntu 14.04) on http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/

Introduced in the last release 2.6.9 due to the fix of [Chrome bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=513206). Directly related with another problem with `fitToSection`.
It is a problem of synchrony created by the use of  `requestAnimationFrame`.

Thanks for reporting it!

I am a JS novice, so forgive me if this is obvious or non-relevant: Could this issue be partially caused by calling promise().done() on an animation in performMovment() that would be scheduled but not completed due to performMovment() being inside the requestAnimationFrame() callback function, causing the function to hang until a scroll event forced the animation repaint and thus satisfied the promise().done()? When I tested the function inside the promise().done() with a simple console line, it was not running after a re-size until I fired a scroll event.
@voxes if you think you have a solution please commit a pull request.

You shouldn't be using `normalScrollElements` for a whole section. That's not the purpose of it. That's only for some elements smaller than he viewport within the section. Not the whole section itself. 
As the documentation states:

>  (useful for maps, scrolling divs etc.) 

If you want normal scroll for it you should be using `scrollOverflow:true` as [in this example](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html) available in the download.
Thanks. I didn't think about that. :)

It doesn't seem to be a fullpage.js related problem. 
I would suggest you to ask in other place such as stackoverflow.com in which they'll help you better.

When drag scolling with middle mouse, updating the window.location.hash causes a repaint (on Chrome) which breaks the middle mouse scroll completely. Basically, it always interrupts scrolling half way a new section.

The problem happens in setUrlHash() after it has been fired through SetState from the scrollHandler, with autoScrolling false and fitToSection false.

(the culprit: window.location.replace( baseUrl + '#' + url );)

The best solution would be to always use replaceState if the browser supports it, only falling back to location for older ie browsers.

Scrolling by dragging the mouse while pressing the mouse middle button will scroll vertically one section. 

I'm not quite sure what is the problem you are describing, but it seems to me that it can be related with [this open issue](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1389) which is a bug of the last version of Chrome.
Please confirm if this is only taking place in Chrome 44 and not in any other browser. If so, I'll close the issue as it seems to be a duplicate one.

It's specifically a problem with updating window.location causing a repaint

I changed it to pushstate since chrome supports history

@alvarotrigo sorry, it is a bit strange, because, if you will load your script synchronously at the html body i guess this condition will always return true (document.readyState != "complete"). But if you require(fullpage.js) asynchronously it is mean that sometimes, fullpage.js might be required after LOAD event fired.

The solution doesn't seem to be simple.

I would argue that it doesn't make much sense to load fullpage.js dynamically as it is necessary for the correct visualization of the page in any case.

You might controll loading manually, so if you show loading image which is playing until all async libs are loaded. In my opinion it is not a good practice to control such a thing inside library exclusively.  
IMO scrollToAnchor should be possible to run manually and of course i guess it is a trouble if your library execution logic depends on the loading order =(((
