I have a quite complex site being developed with this plugin running the slides. My problem was that in few earlier iterations of the site, I've added an element that is absolutely positioned, outside of the initial 100% body width. Meaning, it will generate a horizontal scrollbar, which will make problems for calculating height of the screen, because it's then -15px (or so) smaller. Plugin initializes a moment later, and I didn't even notice the scrollbar for quite some time.

This isn't the plugin problem, just be careful when doing stuff like that. This was really needle in a haystack, but somehow I managed to find it.

Maybe, if you could read window height differently, to not include scrollbar, since scrollbar will be removed after plugin initializes. Just an idea, you check if this should be tagged as enhancement.

I'm not sure how else to report this. Label it however you want, this isn't really my issue, and basically I closed it with this.

Thank you for an amazing plugin! You've done great work!

Best regards

I'm not sure to understand your problem.
It would be nice if you could reproduce it in jsfiddle to us to have some idea.

The issues you mention were both solved and were due to errors from the developers side. 

I'll close the issue until an isolated reproduction of the problem is provided.

There you go, check the height of the element, which isn't 100% of the container after the plugin load. It is when you initialize the plugin, but it's invalid after that, because it includes scrollbar which appears because of absolute positioned element. Of course, same happens if you use translateX for repositioning some element outside of the slide.

Not really an issue, but noticed some folks having a similar issue, and they just might not have been careful and this could be the case.

It;s true. I have similiar problem and was confused by it. The cause is more then 100% of viewport width of page before plugin loaded. http://weil.works/#about 
@ntucakovic how did you resolve this issue?
Possibly related with https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1502

Basically, you need to make sure that your browser doesn't have any scrollbars just before the plugin is initialized. In my case, best solutions was to hide the elements before the plugin is initialized (I was able to do that, it might not be able to solve it like that in your case).

Other possible solutions would be to set max-height and overflow hidden to your sections, before the plugin is initialized (in crucial CSS, which should be loaded ASAP). Then once the plugin is initialized you can remove that.

You could also hide elements that are causing such behavior in JS just before initializing plugin, and show them in afterRender function, when plugin is initialized as it should.

If there are some other solutions, I'd gladly consider? But either way, this isn't a plugin problem but the problem to your implementation. Not sure if related to #1502
@ntucakovic Thanx for fast and full answer
Because i use preloader with function `$(window).on('load'`, i just make section with element outside viewport appear only after dom completed.

a note for coffee users - make sure you explicitly return a value from your onLeave callback, or at least have a return statement. You might be getting false negatives, preventing scrolling with the RAF update.

The reBuild function does not what you expect:

> **reBuild()**
> Updates the DOM structure to fit the new window size or its contents. Ideal to use in combination with AJAX calls or external changes in the DOM structure of the site.

It only adapts the plugin to the new window dimensions. Something necessary when using `scrollOverflow:true`.

In your case you would have to use [`destroy('all')`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#destroytype) to destroy the plugin and then initialize it again.

Hi there,

Great plug-in, well done!

Is there a way to change the scroll sensitivity on desktop like you're able to for mobile devices using touch scroll sensitivity?

Nop.
Why? Because mouse scroll sensitivity is not the same in all computers / devices.

Kinetic scrolling like the one in Apple laptops or some trackpads is very different from a mouse wheel.

Every time I load my website, it flashes the whole content for a moment: http://dekatria.co.uk/. Could you please advise me on this issue?

Initialize it on DOM ready as stated in the docs, and not on load. (which is what you are doing when adding the js at the end of the page)

You don't want to see anything from the website until fullpage.js is initialized.

If you still preferring using fullPage.js on load, then you would have to add the following CSS:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Where `#fullPage` is the selector you use to initialize fullPage.js and `.section` is the selector you use for the classes.

**fullPage.js** was already initialised inside the DOM ready:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I have tried both of your approaches: moved **jQuery** and the **fullPage.js** initialisation to the `head`, and also tried applying the CSS you have suggested. Nothing seems to work.

I've tried it with [this example](http://paste.ofcode.org/HrBEmPpn23Hj3TAJ63yQ3k) and it works as expected applying the CSS styles I mentioned.

The CSS file will be loaded before your DOM is ready. 
If you make sure that your sections are 100% height before anything loads, then you won't see the flickering anymore as the flickering was caused by showing the 2nd or 3rd section before the plugin was applied.

> fullPage.js was already initialised inside the DOM ready:

Even though you are using document ready, you are placing the javascript at the bottom of your site, just before the closing `</body>`, and this will force the javascript to load at the end, once the whole site is loaded. 
So in this case your document ready will be like a document load.

You can test it yourself in the example I created. You'll see the difference between placing the scripts in the header or in the bottom.

First of all, make sure you are using `css3:true` (which is the default value). CSS transforms are way faster than jQuery ones.

Also, you can try using lazy load for images, videos, backgrounds and audio elements.

A new functionality for it has just been introduced in fullPage.js 2.6.6 as you can see [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#lazy-loading) .
For the next version I'm planning to use a `lazyDistance` option as well.

In order to lazy load backgrounds, just follow the steps I detailed [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/46#issuecomment-26509996).

And if you wan to use AJAX to load the sections or slides content, I don't see why you couldn't do it. 
Just combine it with callbacks such as `onLeave` or `onSlideLeave` and you'll have a good result.

Had that issue on another project (none fullpage) and chrome is a bit fussy with some specifics.

"Parent elements can not have float on them.

Setting float:none on all parent elements makes page-break-before:always work correctly.

Other things that can break page-break are: using page-break inside tables, floating elements, inline-block elements, and block elements with borders."

Preface: All sections DO have anchor tags in this case. 

If you navigate to the index of a fullpage.js webpage without using an anchor link , you automatically go to the first section.
If you then scroll to the section below (or slide left/right), you will not be able to press the Browser's back button to go to the first section/page. 

Example: Go to http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/
Scroll down one section, then press the browser's back button. (I'm using Chrome). 
Your browser has not registered the first page and you either skip to the page previous or it does nothing at all.

Best,
Joel

Hi alvarotrigo

I can confirm we have also observed this behaviour in release 2.8.4. To test, we rolled back to version 2.6.6. This fixed the bug (but it introduced other issues which were undesirable for us).

Our method to reproduce:
1. If we start with a full screen page, on the first section (starting on any other section will not produce this bug).
2. We reduce the size of the page. (Our page uses OnResize to setAutoScrolling(false); below a certain size)
3. We maximise the window and reset setAutoScrolling(true);
4. Now the mousewheel and touchscroll doesn't work for scrolling until you use the down arrow.

Our workaround has been to add a null section. at the start of our page which is non-navigable.

Sorry, I'm sure this is a really quirky one for you to pin down.

> 1. We reduce the size of the page. (Our page uses OnResize to setAutoScrolling(false); below a certain size)

I guess you are talking about 2.8.4 ?
You shouldn't be doing this. 
Use the options `responsiveWidth` or `responsiveHeight`. 

I do not provide support for any old version of fullpage.js anyways.  (this is, less than 2.8.6)

Hi alvarotrigo

Thanks for the info. We are already using responsiveWidth and responsiveHeight in our solution on initialisation... sorry that was assumed. However we found that it didn't always switch mode in every resize scenario on every browser. This is why we do both. We force the interchange regardless of the scenario. It could that the two issues are interrelated. We're using horizontal sections, vertical slides and have a page that on moderate sized resolutions needs to vertically scroll, before we drop into responsive. This means we have both page based auto scrolling and in slide manual scrolling.

Happy to say the issue is way way we're using your framework, or that we're leaving the boundaries for which it was designed, but we can't pin it down yet.

That said we'll integrate 2.8.6 into our next build, run a battery of tests and let you know the outcome.

Regards

Explain yourself and why you think it's necessary.

In a project I needed to check not only the width but also the height of the viewport. Instead of adding another option I've added the ability to declare a function. The feature is also in another similar jQuery Plugin and I found it useful.

First of all, thanks for collaborating. 

The [responsive height](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/1256) option is a proposed enhancement I did myself.

Checking the `height` inside the plugin initialization doesn't seem very reasonable. It wouldn't work on viewport resizing. 

It seems to me adding a function  `setResponsive(boolean)` can be more useful for that. 
This way you would be able to apply the responsiveness whenever you want (on mobile phone, under certain condition...).

But I still believing a responsive height is necessary for those without the required knowledge of javascript.

The height is not checked during initialization process, but everytime the plugin checks if it should go in responsive mode, the function is called (if provided). In there, I can finely adjust when I want the plugin to go responsive and when not. And it works on viewport resizing â€“Â I use it just like that in production. 

Check the responsive-Example, I've edited it to clarify the use of a function for this use case (however, I've only read the width as in the original one).

But: A `setResponsive` function seems also useful to me.

> The height is not checked during initialization process, but everytime the plugin checks if it should go in responsive mode, the function is called (if provided)

Right. My mistake :D I don't know what was I thinking about.

The only problem I see with this method, although it seems useful, is that people with a basic knowledge of javascript might have troubles using it.

I see the `setResponsive` a more useful and versatile function to add.
Now that I think about it, there's no need to create the `setResponsive` option, as basically is the same as `setAutoScrolling`. The only difference is that hides the vertical navigation bullets.

It seems [this is causing problems for some users](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32550549/fullpage-js-onleave-firing-twice-when-return-false-in-all-browsers-but-chrome/32568174?noredirect=1#comment52999086_32568174) as Firefox listen to both events.

Also, as stated [in this other post](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/277), it is not convenient to use it. 

Mozilla warns [in their website](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/DOMMouseScroll):

> Non-standard
> This feature is non-standard and is not on a standards track. Do not use it on production sites facing the Web: it will not work for every user. There may also be large incompatibilities between implementations and the behavior may change in the future.

I might go for a way of detecting which handler to use as described [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/wheel).

Hello,
I discovered a bug.

If the website contains a link or a form when you press the "tab" key, the browser goes directly to the section concerned but the navigation is completely broken.

Yeah right. 
I was aware of it. 

The only solution is not simple... [Depending on the browser](http://stackoverflow.com/a/1600194/1081396) some elements are able to receive the focus on `tab` and others don't.

In order to prevent it, fullPage.js would have to set `tabIndex="-1"` to any of those elements outside the current section plus any element containing the attribute `tabindex`.
And if you have many links or inputs in your site, this could decrease the performance of your site on every section / slide change. 

The other option is just to disable the tab in fullPage.js. Or you manually setting tabindex to `-1`.

A quick fix we implemented was this...

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This basically does what alarotrigo said and disables tabbing globally on the page... We actually just got a complaint from a client saying that they couldn't tab through this one form so you might be getting a pull request if I can find a decent solution, but as you said it might affect performance if there are a ton of elements...

You can also set the wrapper of those elements to `display:none` or I believe you can even use `opacity:0` and probably...  `visibility: hidden`. This way you will only have to show the form on `onLeave` or just use the active class in the section to make it visible:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I'll keep looking into this issue. 
It might be able to be solved by using `opacity:0` for all the non visible sections. I believe that's the way [reveal.js](http://lab.hakim.se/reveal-js) deals with it.
Although they have a pretty ugly interval [here](https://github.com/hakimel/reveal.js/blob/master/js/reveal.js#L582) to solve problems with iframes. (you can actually test it by setting `opacity:1` to the next slide, you'll notice how it comes back after _tabbing_ )

I just did a test with the following.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

and I can still tab to the opaque elements, you might need to use display: none...
True.

Seems to work pretty well doing the following..

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Just need to make sure that it hides the previous after the animation is finished, and if you want to jump to a specific index you can't use .next obviously.. but as a proof of concept it seems to be functional.
It seems the `interval` is the solution they are using. That's why you can see a flickering although you don't see the next slide because it has `opacity: 0`.

@Criten your solution might carry some problems. It would need to be tested. But hiding the section completely on load (before even calling fullPage.js) might make things such as `$(SECTION_SEL).each(function(){` not work as expected.
In your case I would go for the CSS solution I provided.

A new functionality for the function `setKeyboardScrolling` has been introduced in fullPage.js 2.6.6.
Now, the function admits a `directions` parameter:

Hey, just wanted to share how to do this. 

I'm working on a site where every section has two child-divs `.half`. In my case the child divs have 50% width, 100% height of the section. And they have content with different heights. So I need to be able to scroll inside those divs and when I reached the bottom of either divs, fullpage-js needs to go to the next section.

The problem: 
When you activate slimscroll with fullpage.js, then it will scroll both divs instead of just one.

The solution:
Don't use slimscroll with fullpage.js, but initialize it yourself. In each `.half` you will need an inner div that contains your content `.fp-scrollable`. Initialize slimscroll by yourself like this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

We need the class `fp-scrollable`, this way your slimscroll containers will be compatible with fullpage.js.
You may need to resize the slimscroll containers on window resize.

As lazy load plugins don't usually work with fullPage.js due to the fact that fullPage.js doesn't use scrollbar unless the option `scrollBar` is set to `true`, a lazy load feature will be implemented in future versions of fullPage.js to make things even easier yet.

The new functionality has been added in fullPage.js 2.6.6
More about it [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#lazy-loading).

I found myself in the circumstance in which the slides should flow one direction and prevent backpeddling, so I modified the existing library to support a new option forceDirection which does precisely that.  It won't let you move left (if there are slides) or up, and it won't let you move down unless all horizontal slides have been viewed.  It guarantees that the user will see every slide.  You're welcome to add this feature (or not add) as you wish.

@Farkal that's not quite true. fullPage.js gives support to IE8 by automatically falling back to jQuery animations when the browser doesn't support css3.

If you read the docs you can see the following:

> **Compatibility**
> fullPage.js is fully functional on all modern browsers, as well as some old ones such as Internet Explorer 8, 9, Opera 12, etc. It works with browsers with CSS3 support and with the ones which don't have it, making it ideal for old browsers compatibility.

That's what anchors are for... there's an animation that moves it from the 1st section to the one given in the URL anchor. Unless you set `animateAnchor:false`, the animation will be visible. You can test it on the [demo page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/).

Use `fitToSection:false`

> **fitToSection:** (default true). Determines whether or not to fit sections to the viewport or not. When set to true the currente active section will always fill the whole viewport. Otherwise the user will be free to stop in the middle of a section (when )

Uhg. I might just have to add in the functionality myself then. It's like the last thing this plugin needs to be perfect.
@itsjms if you are talking about something like what was discussed [on this topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/200) it is not a trivial change at all.

- Using native scrolling on touch devices to preserve momentum scrolling
- Debouncing MouseWheelHandler when scrolling inside a section to prevent changing sections too quickly

You can see how fullPage.js is working as expected if you use the keyboard arrows to scroll horizontally.

In `onSlideLeave(anchorLink, index, slideIndex, direction)`, the value of `direction` is the scrolling direction, not the key pressed by the user.

When on the first (left-most) slide and pressing 'left', the scrolling direction becomes 'right'; when on the first slide and pressing 'right', the scrolling direction becomes 'right'. Similarly, when on the last (right-most) slide and pressing 'right', the scrolling direction becomes 'left'; when on the last slide and pressing 'left', the scrolling direction becomes 'left'.

Thus, with the information currently provided in `onSlideLeave`, there is no way of telling which key the user has pressed. The `direction` can come about because the user pressed that key or because slides are "spooling back".

I am trying to update the content displayed in a navigation bar, based on slide transitions. With the information in `onSlideLeave`, this is not possible, because it is unknown whether the user really pressed 'right'; or the user actually pressed 'left' on the first slide and, because of that, slides are spooling back to the right.

The function signature should be changed to

`onSlideLeave(anchorLink, index, slideIndex, scrollingDirection, key)`

where `scrollingDirection` is the value of the current `direction` and `key` is either `'left'` or `'right'`, depending on which key the user pressed.

What do you think? Anyone else who would need that?

Why do you need to know if the user clicked on the right or in the left arrow? Could you elaborate it?
And, why don't you use instead the `afterSlideLoad` event to determine in which section your users are?

An easy way to solve your problem is just using the `slideIndex` to determine it. Just check if its 0 or if its the same as the number of slides in that section.
Closed until an answer/explanation is provided.

Sorry for the wait. I have solved the problem using several slick sliders instead of a combination of slick and fullPage.

For an explanation of the problem, see my original posting. When using fullPage only, it is not necessary to know which key has been pressed, because fullPage will take care of showing the right slide. However, when fullPage needs to be combined with other controls, such as a slick slider, then it is necessary to know into which direction the user intends to move, i.e. which key has been pressed. FullPage does not provide that information because it will move into a single direction, independently of whether it is moving to the next slide or looping after reaching an edge.

Providing the intended direction of movement in fullPage does make sense in my opinion. Especially, when fullPage should be combined with other controls that need to change based on the direction of movement.

Still, I have found a better way of solving this, fullPage has not been the ideal candidate for what I am trying to do - I am fine with closing this issue.

Thanks!

You don't need to. fullPage.js does it automatically when using anchors as you can see on the [demo page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/).

Read the [FAQs](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/wiki/FAQ---Frequently-Answered-Questions).

> **Short answer:** use the scrollBar:true option for fullPage.js or autoScrolling:false if you don't want to use the auto-scrolling feature.
> 
> **Explanation:** Parallax, **as well as many other plugins which depends on the scrolling of the site**, listens the scrollTop property of javascript. fullPage.js doesn't actually scroll the site but it changes the top or translate3d property of the site. Only when using the fullPage.js option scrollBar:true or autoScrolling:false it will actually scroll the site in a way it is accessible for the scrollTop property.

In any case, you wouldn't need to use any external plugin for it... you can just use the callbacks fullPage.js provides or even the class fullpage.js adds to the body to play with CSS just as explained in [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qiCVPpI9l3M).
Need to disable page scrolling on mouse scrolling down or up. Section should scroll only onclick event.

Use the method `setAllowScrolling(false)`. More info in the docs.

Then use some other method like `moveSectionDown` to create the click event in your elements.

Hi alvarotrigo Just solved it there - slimscroll.js had its 'start: bottom' as default, so when user clicks load more ajax call, it dragged the user down to the bottom of the content newly loaded content. So i just rebuilt with ajaxComplete and used: $(".fp-scrollable").slimScroll({start: 'top'}) no need for fullPage.js rebuild function. :)

What exactly you want to add to the plugin? What kind of HTML5 solution are you looking for?

7Kb gzipped is not too heavy, but if you want to get rid of jQuery, you have the [pure javascript](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/tree/master/pure%20javascript%20%28Alpha%29) version of fullPage.js which drops some features.

Was thinking about leveraging VH units a bit more, and taking out as much jquery and javascript as possible (with a few exceptions that CSS3 / HTML5 can't handled).   More less a challenge to see how much of this fullpage effect can be achieved only using CSS3 / HTML5.   Because within 18 months that will be the solution i'll be leaning towards.

You can read [this topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/854) related with the use of `vh` instead of percentages or pixels.
It doesn't seem to be a good solution. Percentages should work just fine, as it is done in the pure javascript version.

Regarding the drop of javascript or jQuery, that's impossible nowadays. The plugin is already making use of CSS3 to perform animations, and that's as much as you can do with CSS nowadays.

CSS won't be able to deal with mouse / touch events or anything requiring a bit of logic. And neither HTML5. 
That's why javascript is there and that's why javascript is still being used nowadays. CSS and HTML5 are not replacements of javascript. 
Regarding animations, CSS has improved with version 3, but still not being able to deal with logic.

As I said before, you can make use of the pure javascript version of fullPage.js which gets rid of the jQuery library and its only 6Kb gzipped.
I close it until provided viable ideas for this request.

That's not a bug. 
`$.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(false, 'up, down');` works as expected as you can see here:
http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/521/

> **setAllowScrolling(boolean, [directions])**
> Adds or remove the possibility of scrolling through sections by using the mouse wheel/trackpad or touch gestures (which is active by default).

Note the text:

>  by using the mouse wheel/trackpad or touch gestures

If you want to disable the keyboard navigation, you should be using the function `setKeyboardScrolling()`.
Although this will disable it in general.

> I found that when supplying two directions to SetAllowScrolling only the second one was being applied. So I replaced the code with the following:

That's right. There's a bug there. The replace function is not working as I expected. 
I could reproduce it by using 3 parameters, in which only the 1st space is replaced:

> $.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(false, 'up, down, right');

Thanks for reporting it! 

This should solve it `directions.replace(/ /g,'')` instead of the current `directions.replace(' ', '')`.

Although this won't solve the keyboard navigation. Which as I said, its not a bug, but a matter of design.

Looks like there's an inconsistency in the Sass and CSS files, which prevents the slide dots from displaying correctly when using the Sass stylesheet.

`.fp-slidesNav ul li` in the CSS file has `margin: 7px;` set in it. This is missing in the Sass file, which makes it look like the slide dots are piled on top of each other.

Hello,

I am using this option in my own copy of fullPage.js, but I think that the sectionsColor option should be sectionsBG (or another similar option title) and use the "background" property instead of "background-color" that way that any valid background that can be applied via CSS can be used instead of just colors.

Thanks, but the option `sectionsColor` is only there to make it easier for people with few CSS knowledge to be able to create a fast fullPage.js website.
I believe any matter of design should be done by CSS preferable.

That has nothing to do with fullPage.js.
You will need to use javascript and the ajax technique to do it.

The only thing you might need to know that can be related with fullpage.js is that if you want to use `scrollOverflow`, then you would need to call the `reBuild` function after you load the content into the section, so fullPage.js can calculate the size to the new content and determine whether to use an scroll bar or not, and which size should it have.

I usually try to keep it as simple as possible for newbies and adding more files can make it a bit more confusing for this group.
I don't consider a minification of the existent CSS file will provide much benefits, so I'm not quite sure about this idea.
Also, other CDNs such as cdnjs.com get all files and compress them when needed:
https://cdnjs.com/libraries/fullpage.js, which sounds like a good alternative solution to me.

This way, jsdelivr is not providing the most important javascript plugins, such as `reveal.js`, `impress.js`...

Many (majority?) of Github repos use a `/dist` folder or the like for the minified files.
Minifying your CSS will save 2.5k, adds up.

As far as I know, backbone is similar to Angular. When dealing with this frameworks you have to be careful of how many times you initialize a plugin, as this is one of the common problems people have initializing per content loaded (per link users click).

You should be playing with the function `$.fn.fullpage.destroy('all')` and the initialization. So whenever you load a new fullpage.js page (if that's the case), you should destroy fullpage.js (if it was initialized before) and then initialize it again.
If you load a new content which doesn't require fullpage.js, then you just need to destroy fullpage.js to liberate the events used by it (mousewheel, scroll, touch...).

I don't know what are you asking for. Not clear.
Please explain it better.

You should be using the callbacks provided by the plugin (such as `onLeave` or `afterLoad`) to deal with your own menu, or if you prefer, yo can make use of the class added to the body as detailed in [this tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qiCVPpI9l3M).

When the page is partially loaded with ajax, events are binded multiple times.
There is a workaround to this by invoking jquery e.stopImmediatePropagation()
However this onlys work to keydownHandler and not scrollHandler.

Every time you render new content into the site, you destroy it with `$.fn.fullpage.destroy('all')` and you initialize it again.

Although my personal advice is DO NOT USE AJAX when using fullPage.js. It makes no sense.
Just create normal links.
This worked for me. Thank you.

It didn't bother me but it did bother my customer instead :-)
This helps with future maintenance of the library as changing a classname or selector will only require a change in one place instead of many.

I can see it useful mainly in terms of compression, but the reason of making it easier to change doesn't convince me. It is almost as easy as using a "find an replace" and I don't see this variables as something that will be changed with frequency. 

In any case, I would use real constants instead of objects, this way you could save more then 2KB (10%) in the minification and the syntax will be shorter and more easy to read. 
I'm not either sure either of how to deal with the classNames variables. Having them by duplicate doesn't seem very reasonable. 
A function could be used for it, but it would make the code more difficult to read and to be written.

I think extracting these as constants is much more than just for compression (though that alone is a very valid argument imo). Not having "magic" strings all over the code helps with maintainability, refactoring, lessens the risk of typos/regressions, and could help contributers (and with taking contributions) as all the DOM selectors are now easily glance-able.

Though do agree that using raw vars (consts) would help the minification much more.

@eamodio yeah. I agree with you. Although I believe some of those strings shouldn't be constants, such as:
- body 
-  #fp-nav li
-  #fp-nav li a
- .fp-tableCell, .fp-slidesContainer
- #fp-nav, .fp-slidesNav, .fp-controlArrow
- .fp-controlArrow.fp-next
- .fp-controlArrow.fp-prev

Having combinations of selectors which are only used in specific cases, such as the `controls` one (`'#fp-nav, .fp-slidesNav, .fp-controlArrow`) doesn't seem to be very useful for me when they can done by combining those constants. 
I see it useful though for other cases such as `activeSlide` or `activeSection` which are widely used.

Then, not quite sure about the other combinations such as `sectionNavLinks:    '#fp-nav a',`...

@alvarotrigo Definitely agree with combining the constants rather than having combined constants, unless the combination really defines something that should be uniquely addressable (and used repeatedly).

@alvarotrigo @eamodio - agree with individual constant variables and also separating combo selectors where used sparingly.

For selectors like 'body' and 'html, body', I think those should just be declared once and as jQuery objects since those shouldn't need to be re-looked up in the DOM.

> For selectors like 'body' and 'html, body', I think those should just be declared once and as jQuery objects since those shouldn't need to be re-looked up in the DOM.

Ok. Fine then.

Should we just name the constants with upper cases without any prefix suffix to make them shorter and easier to read while coding?

For example: `$(ACTIVE_SLIDE)`

What about the class names? Should we just use a function for it?

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

What do you think about it?
It wouldn't look as clear in the code, but can't think about anything else.

Using CAPS for the constants sounds good. But I would argue against using a function for conversion from selector to class or vice versa. My main argument would be around performance and the amount of strings that would get allocated and destroyed, which would put more pressure on the garbage collector. Causing more collections could cause more pauses in the experience.

I would suggest to just use un-prefixed CAPS variables for classes and prefixed (or post-fixed) CAPS variables for selectors that are the combination of the class variables.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

or

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I believe that would play well for readability, minification, and performance.

Thoughts?

Yeah, sounds reasonable. 
I would prefer to use a single word for selectors, as they are used more in the code, but I think that adding the SEL prefix or postfix will be better in terms of readability. So I agree with you.

I though it would compress the strings, but it seems it doesn't :D 
At least, not Closure compiler. (YUI seems to do it)

Check out this example: http://jsfiddle.net/4d1jd1rk/

YUI compressor: 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Closure compiler:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
I use UglifyJS2 (https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2) for compression and it seems to do it.

Interesting:

From the [FAQs](https://github.com/google/closure-compiler/wiki/FAQ#closure-compiler-inlined-all-my-strings-which-made-my-code-size-bigger-why-did-it-do-that):

> Closure Compiler assumes that you are using gzip compression. If you do not, you should. Configuring your server to gzip your code is one of the most effective and easiest optimizations that you can possibly do. The gzip algorithm works by trying to alias sequences of bytes in an optimal way. Aliasing strings manually almost always makes the compressed code size bigger, because it subverts gzip's own algorithm for aliasing. So Closure Compiler will (almost) always inline your strings when it can, because that will make your compressed code smaller.

Use the option `scrollOverflow:true` as [in this example.](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html)

From the docs:

> **scrollOverflow:** (default false) defines whether or not to create a scroll for the section in case its content is bigger than the height of it. When set to true, your content will be wrapped by the plugin. Consider using delegation or load your other scripts in the afterRender callback. In case of setting it to true, it requires the vendor plugin jquery.slimscroll.min and it should be loaded before the fullPage.js plugin. For example:

Demo online for your example:
http://jsfiddle.net/4yqd8rs9/11/

Do not forget to include `vendors/slimscroll.min.js` and to use fullPage.js onDomReady and not onLoad.

The plugin only provides a way to activate sections in a menu, not slides, as it is detailed in the docs.

To activate slides in your menu you would need to work with the callbacks provided by the plugin such as `afterSlideLoad` or use the added class in the `body` element to work with CSS instead.

I looked further into the issue here and found out, that I'm not batshit crazy :) and that the firefox touch simulator doesn't represent the firefox-reality at all!

Here is what I found: per default-config in windows, firefox doesn't fire touch-events. I tested with that: http://mobilehtml5.org/ts/?id=11

When I use 2 fingers with default-config firefox, I seems to emulate a normal touchpad! two fingers = mousewheel.

Touch events where deactivated by mozilla because of bugginess (text selection instead touch-events). You have to activate touch events in the about:config section but even then they are buggy and swiping won't work, which seems to be a firefox problem - not yours.

But this also means, that windows firefox users with touch devices have no touch-functionality with your script.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25024197/how-to-make-sure-touch-events-are-enabled-in-firefox-desk-top-browser

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Events/Touch_events

Best regards

Hi,

I have an animation on my Nav that is fired when the page loads on the home (afterrender). I have another animation on the Nav that is fired when you change to other sections. The problem is that when you load the website on another section than the Nav, the "afterload" animation is fired and then the "afterrender" animation is fired.

You shouldn't be using `afterRender` presupposing that the user will always load the 1st section.
That's not its purpose.

You should keep using `afterLoad` to fire your animation on the home page. Just use the `anchorLink` or the `index` parameters to filter your actions, or even the section object itself (`$(this)`).

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

You should be applying `scrollOverflow`, not `normalScrollElements`.

> **scrollOverflow:** (default false) defines whether or not to create a scroll for the section in case its content is bigger than the height of it. When set to true, your content will be wrapped by the plugin. Consider using delegation or load your other scripts in the afterRender callback. In case of setting it to true, it requires the vendor plugin jquery.slimscroll.min and it should be loaded before the fullPage.js plugin.

Hello every one,

 I am trying to disable the auto scrolling on tablets and phones but it seems it doesn't work. I want my site to behave as a normal site on both mobiles and tablets.  Any solution would be greatly appreciated.
you could try to use modernizr, ask for touch and rebuild fullpage. you could also use the search, I think there were already similar questions.

@kokoda, the question is: what's a mobile phone or a table for you? Would a PC with touch screen be one of those? Will a tablet with mouse be one of those? A device with slow resolution? What about retina displays in iPads?

There's no way to define what a tablet or a phone is. So you'd better clear your mind about why you want to have a non autoscrolling site for "mobile phones and tablets". 
If its a matter of resolution, then use it as a way to differentiate both and based on that, use one or another initialization. 

The plugin can't just know what you mean with "tablet or phone". It provides the option `responsive` to turn on the normal scrolling based on the `width`. So you can start with that if its a matter of resolution.

You can also try to detect a "mobile browser", it is not quite recommended and you'll probably have to check it every year as new devices are added and it changes constantly, but you can try [the solution proposed here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11381673/detecting-a-mobile-browser).

Although Android tablets, iPads, Kindle Fires and PlayBooks are not detected as mobile browsers by design.

Your problem has nothing to do with fullPage.js but with CSS knowledge.
That's because you are using `position:fixed` instead of `positio:absolute`.

You would need to add `position:relative` for `.section` in that case.

That's because as detailed [in the FAQ](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/wiki/FAQ---Frequently-Answered-Questions#my-other-plugins-dont-work-when-using-fullpagejs):

> if you are using options such as verticalCentered:true or overflowScroll:true of fullPage.js, your content will be wrapped inside other elements changing its position in the DOM structure of the site. This way, your content would be consider as "dynamically added content" and most plugins need the content to be originally on the site to perform their tasks. Using the afterRender callback to initialize your plugins, fullPage.js makes sure to initialize them only when fullPage.js has stopped changing the DOM structure of the site.

It's [a bug in Firefox](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=819763#c0) when dealing with css3 transformations and SWF.

You can see similar topics [in other places](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13882629/firefox-bug-with-translate3d-on-a-flash-element).

You can solve it using `css3:false` for fullPage.js.

Your fullPage.js code has been modified. I'm sorry but I don't provide support to any kind of modifications. 
Try with the original fullPage.js code, if you keep having the same problem come back again.
When auto-scroll is off in fullpage, the browser history can get very overloaded depending on how much scrolling is done up and down the page, making the back button a mess for users.

You are totally right. Thanks for naming it.
More than optional, I guess we could keep using them but preventing them to be added in the history.

A new option has been added for it. `recordHistory` as detailed [in the docs](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js)

> **recordHistory:** (default true) Defines whether to push the state of the site to the browser's history. When set to true each section/slide of the site will act as a new page and the back and forward buttons of the browser will scroll the sections/slides to reach the previous or next state of the site. When set to false, the URL will keep changing but will have no effect ont he browser's history. This option is automatically turned off when using autoScrolling:false.

A new method has also been provided [`$.fn.fullpage.setRecordHistory()`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#setrecordhistoryboolean).

Rebuild is not the opposite to destroy.

I am having one interesting behavior where some of the slides have content which is positioned at or near the bottom of the pages. So, on smaller screens where the content can't be shown all at once, when the user scrolls down to see the content, he or she might _overscroll_ (via mouse or touch pad) and instead of just scrolling to see the content trigger the new page slide in as well, so the user can't read the content and has to go back.

One solution might be too change the content structure and add some padding or empty space below the actual content, but that seems like crude solution. 

Is there a way to solve this so in the initial scroll, when the user is actually scrolling the page which has height larger than the screen/window height, doesn't trigger the scroll event?

Thanks

Already treated [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/294) and [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/286).

Sorry for opening the already discussed issue. I did try to find similar issues but was overwhelmed with questions and didn't try that exact wording while searching.

Do you think its possible to solve this in this way:
- detect is the height of the page larger than the current height of the window
- if so, temporarily disable the plugin
- after scrolling, check is the end of the page reached
- **if the end of the page is reached**, use a funciton like [this](http://documentcloud.github.io/underscore/#debounce), which would enable the plugin again
- when the scroll is activated, the plugin would activate

The function I linked, `_.debounce()` has an interesting behavior that is applicable in this case. It would be triggered **only** after some time has passed after the scroll event has stopped, lets say some arbitrary three digit number of milliseconds, `300`. 

So, if a user gets to the page that is larger in height than the window height, the plugin would be disabled. While the user scrolls, nothing would happen, **unless** the end of the page is reached. After the end/bottom of the page is reached, **and** the scroll event has been stopped for some period of time, that would re-enable the plugin and in the next scroll event, the expected behavior for the user would be to go to the next slide. In case of continuous scroll from the top to the bottom of the active page, the plugin wouldn't activate and used would have to "pause" for a moment.

There would be no additional dependencies as the function doesn't use anything specific to underscore.js (more [here](http://davidwalsh.name/function-debounce)).

The problem comes when dealing with Apple trackpads / trackpads in general and Apple Magic mouse.
There scroll behaviour keeps firing even after 1 second depending on the acceleration of the scrolling. 

I guess the way to go would be to force the user to reach the bottom, and then, after another scroll from the user, scroll the section. But the problem here is how we define the "2nd scrolling". As the scrolling event can be firing for 1 second after the user stops scrolling...
I actually added a debounce function into my local version a few weeks ago and am using it only on the MouseWheelHandler with a 50ms wait. It seems to handle the problem well.

@Canubiz I think that might cause problems in devices with kinetic scrolling such as Apple track-pads. They might have difficulties scrolling down because of the scrolling inertia and they will have to stop scrolling for more than 750 milliseconds.

@alvarotrigo Thanks for your feedback. I developed this modification on a MacBook Air esp. testing its trackpad control and it seems to work exactly the way I'd expect to. I believe it's exactly the way scrolling on a fullpage website, including more content on a single section than it can fit, should behave: not scroll over that content at the bottom of a section, but stop there and require another, separate scroll attempt (detected but a short amount of time without any scroll events recognized) to move on to the next section.
The value of 750ms is for sure something open for debate and fine tuning. I also tried with much lower values like 250ms and it still works very well, maybe even betterâ€¦? So maybe, with a lower value we can still reach the purpose to stop over-scrolling scrollable section content but still serve visitors well who want to quickly jump to the next section.
Note: this modification does not influence scrolling behavior of sections without scrollable content inside them. So in conclusion, if one does not have scrollable sections, this should change nothing in user experience. On the other hand, if one uses scrollable sections, user experience dramatically improves, at least from my point of view, as users cannot easily over scroll any content they wanted to go to and read.
I will do some more testing with the separate Apple Magic Trackpad and the Magic Mouse as well as trackpads on some other Mac models from friends and family and will come back with results, if you're interested. :)

> on iOS-Devices the script is not offering scroll-bars if the content ist to large to show in the section

It does when using `scrollOverflow:true`.

It sounds like you are loading some content dynamically in the sections after the plugin has been initialised. 

Try setting the height of the video on the html markup so the plugin can known in advance its size before it loads.

You can also try to initialise the plugin on load instead of on document ready or you can use the function `reBuild` provided by fullPage.js after all the content has loaded or even by using a timeOut.

> i set the script in the header "verticalCentered: false" and "resize : false" to avoid the the forefox-bug with resizing and used media queries instead (issue #284).

As I said in the related issue:

> The bug has been fixed in their last version 1.3.2 which I will commit now as well.

So that's solved.

I am trying to linkout from my fullpage.js page /welcome to another page where I do not want to use fullpage.js welcome/privacyPolicy and when I do so I get an error:

The result of this error is that the page breaks and I cannot scroll down. It seems that fullpage.js is trying to find var element = $('.fp-section.active');, but nothing is found. I have not initialized the plugin on my privacy policy page because I do not intend to use it there. Any thoughts?

I would need more information about it. Can you add a link to your site or reproduce it somewhere else?

I would say you are using some event for that link element.

That's because you are using AJAX to load the new content... you would need to destroy the plugin using the function `destroy('all')` provided by fullpage.js and initialize it again when going back to the previous landing page.

More about destroy: 
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#destroytype

My personal advice is: AVOID using ajax just for a normal link... makes things easier.
Okay great thanks for the advice. This may be a basic question, but how exactly am I using ajax? I assumed I was just using a standard 'a' link with an href to my page in the footer.

Nop, your site is not loading the whole page, just updating the body of it. That's a question you should better ask in other place. Probably the framework you are using is doing AJAX automatically for you.

As I said: My personal advice is: AVOID using ajax just for a normal link... makes things easier.

You can look for other people asking similar things:
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues?q=RAILs
Great thanks for pointing me in the right direction. I appreciate all of the help!

Just for anyone else dealing with this same issue in rails: 

The best solution as mentioned above is to disable the way rails handles default linking using ajax through turbolinks. You can add the data-no-turbolink tag to a containing html element to disable turbolinks for all inner elements. 

More info here: https://github.com/rails/turbolinks

Being relatively new to jQuery/JS and slowly working out CSS too, I'm a bit confused as to how to add animations and transitions. I've been trying to work it out from the example, but I'm not getting it right somewhere.

a) nop.

Hi !
I'm using your nice plugin for my portfolio but there is a conflict when i load other sliders.

For example, this is a jsfiddle with your plugin only
http://jsfiddle.net/zuzd85fc/3/

It works, but when you add "Slick.js" you can't go to the second slide
http://jsfiddle.net/zuzd85fc/4/

Same issue with "Owl Carousel".
( https://github.com/kenwheeler/slick/ or http://www.owlcarousel.owlgraphic.com/ )

Can you help me to fix this ?

It seems the problem is with Slick.js and not with fullPage.js. 
If you use `display:none`, for Slic.js container you won't have the problem. It is using a fixed `width` in pixels.

In any case, remember you should initialize them in the `afterRender` callback of fullpage.js as said in the docs:

> **afterRender**
> This callback is fired just after the structure of the page is generated. This is the callback you want to use to initialize other plugins or fire any code which requires the document to be ready (as this plugin modifies the DOM to create the resulting structure).

`responsive` can not be `true` or `false`, it has to be a value in pixels as explained in the docs:

> **responsive:** (default 0) A normal scroll (autoScrolling:false) will be used under the defined width in pixels. A class fp-responsive is added to the plugin's container in case the user wants to use it for his own responsive CSS. For example, if set to 900, whenver the browser's width is less than 900 the plugin will scroll like a normal site.

Also, none of them has anything to do with your backgrounds.

If you scroll down just before the first section finishes loading then the screen scrolls past the second second and displays a blank section (This may take a few tries to time it just right).  Examining the css shows that the top position for the containing div is incorrectly set to 1995 instead of 995.

I don't know if it's possible to detect or calculate the max top position based on the height and number of sections on the page to make sure this cannot happen.  I'm happy to help in any way I can and interested in hearing from you regarding a solution.

There's nothing wrong with fullPage.js there. It is the way you are using it what is causing troubles. Your animations are too slow and the user scrolls to the 2nd section before they even start.

You could use `setAllowScrolling(false)` on the `afterRender` callback to prevent the scrolling when loading and set it to `true` after 1 second or so, so the users have time to see the animations of the first section. You can do that with `setTimeout`.

CSS3 gives us viewport-relative units. 100vw means 100% of the viewport width. 100vh; 100% of the height. Very handy when doing full screen slidesâ€¦ It also has good support: http://caniuse.com/#feat=viewport-units

Not supported by IE 8. 
In any case, what's the problem of using percentages? Could you illustrate it somehow? 

Other potential problem i see is in case in the future fullPage.js supports being initialised inside an element instead of working in all the page.

100vw will always calculate out to 100% of the viewport width. If you use percentages, and you don't have 100% down from the root, you can't be assured of 100% calculating to 100% of the viewport. (And that's the whole purpose of the vw/vh units: 1vw == 1% of the viewport width) 

If fullPage.js is initialized inside an element instead of working on all the page, then fullPage is a misnomer. Also, YAGNI. fullPage is designed to be full-page todayâ€¦ and vw/vh helps accomplish that without javascript.

(Also, IE8 represents about 3% of the global browser population â€“ according to caniuse.com. Globally, vw/vh has ~80% support globally)

I get your point and I think it would also be something beneficial for a future, but right now, this plugin will still giving support for IE 8.

IE 8 seems to be more used than IE 9 and IE 10, as also [pointed out here](http://thenextweb.com/insider/2014/05/01/ie11-market-share-passes-ie10-ie9-combined-chrome-cements-lead-firefox/) and just half than IE 11 or even more depending on the studies.

Some studies show 10% usage worldwide, which is not something to ignore.

Until support for IE 8 is dropped, I guess we could use just CSS fallback to `height:100%` when `vh` is not supported, as done in many other CSS styles.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I though there were going to be problems with the vertical centering inside the `table-cell` element if used percentages, but couldn't find any problem now when trying it again in IE 8 and Opera 12.
Please never implement vw/vh related behaviour.
@tezro could you elaborate that?
Sure. IE8 is still more popular than IE9. Also vw/vh is extremely inconsistent from browser to browser.

Yeah, but IE8 only represents [~4% of global usage](http://beta.caniuse.com/#search=vh) (about the same as "UC Browser for Android 9.9"â€¦) and IE9/10/11 together represent ~12%. 

Please source "vw/vh is extremely inconsistent from browser to browser." Again, using caniuse.com as a source, there's few known issues specific to vw/vh (a notable exception being Safari on iOS 7.1 when you leave the page and come back more than 60 seconds later).

What we do at work is install top 5 versions of all browsers, each in separate VM. Run minimal tests for needed CSS or JS features. Compare screenshots and values pixel by pixel. You don't really need to source anything when you do web dev every day and know the issues. vw/vh and of course vmax is inconsistent depending on the browser and the OS.

And yeah 4% of IE8 means 1 out of 25 people uses it, again according to StatCounter, which you have to sign up to have your website stats used there. In real world the numbers are very different.
Closed as it doesn't seem to be a good solution.

You're talking about a solution for what fullPage should utilize by default. I'm not ( #1515 ).

Here's the gist. Make it up to the developer and use pixels as default value â€“ but don't disallow vh/vw. Why? Because using 100vh for example would mean less lookup for jQuery in terms of finding out window.height() on init AND on resize. This is no longer needed. 100vh is 100vh. Ultimately this means better performance and cleaner code (nothing needs to be inline styled except the container).

I'd go with better performance over IE8 support any day. Even IE9. That's me. And it should be up to the dev and project, no? As well as custom classes for container (fullpage-wrapper) and sections (fp-section) and vertically centered sections (fp-table). More options for the developer. 

Why would this be bad?

EDIT: or show an example of how we could simply overwrite or extend $.fn.fullpage to use vh/vw and allow to set the variables holding class names and such.

> I'd go with better performance over IE8 support any day. Even IE9

Sorry but I prefer to keep providing support for them. I haven't researched much about `vh` and `vm` but it seems it is not very consistent as @tezro  said:

> vw/vh and of course vmax is inconsistent depending on the browser and the OS.

Using pixels instead won't create any real performance problem in your site. The difference will be negligible... They are only recalculated on window resize every 350 milliseconds, which is not a bad delay. 
Using other measures can lead to problems with other options such as `scrollOverflow`. 

If you are so worry about performance, you'd better use [the pure javascript fullpage.js version](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/tree/master/pure%20javascript%20%28Alpha%29). It is still under development, as I have no much time for it, but be sure it will be much faster than the jQuery version. (plus it is not using pixels as it doesn't work with `scrollOverflow`).

I'm asking for options, not for you to change the default from pixels to vh. There's a difference!

If not, then how can I extend/replace functionality without having to fork/modify yours? Basically I'd just want to access the variables you've registered to hold the element classes as well as rewriting scrollPage function etc. Can I redefine them somehow? Like extending/overwriting.

The point being, give the tools for the developer to develop using your plugin. Don't limit the developer, give them options to decide how they'd want to use the functionality you've written?

Personally I'd want to use vh for this project. I'd also want to not have jQuery do so much inline to the DOM but use classes instead. The only thing needed to be inline would be on the container, switching sections using translate3d but with 'vh' instead of 'px', so I'd make a variable for the unit.

> The point being, give the tools for the developer to develop using your plugin. Don't limit the developer, give them options to decide how they'd want to use the functionality you've written?

Yep, that'd be nice. I'll keep it in mind as a possible enhancement for the future.
I don't have time for it now and I still have other high priority issues or bugs to solve for the next release. 

Feel free to commit a pull request if you think you can add the option into the plugin.

For example, you removed the jQuery fadeIn from the navigation tooltips and you changed it for a CSS3 transition. But you didn't take into account that this plugin provides compatibility with IE 8 and [transitions are not working there](http://caniuse.com/#search=transition)...

@alvarotrigo I know that it wasn't the best way to make 'so much' changes at one time and I know that you try to make this as much IE8 compatible as possible but [W3C recommends using HTML5](http://www.w3.org/blog/news/archives/4167) and IE8 is simply not fully compatible with HTML5 at all... 

What I mean with that is that IMHO the focus should always be to get the best performance and also usability (for visitors and developers) for modern browsers and only make a website generally working on older browsers like IE8. When someone uses browsers like that he is self responsible that he doesn't get some nice transitions for the tooltips. I believe the most people notice the (0.2s) transition at all.

The problems that I see behind the current tooltip implementation are:
    - The tooltips are created on the 'mouseenter' and removed on the 'mouseleave' event of the menu item which is in terms of performance not that efficient and makes them impossible to debug with a developer console  
    - The content of the tooltips has to be stored in the data of the corresponding menu item
    - The showing/hiding depends on jQuery

All this points are improved in my pull request and you just close it...
Even if IE8 support is a must-have, it would be possible with some quite simple fallback code.

I agree with you, tooltip implementation can be improved. But I would encourage you to submit each of the different improvements in a different pull request so I can see all the changes at once and we can discuss each of them separately.

About IE 8, its fine if there's no transition for them, but right now your code still need something else to hide the tooltips in IE 8 because they are all visible by default.

Also, I wouldn't try to change unnecessary things, such as the change of 0.2 seconds to 0.5. As I still preferring 0.2 seconds. Also the margin of the tooltips to the right, left, top or bottom, which looks ok now and it doesn't seem to provide any kind of improvement.

> W3C recommends using HTML5 and IE8 is simply not fully compatible with HTML5 at all...

W3C says many things... but not all of them make sense in the real world. Old browser compatibility still being strongly demanded in companies all around the world. 

It would be easier for all to use only HTML5 and CSS3, but live is never easy :)

I know that browser compatibility is important, but missing little transitions aren't that important to me to make them IE8 compatible.

Improved navigation css selectors: https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/829

If you fix the problem in IE 8 for the navigation, I'll merge it as well.
I agree now its difficult to debug and therefore to play a bit with the style as well.

Also it will remove code from the .js file making it a bit smaller, which is always good.

Do you pay much attention on the little (fade-in) transition of the tooltips on browsers that doesn't support CCS3 transitions or is it OK when the just appear there correctly when hovering over the navigation dots?
Its fine if there's no transition for them.

Here you go => https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/833
I tested it with latest Chrome, Firefox, Opera and IE 8-11

Hello,

I am afraid fullPage.js is not handling well scrolling inside iframes, and therefore misleading the user scrolling intention too, not leading to another slide when the user reaches the bottom of an iframe that totally fills a page.

You can check this issue here: http://jsfiddle.net/u6dfar7j/1/

If you scroll down to the second page, you will see that you have an iframe. Once you reach the end of the iframe, fullPage.js next slide is not called.

Any suggestions?

Thanks!

Fullpage.js doesn't deal with those cases. You would have to do it by your own.
You probably want to detect with jQuery when a user reaches the top or the bottom of your iFrame and then use the functions `moveSectionUp` or `moveSectionDown` that fullPage.js provides.

In order to detect the reach of the bottom or top of your iframe, you would need to have some knowledged of jQuery or javascript. 

If you don't, then you should ask in other places such as stackoverflow.com where they will help you much better with it.

This forum is just to treat topics about fullPage.js not about HTML,CSS, javascript or jQuery.

If you want you scroll to the 1st slide every time you scroll to the 1st section, then you should do it using the methods the plugin provides, such as `moveTo` or `moveSlideLeft` combined with the callback `afterLoad`.

I don't understand what you are asking for. Once you leave the site? 

If you were in a slider and you leave your site to another one, when you come back you will still being in the same slider **after fullPage.js scrolls to it.**

If you want to disable the scrolling and sliding process of fullPage.js to reach that slide, the answer is no. It's not possible to avoid the sliding effect inside the section. You could avoid the vertical scrolling effect by using `animateAnchor:false` as detailed in the docs:

> **animateAnchor:** (default true) Defines whether the load of the site when given an anchor (#) will scroll with animation to its destination or will directly load on the given **section**.

There's [another opened topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/236) to treat the `animateAnchor` for slides, which is not yet implemented.
If you really need it for slides, remember I offer myself to customize the plugin as detailed in the docs:

> Customizations of the plugin available upon request for some reasonable price. [Contact me.](http://alvarotrigo.com/#contact-page)

Not leave site, leave slider when I click an anchor tag to go to different section.

If I am on slider and navigate to the second slide, I decide to click an anchor that goes to a different section. Then if I click another anchor that goes back to the slider section, the slider goes back to the 1st slide.
I want to turn off the slider that resets back to the first slide.

I might think about changing it for a future version of fullPage.js. 

Then, when accessing the first slide of the section, instead of using a single anchor like now `#secondSection`, the plugin would need to use two, like this `#secondSection/slide1` so when you want to go back to the active slide, you can do it with a link like this `#secondSection`.
Not going to work with sliders. When you have a generic anchor tag, you want to go back to the slider slide where you left off, not anchor to a specific slide.

Yeah, I would say that's an improvement from the UX point of view for people who is not used to deal with navigation bullets (who I suppose are not very used to navigate on internet...).

I'm planning to add a new feature for the next version of fullPage.js which might solve this kind of problems for users.

The idea is to show the scroll bar all the time, so the users can have the same concept of navigation as in any other site, and noticing there's more content to see.
This will still acting with `autoScroll` so the user will be able to scroll with the mouse wheel and the site will automatically scroll up or down.

Whenever a user drags the scrolling bar, it will scroll like it does in a normal site, and on mouse up, it will automatically fit the screen to the closest section if it was not already taking all the screen size.

Hi!

We're using fullPage.js on our home page and we're embedding a full-screen Vimeo embed into one of the slides.

Everything works as a charm in Chrome, but in Firefox and iOS it is impossible to scroll over the Vimeo iframe. fullPage just won't react to it.

I tried covering the video with a transparent div. Again, it works in Chrome, but on iOS the browser would not allow you start the video programmatically, so covering the video with a div makes it unable to start the video.

Is there a solution for this issue?

Here's a demo of the problem: http://jsbin.com/tunove/1/edit?html,output The video is on the second slide and scrolling/swiping over it won't switch slides in Firefox and iOS.

It seems like a problem in Firefox with the `mousewheel` event as you can see [here](https://github.com/noraesae/perfect-scrollbar/issues/98).

A workaround, kind of like a hack, would be to cover all the video except the center (because of the play button) with an invisible layer.
Or cover it all and autoplay the video.

[Here's](http://jsfiddle.net/97tbk/353/) a demo.

Hey  @alvarotrigo, thank you for replying.

---

> It seems like a problem in Firefox with the mousewheel event as you can see here.

The suggested solution won't work because the iframe is cross-origin. Here's what Chrome says:

> Blocked a frame with origin "http://localhost:3000" from accessing a frame with origin "http://player.vimeo.com". Protocols, domains, and ports must match.

---

> A workaround, kind of like a hack, would be to cover all the video except the center (because of the play button) with an invisible layer.

I've already implemented the hole-in-the-center workaround, but it's hacky as hell. :(

---

> Or cover it all and autoplay the video.

It is impossible to autoplay videos on mobile:

> Uncaught Error: The viewer must initiate playback first. 

---

Please reopen.

> Please reopen.

I wouldn't consider this a problem or a bug in fullPage.js. 
This is a problem of the propagation of the mousewheel or the touch ones in Firefox when using iFrames. 

I would suggest you to try to find a solution in other place such as http://stackoverflow.com/.

It is quite unlikely we will find the proper solution for it here. It's a problem originated in Firefox, not in fullpage.js.
The same problem exists on all iOS devices and i believe it's a big deal.

I still recommending you to use other place to figure out the solution for it. You will find much better answers in places like stackoverflow. 

Once a good solution is provided (if any), you can come back to comment it and then we could try to see if it is possible at all to implement it in fullPage.js.

Disclaimer first: I don't know jquery but I'm logical and clever, so I was able to use some examples I found here and elsewhere to use AfterSlideLoad to highlight some fixed nav links for slides. It works beautifully but there is one thing wrong. 

The site I'm designing has 4 sections, and two of them (second and third) contain slides. Let's say I move vertically down from section 0 to section 1, and then move horizontally between three slides in section 1. Nav links light up fine. Then I move down to section 2. Then I move back up to the slide in section 1 that I just left. The nav link does not light up. But if I then move horizontally again, the callbacks fire and the links light up.

Is this a limitation in the code I've created? Or a limitation in fullPage? Thanks in advance for any info...

It sounds like you are using the same fixed navigation for both sections. 

The `afterSlideLoad` callback is only fired after the slider finish the animation to reach the slide.

When you scroll from one section to another one, the slide is already in the viewport and therefore the `afterSlideLoad` callback won't fire. Only the `afterLoad` callback.

You could use the `afterLoad`, then see which slide is active at that moment with something like:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Or in one line:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Then you would only need to add the styles you want again depending on it.

Ok, I detected the problem. It is happening because the address bar in the top changes its size when scrolling up or down and the resize event is fired, causing the plugin to try to readjust and fit the sections in the screen. (as you can see [in the demo page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html) by resizing the window)

It seems iOS 8 was not acting in the same way, it was probably not firing the resize event.

I'll try to think about how to deal with it...
Meanwhile I would suggest you to destroy the plugin with `destroy()` instead of calling `setAutoScrolling(false)`

I've stumbled upon the same issue just today and have fixed it by disabling the vertical resize event for mobile devices.

Here's the part I tweaked:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

What I do here is check if the width changed on resize and if it didn't then it means a vertical resize happened (the address bar height changed). 1024px width is the limit of my choice to let desktops have the default behaviour.

This is a quick fix and probably needs looking into/refining.

I'm not quite sure if that would work in other device mobile OS such as Android, Windows Phone... 
Some of these phones have they `width` and `height` inverted as far as I know.

That'd would need a bit more of testing.

Tested in Android browser on HTC One X and a Samsung tablet, Safari on iPad and iPhone 4.

I guess this Stack question is relevant here:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6850164/get-the-device-width-in-javascript

@malydok right. It seems the values get updated after the `resize` event but not always after the `orientationchange`. That was my previous problem.

In any case, I see you are doing some funny things in there, such as using the value of 1024:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I think the solution is more simple. Just prevent calling the `reBuild` method when resizing if the `autoScrollilng` is turned off and its not changing orientation.

@alvarotrigo That seems to be the case - viewport meta on my website matches the one you quoted. 

On the other hand `initial-scale` causes a "zoom bug" on iOS < 6 (fix: https://github.com/sergiolopes/ios-zoom-bug-fix) but I think it can be neglected at this point as it's an old issue.
I would like to find a solution which doesn't require to modify the HTML markup with any meta tag, as many people will not include it.

This viewport meta is the most common one on responsive websites and in frameworks (h5bp, foundation, bootstrap, etc.) so most people already have it even if they don't really pay attention to it. I understand your concerns though and will try to help you look for a solution in my spare time.

I've noticed the `height` value does change. Not sure if this will work in the same way for Android or other OS, but this could be an easy solution .
If the change of it is not too big, then we can assume the browser is hiding the address bar or similar, otherwise, if it is big enough, the device was rotated. 

It doesn't sound like the perfect solution, as this might change in a future for other OS or an update of the browser and it sounds a bit weird only the `height` value is updated, but is something that would solve the problem temporary.

That's actually what I did, although differently - by checking the width of the viewport. If the width didn't change on resize then obviously height did. Checking the size of resize is something I didn't include because it requires coming up with a magic number for the "not too big" part and it needs some testing.

And still you have to detect the viewport height somehow. Does it work without `initial-scale: 1` on orientation change? I presume it's the exact same problem we discussed earlier.

> That's actually what I did, although differently - by checking the width of the viewport.

The thing is that the `height` changes even when not including the meta tag, which doesn't happen with the `width`.  (at least on iPhone OS)
About the _not to big_, percentages could be used.
Alrighty! Sounds good then.

For my project I added these css rules to make the dots usable.

I get your point.
But the dots have two purposes: 1. they indicate which slide the user is currently looking at and how many there are 2. they can be used to navigate.
I personally think that a site using full page slides without dots is not intuitive, that the dots are too small and that they look good at 16x16px even on desktop.

I respect your choice, I just wanted you to think about it.

You are right, they are recommended from the UX point of view, but on the other hand, designers should in most cases make use of css3 media queries to deal with this kind of problems adapting elements to different resolutions.

This shouldn't be an exception.

You probably want to adapt other elements as well, such as text, images...

Hi there.

The new responsive feature unfortunately only works on window resize.
If the page is loaded and the browser window is below the set width (which probably happens everytime on mobile devices - I only tested it on a Desktop), autoScrolling will not be disabled and the .fp-responsive css class will not be added.
This happens because $(window).resize (line 1141 in https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/2e085dad1b09941592ffa09ae1d1f98eb9e25656/jquery.fullPage.js)  is not called on page load, but only on window resize. Apprently it does in some browsers, but it is not expected to happen.
Tested on Firefox 32.0.3.

Also please think about if it makes sense to show the navigation dots when autoScrolling is disabled.

Thanks for reporting it, I'll take a look at it in a a couple of hours.

> Also please think about if it makes sense to show the navigation dots when autoScrolling is disabled.

They are disabled by default and its totally configurable. If you have navigation dots when autoScrolling is set to `false`, then is because **you set it like so**.

Thanks for your rapid answer.
I do not have time for a pull request, but I guess the fix is as trivial as just calling the resizeHandler somewhere in fullPage initialization.

I probably didn't express myself right.

I'm biased by another plugin I used which handled things that way.
On the other hand, I guess a developer using fullPage.js could also just add a css rule to hide the dots when .fp-responsive is present.
