Is there an easy way to fade the sections that by default slide horizontally? Just wondering before I go digging!

Nop.
This is an scrolling plugin, not a fading one :)

I would recommend you to make use a external fading slide plugins inside a section to achieve that effect.

This is now possible with the [Fading Effect Extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/fadingEffect.html).
Assured compatibility with future releases of fullpage.js.

Hi there - Again, love the plugin. Do you have any code or suggestions on the best way to preload slide images? I'm using the plugin with full page bg images and if the client loads several large images it really slows down the site. It would be great to preload the images somehow... I was using `afterRender` and `afterRender` to load the next/previous slide image but when the user clicked on the slide navigation that was several down from their current slide it would look terrible sliding to it without the images in between loaded. Any helpful tips or advice is appreciated!

I did some digging and notice you keep recommending https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/46#issuecomment-26509996 as the preloading answer. The issue with this is that if you are using fullscreen images and the side navigation, such as in your example: http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/backgrounds.html and then click from slide 1 to slide 4 the slides in between won't have their images loaded properly and when it slides past them the background displays. This leads to a pretty bad UX. Scratching my head to how load times can be reduced when using large bgs like this...

This plugin won't offer a magic solution for it. You will find the exact same problem in any site using  anchors and huge images. The problem you are talking about here is not fullPage.js exclusive. Its a general problem.

A proper design should use light images and serve them in the proper size (usually done using CSS3 media queries).

If you want to load the images of all the sections then you will have to do it afterRender, there's no more to think about there. 

Another solution would be to use a loading screen as some sites do. This can be easily be done using an external plugin for it if you don't want to do it by yourself.
Hmm, ok. I guess I'll tinker around more to see how I can get it working a bit nicer for slower connections. Thanks for the reply...

> use light images

Manually blurring non-subjects (eg background) & aggressive graphics compression helps.  There is a hard-core compressor that I use that will shrink most images 5-70%, & some online versions allow free use. 
Also, [sharding your domain for images &/or using CDNs like jsDelivr](http://tombyrer.github.io/slideshow-improving_load_times_with_cdns/#CDN_vs_Plain_Old-School_Hosting) for script & font assets can help decrease load time.

Even if "resize : false" is set, on mobile devices the page always re-sizes. This is an issue for responsive design because there is no control for e.g. navigation etc. This issue applies to Android as well as iOS touch devices. it works fine for desktop browsers.
I also tested with the provided examples and had the same results.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Kind regards,

Marcello

The `resize` option only affect the text on resize of the browser's window. (not on load).

A mobile phone browser can not be resized and therefore it won't make any sense on it unless you change orientation from vertical to landscape, where resize will be fired as expected.

In any case, I wouldn't recommend to use `resize:true` if you want to have total control over your text size. You should be using CSS3 media queries or some javascript for it.

Nop, the slides are not stacked. They are one after another as you see them when you slide.

If it gets a bit chunky is because your images are **huge**. You are using images of 3700 x 2100 pixels no matter what the resolution of the user is. 

I would recommend you to use css3 media queries to serve different images depending on the screen or to reduce the size of those images.

You will hardly see any website using images of that size. It is not recommended at all, not only for performance but also for the time needed to load them and their repercussion in SEO.

This is now possible with the [Fading Effect Extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/fadingEffect.html).
Assured compatibility with future releases of fullpage.js.

I realize this issue was closed on the scrollReveal thread. [https://github.com/julianlloyd/scrollReveal.js/issues/45](https://github.com/julianlloyd/scrollReveal.js/issues/45) But curious, if anyone has gotten both to play together. Is there a special callback function needed? I can get [scrollReveal](http://scrollrevealjs.org/) to load on the initial panel. But, navigating to any other sections with [fullPage.js](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/) does not work with scrollReveal or similar animated plugins for that matter.

I would say that it doesn't make much sense to use scrollReveal.js in combination of fullpage.js.

If you are using `autoScrolling:true` (which is the default one in fullpage.js) then you should be using callbacks such as `afterLoad` or `onleave` to fire the animations you want.

The problem underneath is due to the fact that fullpage.js doesn't really scroll the page. It just changes the `top` property of a container or uses a `translate3d` transformation in case of using `css3:true`.

scrollReveal.js won't be able to recognize when fullpage.js is scrolling unless you use the option `autoScrolling:false`, which will make fullpage.js look [like this](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html).

As pointed out in [fullPage.js FAQs](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/wiki/FAQ---Frequently-Answered-Questions):

> Parallax, **as well as many other plugins which depends on the scrolling of the site**, listens the scrollTop property of javascript. fullPage.js doesn't actually scroll the site but it changes the top or translate3d property of the site. Only when using the fullPage.js option scrollBar:true or autoScrolling:false it will actually scroll the site in a way it is accessible for the scrollTop property.

So, there you have it:
Use [`scrollBar:true`](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrollBar.html) or [`autoScrolling:false`](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html).

And don't forget to initialize scrollReveal inside the `afterRender` callback. More info in the FAQs.

Hey :)

Thanks for the script. I've been having quite a lot of fun playing with it. Replacing the CSS3 transformations with the Velocity.js equivalent appears to work rather well. I considered using the transitionEnd event to release GPU resources after scrolling to a section/slide, but Velocity.js handles this automagically and is also backwards compatible with IE8/9. Given that it outperforms jQuery animations across the board and does not require CSS3 transform3d detection, it seems like a perfect fit for fullPage.js, apart from the fact that adds another dependency. I've offset this by using a non-standard jQuery build without the animation module etc.

Might it be worth looking at using Velocity.js instead of CSS3 or jQuery for animation?

I believe it involves a huge change in the plugin and I'm not sure of the benefits of it yet.
It would also add more than 40Kb to fullpage.js if the UI file is also needed. (34Kb otherwise).

Thinking about it twice, I believe I might integrate it as an option instead of using jQuery animations. 

CSS3 animations would remain intact. If the user wants to use velocity they would only have to set the option `velocity:true` and velocity animations would be used instead of jQuery ones.

Using `velocity:true` would require the inclusion of a new vendor. It would be set to `false` by default.

Does it make sense for you?

This way the plugin would work as follows:

Yeah, that looks good. I won't be using it personally because I have stripped fullPage.js down to include only what I need and have removed JQuery and CSS3 animations altogether. Given that velocity can act as a drop-in replacement for CSS translations and accepts a function to fire upon completion of animation like jQuery, integration was easy. 

I'd only fallback to CSS3 when Velocity cannot be found and both options are enabled. I found velocity's translateX/Y outperforms hardware accelerated CSS on my low end smartphone.

I'd also point out in the docs that the jQuery easing pack can be omitted when using velocity, as velocity bundles the extra easings by default.

> I'd also point out in the docs that the jQuery easing pack can be omitted when using velocity, as velocity bundles the extra easings by default.

Nice to known.

I've been testing its integration a bit on fullPage.js and on pagePiling.js.
I don't really notice a big improvement on the sliding performance. 

When tested in IE8 (IE 9 with browser mode and document mode set to IE8), I even notice a worse performance when using velocity.js than when using jQuery to animate the sections. (it also depends on the animation easing, using the default one for velocity (setting it to null) the difference its quite noticeable)

On the other hand, I can clearly see an improvement on iPhone 5 when using velocity instead of jQuery, but it seems to me that it still being worse than when using css3 translations.

The thing is, I don't see the point on using velocity on mobile phones or tablets, as they all usually support css3, and as the performance on desktop computers is even worse (for IE) and almost not noticiable in other browses, I'm not sure to what extend does it make sense to integrate it in fullpage.js.

If you want to test it, you can find a customization of fullpage.js [in this link](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/prueba/jquery.fullPage.js).

You will notice I added two more options in fullpage.js: 
- `velocityEasing`: sets the easing for velocity
- `velocity`: (boolean) to define whether to use velocity.js or jQuery instead.

I've tried it [in this demo](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/prueba/examples/backgrounds.html) with 15 sections with a fullscreen background. 

Feel free to play a bit with it or the customized fullpage.js to test it.

I tested it on some Android and iOS tablets and mobile phones and the animation is smoother.

If a section has only one slide and anchors are used, the site won't go to the section identified in the URL and menu navigation may show unexpected behaviour.

Fix is easy: just remove <slide> element and put content in <section>, but it's not obvious.

A single slide in a section has no sense. 
If you use slides is because you want to create an horizontal slider, for which you will need at least 2 slides.

Fullpage.js doesn't really scroll when using `autoScrolling:true`. It just changes the `top` property of the container or adds a a css3 `translate3d` effect to it.

You will be able to use it only when using `autoScrolling:false` in fullpage.js.

But it seems to me that you are talking about the **text resize**.... in that case, it makes total sense. It wont resize until you resize your window.
It needs a point of reference to start resizing. And that's when the site loads.

Otherwise the plugin can not know how you want to resize the text.

See this [related issue](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/492#issuecomment-45110427).

You are definitively talking about the text resizing. 

As pointed out in my previous answer and in the related topic I provided, that's not a bug. It is the way it works.

You should be using css3 media queries to avoid this kind of problems and not rely on the resize function of the plugin.
The plugin can not calculate the size of your text and decide how to adjust it. That's part of the designer's work.

The preferred window size is 900x825. The font size is scaled down when
the actual width or height are smaller. If both are smaller, the width
percentage is always used. This causes problems, for instance a 900x768
window has fonts that fit (sized with the height scale), but resizing it
down to 899x768 switches to use the width scale and the font gets bigger
again, overflowing off the page.

The fix is to calculate both scales and take the minimum to ensure that
the content fits in both dimensions.

Not sure how `scrollTo` plugin works. But this doesn't look like an issue of fullpage.js.
The way of scrolling by using anchors (#) won't work in a page if there's no scroll bar on the body of the site. To generate the real scroll bar you would need to use the option `autoScrolling:false` or using the method `setAutoScrolling(false)`.

Otherwise the scrollbar generated by `overflowScroll` won't act like a normal one.

Plus if you are using your fullpage.js plugin with anchors (#), fullpage will try to access a section or slide with that name.

The problem is that you are using `verticalCentered` but you are not creating the required structure for it in your new content. Fullpage.js uses `fp-tableCell` elements and it is expecting them in every section. But it seems you remove it somehow.

I see. When I enlarge my content to more than the viewport-height and do a reBuild, the `fp-tableCell`gets created.
If I then reduce my content and do another reBuild, the `fp-tableCell` gets removed.
On the next reBuild no fp-tableCell gets created and I get my error.

I will investigate some more...

I found the mistake!

In my custom scrollhandler remove-method I did this:
`element.find(SCROLLABLE_SEL).children().first().unwrap().unwrap();`

This removed one layer of nodes too much (probably necessary for slimscroll) so I changed it to:
`element.find(SCROLLABLE_SEL).children().first().unwrap();`

Now it works fine.
Thank you very much for your help - it guided me directly to the bug!
Thanks for it! :)

I'm not quite sure to understand your problem.

Why don't you just invert the order of the sections on the HTML markup?

There is a belief that web search indexers will only store the top _X_ kb of a webpage.  And sometimes the content or link that is near the top of the HTML is more important.
I know this used to be true 5+ years ago, but I have not found recent proof from the last 2 years of Google's changes which have been significant.

Your problem looks very specific and I don't think a solution for it will be provided.
I would recommend you to fork the project and modify it to fit your requirements. Or if you prefer, I can modify the plugin for you for some price.

Also, I'm not quite sure about the use of `order` for a SEO improvement.

I have 4 sections, but sometimes I only want index 1 and 2 allow for scrolling.
Is it possible to get my problem fixed?

There's no a proper way to do it right now.
You can do it by removing with javascript or jQuery the `fp-section` class from your 3rd and 4th section elements. This way the plugin won't realize there are more sections to scroll and won't scroll down anymore.

Whenever you want to allow the scrolling again, you can add those classes again. 

It is not the best way to do it, but its a work around meanwhile I think in a better way to deal with it.
Injected some lines in moveDownSections() and moveUpSections() solved me problem. I know this isnt the best way in sight to further updates but fixed my problem.
A new tag needs to be pushed reflecting the most recent changes to bower

Is it possible to set min-width and height settings? I am running into issues where I only want the site viewable on desktop and tablet as the content is not responsive enough to go down to mobile.

You can do that with jquery or javascript.

Just check whether then width or height of the device is bigger than what you want and then initialize the plugin. Otherwise don't.

The plugin doesn't offer that possibility but you can do it by yourself.

You can not use the `responsive` option detailed in the docs: 

> **responsive:** (default 0) A normal scroll (autoScrolling:false) will be used under the defined width in pixels. A class fp-responsive is added to the plugin's container in case the user wants to use it for his own responsive CSS. For example, if set to 900, whenever the browser's width is less than 900 the plugin will scroll like a normal site.

I have currently the same problem and typical solution involving scrollTop, anchors etc. have no effect, fullpage.js seems to catch this stuff.

The problem is that fullpage.js doesn't work scrolling the page. It works simulating a scroll of the page by adding the `top` or `translate3d` properties over the wrapper. 

There is a logic reason behind this. When using `overflow:hidden`  in the `html` and `body` elements in order to hide the scroll bar, the scrollTop won't work in all browsers. (try it in IE 8, Opera 12, Safari...)
`overflow:hidden` means the section is not "scrollable" anymore, and [`scrollTop` definition](http://api.jquery.com/scrolltop/) says:

> The vertical scroll position is the same as the number of pixels that are hidden **from view above the scrollable area**. Setting the scrollTop positions the vertical scroll of each matched element.

Nevertheless, there's people using fullpage.js together with some paralax plugin as you can see in some links of websites using fullpage.js at the documentation such as http://www.saltaboombox.com.ar/

@japhigu you can try to solve it by using `scrollOverflow:true`. You can see a demo in [this example page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html).

Now from version 2.4.4 you can combine fullPage.js with any parallax plugin if you use the option `scrollBar:true` as you can see [in this demo](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrollBar.html#secondPage).

> **scrollBar**: (default false). Determines whether to use scrol bar for the site or not. In case of using scroll bar, the autoScrolling functionallity will still working as expected. The user will also be free to scroll the site with the scroll bar and fullPage.js will fit the section in the screen when scrolling finishes.

This way the plugin will really perform the scroll of the site as all these kind of parallax techniques expect.
There's now a [parallax extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/parallax.html) to create parallax effects!

How does that solve your problem? I thought your problem was that you want the last part of the website to be scrollable as a normal website, like this example: http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/oneSection.html but with more sections before the "normal" website part.

It solves my problem because when you use the slides functionality built in to fullpage.js, the slides automatically take up the entire height of the page. Any content added after the slides gets pushed out, and you can't actually view it.

Using a different slides plugin means that the slides do not take up the entire height of the section, so you can insert content below the slides and scroll to it.

If you only have one single section, you can do it like [in the example](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/oneSection.html) using `autoScrolling:false`.

Otherwise it is more complicated if you want to use `autoScrolling:true`.

I think I found one solution, that is when you want the page scroll as normal, just call function `$.fn.fullpage.setAutoScrolling(false);`
and you can call `$.fn.fullpage.setAutoScrolling(true);` to make it change back to the sliders.

Some known issues:
a. Doesn't work when you have more than 1 scrolling div on the page. The mouse wheel event is bind at window level. This needs to be reworked to support multiple scrolling div on the same page.
b. Navigation dots are not moved inside of the container. This is by design as the partial div could be too small to host the navigation dots.
Thanks for your hard works & notification of issues :)

In my website, I have a setup of two sections, both containing two slides.

It is essentially structured in a 2x2 grid as follows:
a b
c d

**a** and **b** are slides in section 1; **c** and **d** are slides in section 2. 
From **b** you can navigate to **c**; from **c** you can navigate to **d**; from **d** you can navigate to **a**. 

So my question/issue is that when going from **d** to **a** (after following the chain I listed above), the page first scrolls to **c**, then slides to **a**. Is there anyway to have it jump directly to **a** without the slide? I tried changing the `active` class for the slides using the `onLeave` callback, but it didn't seem to do anything. 

Hopefully this makes sense, I can clarify if needed.

You just have to use the URLs to do it as detailed int he documentation:

> If you are using fullPage.js with anchor links for the sections (using the anchors option), then you will be able to use anchor links also to navigate directly to a certain slide inside a section. For example: http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/#secondPage/2

From D to A it goes directly. 
You can try it on the [demo site](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/#firstPage) going from the 2nd slide of the 2nd section to the 1st section.

Is it possible to do something like `$.fn.fullpage.moveTo(last);` ?

This could come in handy when creating slides dynamically. Thanks! :)

`$.fn.fullpage.moveTo()` method uses the `.eq()` method from jQuery to retrieve a page with its index.

As fullPage.js don't use a zero-based index, you can call `$.fn.fullpage.moveTo(0)` to go to the last page (-1 for the second from the end of the set, etc...).
Just count the number of sections  (`.section`) with jQuery and use `moveTo`.

If you resize the browser, the font resizes.  That's cool & handy sometimes.
But if you refresh the browser, the font sizes return to what they were before the resize.  Eg, make the browser smaller, the fonts become smaller.  Refresh, the font size jumps big again.
Win7 Chrome & Firefox.  I haven't tested IE.

Yeah. That's normal. There's no reference to set the size of the text. It only changes when resizing the window in reference to the original size and the new window's size.

This is a feature which might be deleted and doesn't look very useful.

> This is a feature which might be deleted and doesn't look very useful.

It can be helpful, but is more confusing.  IMHO I'd just do CSS media queries.  You can bake those into the CSS if you wish, or just have an mini-tutorial-example?

I'm afraid there's no other solution for what you are looking for.  The plugin doesn't offer that possibility. 

The scrolling events are only fired when using `autoScrolling:true` (the default one), which causes the scroll bar of the site to disappear making it impossible to scroll normally with the mouse.
So, it is not possible to make only a piece of my website work with the plugin? It must be all of it?

fullpage.js is a full page plugin. Expect it to be part of the whole page :)

I believe there's a way to do it with a big of imagination, by using 2 sections and in the 2nd one an scrollable div, combined with the option `normalScrollElements` and then using the function `moveTo` or `moveSectionUp` that fullpage provides. Firing it when the scrollable div reaches the top again would reach you back to the 1st section.

You probably have to use `afterLoad` calback in the 2nd section so you can create your own mousewheel event (and touch event if you want to support touch devices) and then disable them using the callback `onLeave` of the 2nd section scrolling to the 1st one.

You can give it a go.Or if you prefer, I can spend some time on it for some price.
Updated answer. You don't need to use the `destruct` function. Just to create your own mouse and touch events. And their destruction ones as well.

If you want to rebuild it, then you need to destroy it with the `all` option. Otherwise you will only unbind the events that fullpage adds such as the mouse wheel scrolling, touch scrolling... 

Use `destroy('all')`:

> **destroy(type)**
> type: can be empty or all. **If all is passed, the HTML markup and styles used by fullpage.js will be removed. This way the original HTML markup, the one used before any plugin modification is made, will be maintained.**
> 
> //destroy any plugin event and any plugin modification done over your original HTML markup.

You're welcome, nice to know you solved your issue.

- Tabs to 4 spaces
- Some -vendor- prefixes: [transitions](http://beta.caniuse.com/#search=transitions), [box-sizing](http://beta.caniuse.com/#search=box-sizing), [border-radius](http://beta.caniuse.com/#search=border-radius) haven't been in use for years.
- Using a space inside `navigationTooltips` causes wrapping unless you use `white-space: nowrap;`

Hello,

Is there a way for me to only allow users to navigate between sections by clicking anchors? I want to have full page sections, but I don't want users to scroll between them (there's no scrolling necessary within individual sections).

Use the method [`$.fn.fullpage.setAllowScrolling(false);`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#setallowscrollingboolean) and [`$.fn.fullpage.setKeyboardScrolling(false);`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#setkeyboardscrollingboolean).

> setAllowScrolling(boolean)
> Adds or remove the possiblity of scrolling through sections by using the mouse wheel/trackpad or touch gestures (which is active by default).
> 
> setKeyboardScrolling(boolean)
> Adds or remove the possiblity of scrolling through sections by using the keyboard arrow keys (which is active by default).
Direct to easing examples.
Thanks.

Ok, the [libgrabber README](https://github.com/jsdelivr/libgrabber#libgrabber) was confusing to me, so I updated it for you.

> How often does the plugin get updated?

When you [create a new package](https://github.com/jsdelivr/libgrabber#create-new-package-release)  Since you like to make many small changes (which is cool), I'd recommend about monthly GitHub Releases or after you fix a nasty bug.  You could [release](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/releases) at every PR if you wanted; decide how you wish.

Cool thing about jsDelivr that it supports aliasing, so `//cdn.jsdelivr.net/jquery.fullpage/2.1/jquery.fullPage.min.js` will auto-update any bugfixes & updates you Release in the v2.1.*

As noted in https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/553 I had to update slimscroll.js to fix an issue with it. Doing so was very difficult since slimscroll.js was modified for fullpage.js and only the minified version is provided.

If an uncompressed version is additionally provided, its easier to make these upgrades and troubleshoot.

Thanks,
Keith

I wouldn't like to add many unnecessary files for normal users. The less files the less confusion they will face.

Besides that, I'm not too happy with slimScroll behavior and I was thinking of changing it some day for [isscroll.js](https://github.com/cubiq/iscroll). But right now it doesn't support IE 8...

The changes made to slimScroll are [to solve a problem when slimScroll is added dynamically](https://github.com/rochal/jQuery-slimScroll/issues/133). Which could be consider a bug in SlimScroll.js rather than a customization of the plugin for fullpage.js

It's a pity that SlimScroll plugin is kind of abandoned and even if I make a fork nobody will merge it... but that's the place where it should be.

The files for fullPage.js must be included in the document's `<head>`. I made the mistake of including everything at the end of my `<body>`, and it did not work. I just added a reminder to do so in the README.

You might be using the old way of initializing the plugin. 

Since version 2.0, if you use a selector to initialize the plugin and the wrapper for the plugin, then you can add all your javascript file at the end of the page (just over the closing `</body>` tag) and it will still working without any problem. (although I don't personally recommend it, as this plugin sets the looking of the site, and until it is applied you won't see the site properly...)

It can not be done with fullpage.js.
Sections are always full screen. (full page means that) You can never have a section bigger than the height of your browser's window.

If the section can not be bigger than the section there's no way you can scroll inside.

The only way is using the plugin option `scrollOverflow:true` but that doesn't work the way you want.

The short answer is. No. You can't do what you are looking for. The scrollbar can not be added partially in only some part of the site. I would recommend you to use an absoluted positioned footer inside the last section.

The CSS selectors are related with those classes so you can not change them that easily without taking into account that.
There was an [old topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/224) trying to do the same.

As mentioned [in this other open topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/403), to deal with this problem, the plugin should internally works with a predefined class (as the CSS styles should be linked to it).
To avoid problems with common class names, a fullpage prefix such as `fp-`. could be used.

`.fp-section`, `.fp-slide`...

I close this topic as I won't merge the request. If you want to add anything to the topic, just answer in [this another one](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/403).

Solved in the last version. v.2.1.5 (required the updated CSS file as well)
Slide and Section selectors are now configurable. Internally the plugin will use selectors prefixed with `fp-` (meaning fullpage-). (such as `fp-table`, `fp-next`, `fp-scrollable`...)

You can't use wow.js if that plugin is taking into account the scrolling value. 

Fullpage.js doesn't actually scroll the page. In fact, the `body, html` property is `overflow:hide;`.
Fullpage uses `top` or `translate3d` properties over the plugin wrapper.

As you are hijacking the default behaviour of the browser (scrolling), when the viewport contents is greater in height than the contents you cannot scroll to see it. A basic principle of the web.

Content is cut off, the responsive experience is poor.
### Chrome OSX (notebook size)

![screen shot 2014-06-25 at 15 01 00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/713128/3386141/3102441c-fc71-11e3-8e49-addcd2b83378.png)
### iPhone

![screen shot 2014-06-25 at 14 57 15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/713128/3386106/d2a5f472-fc70-11e3-89d1-92827977fad0.png)
### Nexus 7

![screen shot 2014-06-25 at 14 59 32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/713128/3386117/f3489766-fc70-11e3-8f52-9abeeb759013.png)

That's why this plugin offers an option called `scrollOverflow`:

> scrollOverflow: (default false) defines whether or not to create a scroll for the section in case its content is bigger than the height of it. In case of setting it to true, it requieres the vendor plugin jquery.slimscroll.min and it should be loaded before the fullPaje.js plugin. For example:

This doesn't support horizontal scrollbar, that will depend on the responsive design of the page.

The nature of scroll hijacking is just so bad though. This can still work well without the scroll hijacking.

:bomb:

By the way, here's an available example for your problem:
http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html#secondPage

That example proves the bad UX. You scroll down the "inner page" to read the copy not knowing your near the bottom of the content and all of a sudden your automatically scrolled onto the next "slide". You then have to scroll backup careful not to scroll back down again.

It's a bad trend that's setting in. It's not a comment on your work/ability, just the technique itself.

> not knowing your near the bottom of the content

Anyway, the scroll bar stills there. So in some way you have a reference for that. Thinking about changing it for [a better scroll bar](https://github.com/cubiq/iscroll) but right now it doesn't support IE 8.

And what to implement in my file to get this desired effect to make the slide change a bit smoother.

Thank you!

The Apple example I created is using `css3:true` instead of the default option `css3:false`.
This way it will work smother in some devices (it is hardware accelerated ) and in tablets or mobile phones (usually).

In old browsers css3 is not supported so it will fallback to jQuery animations. 

Take also into account that with `css3:true` you **can not** use jQuery easing animations and you will have to work with the CSS3 easing effects in case you want to modify them.

To modify the css3 easing parameters you have to do it on [the `.easings` class](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.css#L83) provided in the `jquery.fullpage.css` file:

You have to use `$.fn.fullpage.reBuild()` as detailed in the documentation.

Anyway, your problem is that by using `slideToggle` you are adding the inline style property `display:block` to your `#servicewrapper` element which overwrites the `display:table` property.

You can see it by inspecting the DOM [here](http://jsfiddle.net/N24xg/).

Also take into account that the `table` style in fullpage.js is only applied to `.section` elements or `.slide` elements:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I'm sorry, I meant the navigation specified by the `menu` option. Specifically I'm referring to [this](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L282) line of your plugin.
And why is it a problem for you? The menu will be using `position:fixed` (or it shoud...) so it doesn't matter where it is placed in the DOM.

After I ran the plugin, the menu wasn't where I left it, which caused problems in both my JavaScript and CSS. If you style an element relying on a certain DOM structure, then if that structure silently changes along the way, the styles will naturally be screwed up.

The menu doesn't have to use `position: fixed`, it can use `position: absolute` as well. I think the plugin should be agnostic of how do I style my menu and not change DOM structuring unless there's a really good reason for it. I would simply suggest in the README how to style the navigation.

That's normal. It's the way the plugin works.
The plugin can not know which size you want for the text on the first load.

When using `resize:true` it will resize the text down when reducing the size of the window in reference to the original size.

I would recommend you to use css3 media queries to deal with this problem instead.
And turn `resize:false` if you prefer.

Your code contains errors.
You are loading the jquery UI 11 when it doesnt exist...
You are using the new initialization of the plugin but then you are forgetting to wrap your code in the #fullpage id element.

And the most important one and [the cause of your problem](http://viralpatel.net/blogs/jquery-window-height-incorrect/). You are forgetting to add the DOCTYPE  declaration over your `html` tag.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

jQuery wonÂ´t be able to work properly without it.

> The <!DOCTYPE> declaration must be the very first thing in your HTML document, before the <html> tag.
> The <!DOCTYPE> declaration is not an HTML tag; it is an instruction to the web browser about what version of HTML the page is written in.
Fascinating. This indeed fixed the problems I've had - thanks for your help and for your work on this project!

the bower.json file in the downloaded package states "jquery" as the name.
it is important because it impacts scripts with further libs depending on "jquery" .
e.g. when automatically generating sources => jquery gets injected twice.

Right now the library does 2 things (which make total sense): 1. When the user clicks on a link with a target as the href, the library recognizes the 'hashchange' event, and changes to the selected page. 2. When the user scrolls on the screen, the library recognizes the scroll event and changes to the next page in the scroll direction. However, when the user scrolls and the library changes the page, it does not update the window location hash. This means that if someone scrolls to the next page, they won't be able to deep link to that page. They will be able to deep link if they click on a link with a target as the href, but not scrolling. Here's a user story if this helps: 1. User visits website, first page is shown by default. 2. User clicks on `Page Two`, which changes the URL to `http://example.com/#page2` and triggers the `window.hashchange` event. 3. FullPage.js' listener on the `window.hashchange` event animates to the next page. 4. User copies url to direct people to page2 and people who click on `http://example.com/#page2` will successfully see the second page. Not working story: 1. User visits website, first page is shown by default. 2. User scrolls on window with intention of visiting next page. 3. FullPage.js' listener on `window.scroll` animates to the next page. 4. User copies url (which is still `http://example.com`) with the intention of showing people the second page. 5. People who click on the shared link will not see page 2, instead they will see the default first page. Ref: #175. Is that clearer?

> Not working story:
> 
> 1 User visits website, first page is shown by default.
> 2 User scrolls on window with intention of visiting next page.
> 3 FullPage.js' listener on window.scroll animates to the next page.
> 4 User copies url (which is still http://example.com) with the intention of showing people the second page.
> 5 People who click on the shared link will not see page 2, instead they will see the default first page.

I don't know how are you able to reproduce it.  The point 4 is wrong. The URL should be with an anchor link (#).

If you try it by using the [demo page](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/), you will see the URL hash changing every time you make any scroll with the mouse.
And that's not because of the `window.scroll` event, but because of the mousewheel one.

Even if you use `autoScrolling:false` the URL hash keep updating on scroll as you can see in this other [example online](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html). This time triggered by `window.scroll`.

Show me an example reproducing  your problem. I really don't understand which is the trouble you are having.

We weren't using `autoScrolling:false`, but I re-looked at your demo code and not specifying the anchors fixed this issue. That's a very interesting behavior.

If I have some time I'd like to help you flush out more of the docs. The options aren't self-explanatory and the required options don't seem noted.

Anyway, thanks for being responsive to my questions!

That's interesting. I'm on a Macbook Pro laptop and want this to be a settable option so that I can lower it! The scrollDelay seems like it should just be set to scrollingSpeed (+1 maybe). That way you won't take new scroll events until it's done scrolling but also can then immediately scroll again if you want. 

As it is today, if I set scrollingSpeed to 300 (so that the transition doesn't feel sluggish) there's this weird 300ms delay before I can swipe again.

Also, as it is today, with the default for scrollingSpeed being 700 and the scrollDelay being 600 (hardcoded), won't there be a 100 milliseconds where weirdness can creep in?

> The scrollDelay seems like it should just be set to scrollingSpeed (+1 maybe).

Nop, there's inertia in the scrolling event. Even after you stop scrolling, the scrolling event will still being fired for almost a second depending on how fast you accelerated. 
This is more visible yet with Apple magic mouse. Users using it request a higher `scrollDelay`...

> Also, as it is today, with the default for scrollingSpeed being 700 and the scrollDelay being 600 (hardcoded), won't there be a 100 milliseconds where weirdness can creep in?

Nop, the `scrollDelay` is added after the animation finishes.

I see. Yeah, I see the inertia there now. So it's still possible to get the double movement if I swipe "hard" enough (making the inertia higher and the slow down period longer) ... even with 600. Interesting.

It seems like a solution might be to relate all of a series of scroll events together and then disregard any more once the movement has started. 

Looking at the events generated in Chrome on OSX on my Macbook Pro, it looks the srcElement, target, path, etc stay consistent within the same series of WheelEvent events. 

If you combined that information with a timeout in the wheel event handler (that would reset the timeout on each event), you could say something like "only scroll again if I'm not moving and the scroll target isn't the same as the original".

Thoughts?

> Looking at the events generated in Chrome on OSX on my Macbook Pro, it looks the srcElement, target, path, etc stay consistent within the same series of WheelEvent events.

Not sure what you mean with that. Which target?

hi 

I am am using the function  $.fn.fullpage.moveSlideRight(); to automatically  move the slides.

thanks
AWESOME PLUGIN !!!

Documentation says:

> moveSlideRight()
> Scrolls the horizontal slider **of the current section** to the next slide:

That means, it only affects the current section.

And yeah, it is possible. Just use the `afterLoad` callback to do it only in the sections you want and to STOP it whenever you want.
If you set an interval, it will be fired every X milliseconds, so when you scroll down to another section with slides, it will keep being fired and it will affect the current section again. So you have to stop your interval whenever you want. But this doesnt mean the function is global, it is just that you are calling it for every section.

var idInterval;

To use the auto sliding only in some sections, then instead of using the `afterRender` to set the timeout, use an `afterLoad` callback. That way you will only initialize it for that slider.

Who of you guys uses the **space bar** and **shift+space** as a natural alternative to page down / page up? I think those keystrokes are generally accepted for "next" and "previous" (e.g. see [reveal.js](https://github.com/hakimel/reveal.js/blob/master/js/reveal.js#L2719)).

I would add `Space` (code 32) and `Shift`+`Space` to the list of available keyboard navigation keys, too.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
@bittner shift+space ? I've never heard of it. It does nothing in any browser as far as I know.

Well, it does. Just tested it on FF, Chrome, IE 9 (Windows), and FF, Chrome (Ubuntu). Try it with lengthy pages: `Space` works as `PgDn`, and `Shift`+`Space` as `PgUp` in all major browsers.

Please, also visit the link above that jumps into the reveal.js source code. The "next" / "previous" of space / shift+space has an interesting meaning there, which could also be applicable to fullPage: The arrow keys follow the one, indicated direction only; space, on the other hand, follows the whole two-dimensional path (try with the [demo presentation](http://lab.hakim.se/reveal-js/#/)).

This could work out for two-dimensional navigation with fullPage too (see [horizontal navigation](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/navigationH.html#secondPage) demo).

callback in moveSectionUp and moveSectionDown used to trigger application that a moveDown or a moveUp has been requested. If application does not want to slide now (because pending animation for instance) it could return false from couldMoveDown or couldMoveUp
What would be the purpose of it? In which situation could it be useful?

Well in our case we need to slide up the footer with an animation when we are in the last slide.
We do not want a fullpage, so we do not want to add a new section just for the footer (it has to be visible in the last page). 
So when we are in the last slide if a move down is detected by fullpage we slide up the footer
Then if a moveup is detected we slidedown the footer and we do not want the page to slide up (that the meaning of returning true/false in couldMoveUp)

https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/blob/master/jquery.fullPage.js#L173

$('.section').each(function(index){ } )

...it's possible that there could be other 'section' classes used by other jQuery plugins or it could be a user-defined css class.

I agree it would be simpler to just hardcode prefixed selectors right into the plugin. I see you already have a few prefixed with .fullPage- and #fullPage-, what are your thoughts on prefixing all selectors like this?

And also, I would prefer to keep it as simple as possible plus using a more complex selector such as `fullpage-section` adds more text to the minified file making it bigger.

I was thinking now about maybe allowing to define a selector for sections and slides, but then internally add another class such as`fp-section` or `fp-slide` which then could be used internally as selectors.

Something like:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This way the CSS style sheet problem would be solved, as we could use a fixed selector for them, and the configurable selector as well.
The default `sectionSelector` could still be `.section`.

Of course, this would be exactly the same as using `fp-section` directly from the start:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

But... maybe it doesn't look that cool anymore?

I don't know what you've done, but I can not check the changes from here.
It says "1511 additions, 1473 deletions not shown". That's... A LOT :D

I agree using fullpage-section or even fp-section are not exactly the friendliest.

I sent up a PR based on your style of using selectors based on the options object for all selectors and classes in the plugin. It looks something like....

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This way, people that want clean selectors and won't have any potential for collisions can use 'active', 'section', 'slide', 'slides', 'table', etc. as is, without any modifications. For me, I can change the options config to give me prefixed classes so that fullPage can run in a completely safe sandboxed mode.
Yes it was a lot, I had to use my desktop diff tool, as github would not show all the diffs...

That's not what i meant. 

I was talking about referencing sections as `$('.fp-section')` inside the plugin except in the top of it, where we add the `fp-section` to all of the ones defined with the custom selector. 

Otherwise, if you use any other selector the CSS styles won't be applied to them.

Anyway, there are some selectors I consider they shouldn't be customizabled, such as the ones starting by `fullpage` (.fullPage-nav, .fullPage-nav.right, .fullPage-nav.left, .fullPage-slidesNav, .fullPage-slidesNav.bottom ... etc). There shouldn't be any collision ever. It would be difficult to find other plugin those exact same selectors. It is adding unnecessary code to the plugin which will rarely be useful for anyone. 

The same with the `#superContainer` selector. It shouldn't be configurable as it is to maintain compatibility the older required HTML markup and should no longer be used. 

I consider only the main and "public" classes should be configurable. These ones are:
-  `.section` 
- `.slide` 

Things like `slides` or `table`... etc, are only used internally. Changing them internally to `fp-slides` or `fp-table` won't affect the user in any way, it won't add so many bites and the problem would be solved. 
The end user doesn't have to know about these selectors.

+1 Something like this has to be done. "section" is way too generic a classname, and is bound to collide with other styles.  If you can't or don't want to make it customizable, just pick a namespace and move to it ("fullpage-section", "fullpage-slide").

This really is a best practice.

Solved in the last version. v.2.1.5 (require the updated CSS file as well)
Slide and Section selectors are now configurable. Internally the plugin will use selectors prefixed with `fp-` (meaning fullpage-). (such as `fp-table`, `fp-next`, `fp-scrollable`...)

Thanks for the update. Its a slight improvement, but I think having a configurable prefix option is still the ideal route.

I would be happy to make these changes and submit a PR for this as well.

Take a look at this gist so you can see what I mean: https://gist.github.com/d13/2cfaa6e5c05ece87ece3

Using these to easily update the CSS naming in conjunction with a prefix option in the JS would make it very easy for devs to manage the prefixing without messing up anything.

Added the feature to define a custom Markup for control arrows (e.g. having > and < instead of pure CSS arrows).

Additionally, control arrows are only displayed if there is more than one slide present per section, adding the possibility to have a single slide markup present (for formatting reasons) without the controls being displayed.

The custom markup shouldn't allow to modify the `controlArrow` or `next` and `prev` classes. As these are used internally and for the needed CSS styling. 

I don't see very well the purpose of the custom markup besides adding some additional css classes or IDs. (which shouldn't be such a big deal as you can always use `.controlArrow.prev` and `.controlArrow.next` selectors).

Also, with CSS you could specify the content of them by using the `content` property and add your desired HTML elements such as > and <.

Could be a nice addition to have an `afterResize` callback? Since actually you advice to use `afterRender` to initialize some components but maybe they depends on the section dimensions and should be refreshed or reinitialized after the component does its resizes.

I've also tried to use window.resize event but it's fired before your component has done resizing. I've locally added

`$.isFunction( options.afterResize ) && options.afterResize.call(this);`

after the `isResizing = false;` in the `doneResizing` function and seems to work fine, if you would accept the contribution I can create a PR with it

There's [another topic opened treating the same topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/75).

I will happily accept your PR :) . Don't forget to add it into the documentation file as well. Ideally after `afterRender` with its respective description.

`afterLoad` is no being fired on load of the site. You would need to use the callback `afterRender` for it.

> **afterRender()**
> This callback is fired just after the structure of the page is generated. This is the callback you want to use to initialize other plugins or fire any code which requires the document to be ready (as this plugin modifies the DOM to create the resulting structure).

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Hi, i've got a problem when setting    css3: true
it automatically sets the menu as a fixed element, which prevents it from being shown on  the navbar (I'm using twitter bootstrap3 ), you can see this issue here: http://jsfiddle.net/tdrP6/1/

if you remove the menu option, it doesn't have any issues, apart from the fact that you don't get the active class highlight; If you set the menu as a fixed element, without setting the menu option of fullPage, you get the same results as if you set the fullPage option

Example:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

and 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

shows the same on the html page

(By using the dev tools you can see that the menu isn't inside the nav markup, on any of the two examples)

I really have no idea if it is a bug or if I'm doing something wrong

It's not a bug.

Your `menu` option doesn't have to be the menu itself, it could be its wrapper. 
If you use `menu`, then you don't have to use `fixedElements`, it will move it out from the wrapper as well.

The `menu` option just move that element out of the wrapper and creates the `active` class for the elements with the `data-menuanchor` tag. 

Take a look at your [updated example](http://jsfiddle.net/tdrP6/2/).

I just removed the `fixedElements` option and changed it for the `menu` option linking it to your menu wrapper. 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
I guess I didn't think it would work that way, thanks and keep up the good work !

It's useful to know onLeave which section you're going to - using the navigation, for instance, it may not be the immediate next or previous section, so the "up" or "down" isn't much help.

It's trivial to add it into the code (the variable needed is called sectionIndex), but it would be better to have part of the main branch.

Thanks!

Similar topic was treated [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/365).

Could you explain why in your case are you interested in knowing the destination? CanÂ´t you use another callback such as `afterLoad` for it?

Hi unfortunately my site's on an intranet so I can't show you, but in our case it was hooking up an animation relevant to the target slide (but not on it), which needed to begin as you leave the previous slide. That way the whole animation can 'arrive' at the same time. But there is no easy way of telling which section is coming next.

Another use case might be for lazy-loading: the 600ms transition between sections might be a good time to fetch resources for the section being loaded (either images or through ajax), rather than waiting for the afterLoad event.

Thanks.

Did anyone encounter an issue when a video takes up the whole section and it prevents you from scrolling up or down using a touch device such as an iPad?

I'm using video.js with <video> tags which I scale fully to fit the section container. It seems to prevent touch scrolling on an iPad.

Any clues on how to solve that or what the underlying issue is?

It sounds like a problem with iOS and the detection of touch events over HTML 5 video elements.

I would encourage you to avoid the use of videos for touch devices and change it for a plane image. This way you will speed up your site for those devices and you will probably avoid many problems with some devices. 

I've tried it on my iPhone and I can see the play button when it is suppose to play automatically, which is not perfect either...

iOS doesn't allow automatic video playback - that's a hurdle I've already discovered.
Unfortunately, avoiding using videos in the webpage is not an option.

Look at [this answer](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3469781/ipad-touch-events-on-video-tag) or [this another one](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3803702/html5-video-element-on-ipad-doesnt-fire-onclick-or-touchstart-events).

It is not a problem of fullpage.js but of the video element and iOS. You will have to find the way to solve it by dealing with the video element, not with fullpage.js.

Asp.net is a back-end language and fullpage.js is a plugin for jQuery which is a front-end framework.

You just need to include the needed files and follow the needed structure. Follow [the documentation](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js) for it.

This is to attempt to fix the problem of allowing `normalScrollElements` to work on touch devices. Before it calls `event.preventDefault()` in `touchMoveHandler(event)`, it tests to see if the target element has one of the `normalScrollElements` in its parent nodes recursively and uses a new option, `normalScrollElementTouchThreshold` to limit the recursion.

Added option to use semantic HTML5 containers

A little more info...
I added an option `html5` when set to `true`, will allow the user to use semantic `section` containers, specifically `<section data-role="page">`, as the top level page elements.

I would rather recommend to use the class `.section` for each `<section>` tag. This would solve the problem:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

It doesn't look like something so needed and it adds more complexity to the code. 
We have to remember as well that although they choose not to use the `html5` option, the styles for the `<section data-role="page">` tag would keep being applied, which doesn't make much sense.

Also, HTML5 tags are not well interpreted by old browsers such as IE 8 and some users might now know about it...

The data-role="page" is ARIA compliant. 

Plus, the HTML5 option is false by default. 

section tags do also work in IE8 with a polyfill. Would you be open to merging the pull request if I added the appropriate polyfill? (Essentially it's just a createElement call). 

Thanks,

Daniel Mullins

> Why are you reluctant to use the section class in your <section> elements?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Using classes is a very common practice in jQuery plugins plus it also adds the needed CSS styling.

Personally I don't see the reason why we should add more complexity to the plugin when adding a simple class solves the problem. 

Also, it is a way to abstract the logic of the plugin from the HTML markup. Using the `.section` class allows you to use any tag you want (`<article>`, `<section>`, `<span>`, `<div>`...) 
Modifying the plugin for each of those elements wouldn't be worthy.

I understand your argument.

Iâ€™ve been trying to add animations before the scroll starts, and I guess that's why most people might want a 'beforeLeave' event. There's a very simple workaround that I thought might be useful to share: simply add a timeout to perfomMovement within the scrollPage function: 
    `setTimeout(function(){performMovement(v);}, 400);`
That creates a lag though, i.e. if you scroll or press keys rapidly, things get messy. Fixed this by temporary disabling KeyboardScrolling until sections are fully loaded: 
    `FP.setKeyboardScrolling(false); setTimeout(function(){FP.setKeyboardScrolling(true);}, 1400);`
(--still within the scrollPage function)
Same logic for scrolling, replacing 'canScroll=trueâ€™  in the afterSectionLoads function by:
            `canScroll = false; setTimeout(function(){canScroll = true;}, 400);`
Gives a behavior similar to this: https://cloudmagic.com/ or this: http://torchbrowser.com/
It means users canâ€™t bolt through sections by scrolling, but I guess thatâ€™s why god made nav-dots and anchor links :)

By the way, this is a truly amazing plugin, Iâ€™ll make sure to make a donation. Cheers!

Forgive me, I'm just learning a new codebase using fullpage.js, so I may be conflating things, but here we go:

We use the `fixedElements` option to keep our controls separate from the slide structure. The presence of the `controlArrow` class causes magic to happen (clickable scrolling), which isn't documented anywhere except in examples. In my case I needed to add event tracking to those clicks, but couldn't figure out at a glance if the click events on those arrows we're handled by code my team had written or internally to the plugin. Moreover, if somebody needs to theme this it's useful to have a reference of what the functional classes are, that doesn't require reading examples.

I would recommend you to, instead of tacking the clicks, tracking the times slides are loaded. This way you might have the exact same results as you are looking for.

You could do it by using the callback: [`afterSlideLoad`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#afterslideload-anchorlink-index-slideanchor-slideindex).

There's no function in the plugin yet to scroll horizontally although [I'm in process of adding it into the plugin](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/288) soon.
For what it's worth, in this I explicitly needed to be able to distinguish between "clicks" and navigation made via keystrokes or anchors.

Then you just have assign an event to the `.controlArrow` element with jQuery. You don't need to code it into the plugin itself:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
Sure, that's what I did. I'm just saying the functionality was opaque. It would be nice if all the UI elements we're documented.

But that's like adding an event to any element on the site or deciding to modify the styles. You only need the selector for it which anyone can obtain by looking at the HTML markup. 

The plugin documentation includes all its options and methods and explanations about how they work. 
The classes that they use are (and should be) irrelevant in terms of functionality for the end user.

If any front-end designer/programmer wants to change any UI element style or behavior, they will have to check the DOM structure to determine which selectors are needed for use for it.

I don't know which kind of documentation were you expecting for the `.controlArrow` elements. A single click to inspect the element in any DOM inspector would have been enough.

You might be talking about the delay between arriving from another section and being able to move to any other section again.
This has been treated multiple times in this forum and it has been explained why that delay was implemented. 

It is done on purpose to avoid problems with laptop trackpads and Apple products such as the magic trackpad or the magic mouse (as well as all Apple laptops).

You could change the `scrollDelay` option but users with a other devices will complain...

Take a look at [this related topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/298)

And to this ones:
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/12
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/164
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/18
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/73
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/314

If you read the console you will see this error message:

> Uncaught TypeError: Object #<Object> has no method 'easeInQuart' 

Which means the plugin doesn't know what's it. That's the jQuery effect you are adding for the transitions and you forgot to add the jQuery UI library or the file `vendors/jquery.easings.min.js` which contains all the jQuery UI effects. (only them, and not the rest of the library)

If you read [the documentation](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#including-files) you will see how this is specified.

Yeah. There's no problem with it. The menu element is only defined to move it out from the scrolling structure as well as to create the `active` class for the menu elements.

When continuousVertical is used, the last page index is incorrectly passed in the onLeave event. 
It then passes the index it is going to, not the index it is about to leave.

As can be seen in this jsfiddle:
http://jsfiddle.net/TDxV6/1/

There is never an index 4 alerted, erroneously it reports index 1 twice.

We're seeing an issue (confirmed by testing on the fullPage.js demo page) where a "hard" swipe (big/long/aggressive) on both a MacBook Pro touchpad and on an Apple Magic Mouse causes a double advance through sections.

With a hard swipe the section will advance and land on the next, stop briefly, and then advance to the next section.

More than hard I would say **long**. This is not actually an issue but the way the plugin is designed to work.

If you scroll for more than 600 milliseconds once you reach the destination section (which is not common...) then the plugin will consider you want to scroll again to the next section.

If you stop scrolling once you reach the next section, then you should not have any problem.

This topic is related with:
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/298
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/18
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/73
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/5
https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/164

Hmm, I guess I'm not sure if what you're describing is what we're seeing.

If the "hard" swipe is made -- and the finger stops touching the swipe surface _before_ landing on the next section -- the section transition will land/end, pause briefly, and then continue to another section.

Is that by design?

FWIW, this cannot be replicated with a mouse scroll wheel (at least none we have and can test with).

@theraccoonbear Nop, that wouldn't act that way. 
I will check it from home with my Macbook Pro and let you know. Does it happen in all browsers?

We're seeing the issue in at least these browsers on Mac OS 10.9.2

Firefox 26.0
Safari 7.0.2 (9537.74.9)
Chrome 33.0.1750.152
Fine.

Yeah. I've tested it and it seems to have some kind of bug with it.
I'm not sure what could be the cause, it seems like jQuery believes the user still scrolling when they are not...

I will try to research a bit on it, although I don't consider it a major problem as usually people don't scroll that fast :)

Understood.  It's obviously something of an edge or corner case requiring specific hardware and somewhat atypical usage, but thank you for confirming that it's a bug.  If nothing else we're glad we're not losing our minds over here :)

@alvarotrigo I've done some [research](http://blog.danyll.com/lethargy-tackling-inertial-scroll/) on this and it's not because of "jQuery believes the user still scrolling when they are not...", it's because the trackpad and Apple Magic Mouse emits scroll events long after the user has finished scrolling.
@d4nyll yeah I agree. Basically its the kinetic scrolling that keeps firing scrolling events because of its inertia. It seems at that moment in 2014 I didn't tested the scrolling enough.

I forgot to mention, this issue was solved time ago. Fullpage.js doesn't scroll twice anymore with hard swipes. It is able to detect deceleration (inertia) and prevent the scrolling. 

It only has problems with fast scrolling speeds at the moment.

Thanks so much Alvaro. > Should I assume that section 2 slide 2 is the last slide of section 2? No. There may be a section 2 slide 3, but there won't ever be a section 2 slide 3 without a section 1 slide 3 for it to correspond to. The Site will grow in section one, and then down as needed. | Section 1 | 0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | ... | | --- | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | | Section 2 | 0 | x | 2 | 3 | 4 | ? | | Section 3 | x | x | x | 3 | 4 | ? | | Section 4 | x | x | x | ... | ... | ? | ^ Something like that. Where the 1's are one series, the 2's another, and so on. "x" means no content for slide. I'll mention how thats a problem in a sec, but I bet you already see it. "..." means that the website can be added to and will grow from there. "?" means it depends on if any more content is necessary. Ex. One might add Section 1 Slide 5, and Section 2 Slide 5, but not need Section 3 Slide 5. At that point, Section 3 Slide 5 and Section 4 Slide 5 would become "x". - So, in Section 1, going left and right means that section 2, 3, and so on must follow. - \- That way, going down from section 1 to 2 will keep you in the corresponding column. - In section 1, you can't go up. - But in section 1, if there is a corresponding slide in section 2 you can go down to it. And down again if there was another corresponding slide in section 3. If you are elsewhere, say Section 2 Slide 2. - If you go up, you should land on Section 1 Slide 2. - If you go right, instead of going to Section 2 Slide 3, you get sent to Section 1 Slide 3. (The top of the column) - If you go left, instead of going to Section 2 Slide 1, you get sent to Section 1 Slide 1.(The top of that column) - \- Problem: It is the case that there may be no content for Section 2 Slide 1. Not sure how to handle this for all the other slides to correspond correctly. If we don't include it, then the numbers are thrown off. Maybe somehow flag filler empty Slides to be skipped? - If you go down, there is no slide content. So, you either you can't go down, or it wraps up to Section 1 Slide 2. -- Same problem as before. Even though there is no content, there is content on Section 3 Slide 3, so how do we act like there is no Section 3 Slide 2 , but keep columns corresponding? That pretty much covers all cases I think. > What should happen on scrolling left from the 1st slide of each section? Either nothing, or it wraps to (in this case) Section 1 Slide 4. Otherwise, Section 1 Slide (rightmost). Nothing nothing is preferable to me though. Just like this site. Warning: That site is awesome and extremely distracting. Thanks again for the help.

Is it possible with jQuery to remove a section and add it back to the document as a proper fullpage slide? Currently it is being added as a generic div with a class of slide rather than as a fullpage slide - it makes sense to me why it is behaving like this, but I'm not sure how to fix the issue.

Basic structure is:
The first section has two slides as the user must navigate horizontally, but then the third screen is a section, making them navigate vertically - on desktop.

On mobile, all screens must be horizontally navigable. I am width sniffing in order to get the mobile view, and then using .remove() to get rid of the second section and .append() to add it as a slide to the first section.

Is there a way I can do this while keeping all slides within fullpage?

I've got a workaround for this in case anyone else comes searching - until I find a better method, I have set the width in Javascript of .slidesContainer to 100% more (in this situation from 200% to 300%) and decreased .slides  based on the number of slides there are (from 50% to 33.333%).

Slide 3 (formerly Section 2) now takes on the basic functionality/appearance of fullpage and acts like a regular slide. Other feature or available options for the plugin (such as dot navigation) may not work with this method - I'm using a very stripped down version and have no need for the customisation so haven't checked that they work.

I believe the easy way to visually create that structure of the site would be to disable the mouse wheel or touch handlers to navigate vertically until you reach the last slide. This way from the user's point of view it will look like the section is in the last slide while actually it is under any slide.

You could use the method [`setAllowScrolling()`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#setallowscrolling)  setting it to false when you want to avoid the vertical scrolling and true when you want to allow it. 

In order to do it you probably want to use the [`afterSlideLoad`](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#afterslideload-anchorlink-index-slideanchor-slideindex) callback.

I guess you are using an Apple device. 
It is totally normal. There's a timelimit set to 600 miliseconds by default which avoid having this issue with a normal use of the trackpad. (as [it was a problem](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/5) reported long time ago)
If you scroll for more than 600 miliseconds then fullpage will scroll twice. I've been testing it with my Macbook Pro a normal scroll won't take more than usually 350 or 400 miliseconds and therefore I won't consider this as a problem. 

It works properly with mouse wheel. An increase of this timelimit would make it uncomfortable for  users with a mousewheel as it has been talked [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/pull/73) and [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/18)

Also, 1000 might do the job for your scrolling speed in your trackpad. But if someone still scrolling slower than you, they will still have the same problem.

I found my problem. I used `$( window ).load(function() { });` instead of  `$( document).ready(function() {});` around the fullpage initialization. I don't really know why this was a problem, but it was.
Most of the plugins needs to be called in the `ready` statement as they operate over elements of the site.

Yeah I know, but I thought `$( window ).load(function() { });` ("The load event is sent to an element when it and all sub-elements have been completely loaded.") is doing the same and the rest of the plugin worked, so I didn't suspected this as a problem.
Probably because the plugin inside is using `$(window).on('load',` as well.

@Pixelsmith  Just don't use data-src if you dont want lazy loading. Use src.

Not the answer I was looking for, but it did trigger the answer I needed.

The conflict I was having was that Lazy Load XT natively calls `data-src`, identical to FPJS.  LLXT allows me to [customize the SRC attribute](https://github.com/ressio/lazy-load-xt#options) with `srcAttr`, so I changed that and now everybody's playing nicely together.

What I have discovered, is under the `MouseWheelHandler` function in the plugin, under the `scrolling down` section, once it reaches the bottom (`if(isScrolled('bottom', scrollable)){`) I have changed `moveSectionDown` to
`removeMouseWheelHandler();
activeSection.find('.controlArrow.next:visible').trigger('click');
setTimeout(function() {addMouseWheelHandler();}, 1000);`
thus when it reaches the bottom, it arrests mouse movement, goes to the next section, and then resumes scrolling.

I'm not sure how efficient it really is, though. I might just have jQuerry `append` a "continue to next slide" button at the end of every slide...

You might also want to do it when there's no scrollbar in case of using big screens. 
But then you have to decide when or how are you going to scroll up o down to another section.

I have solved the delay problem, good sir!

You have to set `var threshold = 0` at the beginning of `function MouseWheelHandler`, then every time you scroll up (at the top) or down (at the bottom) the below script adds to the threshold. Once the threshold has been met, it will continue the normal function of the script. Just have to work this into touch-screens. You can read more about my inspiration here: http://www.hugeinc.com/ideas/perspective/scroll-jacking-on-hugeinc

Also, note that when it's at the bottom of scroll, `e.wheelDelta` should be `< 0`.

DOMMouseScroll is non standard anymore (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/DOM/DOM_event_reference/DOMMouseScroll). It fixes scrolling issues with trackpad in Firefox.

People reported to me that they had issues on MacOS X using Firefox when using trackpad to scroll between pages. I could reproduce. On MDN they announce that DOMMouseScroll is non-standard anymore and it has to be replaced by wheel event.

I tested it on MacBook Air with MacOS X 10.9.1 and Firefox 27.0.1. It works as expected for the people who reported the problem and myself after this fix.

I haven't been able to reproduce such a problem on the exact same conditions [as you can read on this topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/65#issuecomment-35846849).

It works well for me on Firefox 27.0.1 over Mavericks 10.9.1 by using a MacBook Pro with trackpad.

You are dealing here with a **fullpage** plugin. This means the plugin is designed to cover the whole page.

It doesn't work inside other elements. You can apply margins, paddings... create elements inside sections with any other style you want... but the plugin will work in fullscreen technically. 

If you need to have fixed elements, then you have to add the `position:fixed` property to those elements and you might need to add them to the option `fixedElements` as detailed in the documentation.

To achieve what you are looking for, i would use the option `paddingTop` to avoid using the same space as your header bar and then I will add another padding for the `.section` elements to avoid overlaying the left bar. 

Of course, the left bar and the top one would have `position:fixed` and they will both be added to the `fixedElements` option (to move them out from the `supercontainer`)

@internetix you should be able to do it as I pointed out previously. 
The change you propose is not that trivial and less yet when dealing with touch devices. Just remember this is a **fullpage** plugin.

The solution you pointed above is not working because the script will take the elements i mention in "fixedElements" out of their container and append them right inside the body thus messing up the original html structure.

I am willing to sponsor some customization job to the plugin in order to give us an option to specify the inner div where "#superContainer" will be appended. Maybe other people needs this aswell when running your plugin in a non-fullpage mode.

If you can't do it, i will assign this to a freelance developer but can you help me out with some advice on what should be change inside the code so i can forward this info to him ?

Thanks again ! I really love this plugin.

@internetix it doesn't matter where the elements are in the DOM if you assign them the `position:fixed` property. It might only interfere if you are using some javascript which depends a lot on the position of the elements in the DOM structure.
Your left and top bars should be fixed that way the changed I proposed won't _mess up the original html structure._

As I said, the customization you are talking about is not that simple and less if you want to make it compatible with phone devices.

The core of the problem is that "superContainer" is wrapping the whole page. From the original purpose of the plugin this is perfect fine but if you want to include the plugin in some inner divs it's not gonna work unless we can make somehow that "superContainer" wrap only the specific div we want and not the whole page.

Your provided jquery script actually resize the entire "superContainer" and because "superContainer" is wrapping the entire page in the default behavior, it resizes our entire site :)

Let me rephrase what i meant previously regarding function "fixedElements":

This function takes the specified elements OUT of their original location and will append them inside the "body" (at the "root" body level).

So, after using "fixedElements" function on our fixed div, that specific div is pulled out of the original location inside the html structure and is appended at "root" body level of the page.
Of course, that specific div being in another location and being taken out of it's original containers will create a problem with css classes thus messing some things up.

Making that "superContainer" div wrapping only the elements we want will solve everything and will mantain the original html structure, "activating" the plugin in the inner div we want.

The slides which contain lot of text get cut on resolutions lower than 480px wide.
I would expect that if autoScrolling is set to true the height of the slide would make the text fit? Ho can I deal with this?

Nop.
`autoscrolling` defines the way you scroll (normally or by sections)
[Example of autoScrolling:false](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html)

You would need to use `scrollOverflow` as pointed out in the documentation:

> scrollOverflow: (default false) defines whether or not to create a scroll for the section in case its content is bigger than the height of it. In case of setting it to true, it requieres the vendor plugin jquery.slimscroll.min and it should be loaded before the fullPaje.js plugin.

[Live example](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html)

It would have been great if we could add a video/photo to the background while declaring the script. Something like:-

slidesVideo : ['video1', 'video2']
or
slidesPhoto : ['photo1', 'photo2']

which will set a background video/photo AND maintaining the responsiveness.

There are many ways of adding backgrounds defining their position, size (cover, 100%...) and it is more a matter of design. Doing it in CSS is the correct way. 

Kind of the same with videos. Different formats, options... etc.

I can understand what you are trying to explain about customisation. But, if there was a privilege of just mentioning the files in the script declaration, it would save a lot of time AND make your code much more robust.

It will only solve the problem for people who don't know CSS (to add a background to a section, which is quite basic) or people who don't know jQuery at all to play a video (which is one line).

But it will create other problems as it won't be configurable at all. Also, those styles will be defined as inline styles and that's even worst for possible customization with CSS.
