<S_CODE_TOKEN>

If I have a few minutes I'd like to fix the issue more specifically instead of this hacky way. I'll update you if I get a second. Thanks @alvarotrigo and @mlilley.

**Update**: Logging the width and height of the window on a Nexus 7 and they appear reversed in the `reBuild` function. Surely someone else recognized this and has a polyfill or something...

**Update**: Changing the `reBuild` function to fire on only the `resize` event instead of `orientationchange` event fixed this issue on the Nexus 7. There have been [some reports](http://davidwalsh.name/orientation-change#comment-31322) that the `orientationchange` event fires prematurely, which is why the values are reversed. @alvarotrigo any reason we can't just exclusively use the `resize` event?

> Changing the reBuild function to fire on only the resize event instead of orientationchange event fixed this issue on the Nexus 7

Johnathon Ortega also commented reporting some similar testing results...

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

so maybe we should leave the 500ms delay in there?

Ultimately I think this is going to be _extremely_ difficult to get right
on every device given that tablets have variable CPU/RAM speeds and tablet
browsers (especially chrome) are attempting to behave more and more like
desktop browsers instead of a "mobile" browser (since newer devices are
just as powerful as some desktops).

Like Johnathon said, I think 500ms is a good compromise. Developers can
also find this ticket and adjust the waiting period if their application
has specific device requirements.

@alvarotrigo feel free to pop off the last commit on my PR.

-- miles

@milesmatthias thanks for your PR. I think we better not omit isTouchDevice otherwise we might have 500ms delay to rebuild. touch device resize once so it should be called right away without using setTimeout.

@channainfo I think everyone might be on different pages. According to @Jhony0311 and @lemmyFromMotorhead, various touch devices have various delays between the `resize` event firing and the updating of the `window.width` and `window.height` values.

Everyone -- I just found a couple of great stack overflow answers that discuss this situation in great detail complete with testing:
- http://stackoverflow.com/a/6603537/837042
- http://stackoverflow.com/a/13805104/837042

Going off of the second answer, we should try only listening to the `resize` event and using `window.innerHeight` and `window.innerWidth`.

However, I'm not encouraged that there is a great way to have something that handles every single browser, considering this is in the jQuery documentation for the `.resize()` function:

> Depending on implementation, resize events can be sent continuously as the resizing is in progress (the typical behavior in Internet Explorer and WebKit-based browsers such as Safari and Chrome), or only once at the end of the resize operation (the typical behavior in some other browsers such as Opera).

I don't have any Android devices with me right now, but I will tomorrow. In the mean time, if someone wants to test the fullPage.js version in the following branch in my fork, that would be awesome:

https://github.com/milesmatthias/fullPage.js/tree/master-resize_inner

I've seen [people applying the delay to the `orientationchange` event](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12452349/mobile-viewport-height-after-orientation-change). But this one occurs before the resize one and that might be the reason.

In [other answers](http://stackoverflow.com/a/9930331/1081396), that delay is omitted when using the `resize` event.

As you forgot to add the `jqueryui` library as detailed in the documentation if you want to add a different animation: 

> easing: (default easeInQuart) Defines the transition effect to use for the vertical scrolling. **It requieres jQuery UI for using some of its transitions.** Other libraries could be used instead.
If I don't want to use the jqueryui library, how would I specify a different easing effect, something that is built into the standard jquery library? Or perhaps a native CSS transition easing?

Read [this](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5207301/looking-for-jquery-easing-functions-without-using-a-plugin) if you want to add other than the default (swing)

[Documentation](http://api.jquery.com/animate/) says:

> The only easing implementations in the jQuery library are the default, called swing, and one that progresses at a constant pace, called linear. More easing functions are available with the use of plug-ins, most notably the jQuery UI suite.

So, use `easing: "swing"` if you dont want to add the library.

I have a similar question. (I don't know if there is a solution for it existing already, hence I don't open a separate issue for it.)

With full screen backgrounds the images are aligned on the left upper corner, therefore they are cropped either at the right end or at the bottom (depending on what is needed to make the image fill the whole screen). I refer to the left upper corner as "in the focus".

Is it possible to define which corner, or that the center, should be in the focus? I've seen there is an option `verticalCentered` (which doesn't seem to make a difference when I use it). The point is, in many cases the photo I display as a background has a specific area of interest: I don't want to show Marilyn Monroe's right ear, I want to show her smiling face, for example. -- In other words, I would love to be able to tell `fullPage()` which area to show always.

Would it make sense to add two options as follows?
- `alignVertical: top|middle|bottom` (default: `top`)
- `alignHorizontal: left|center|right` (default: `left`)

P.S.: The problem is well described on [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17722239/full-screen-background-with-cover-but-focus-on-a-part-of-the-image) with the [yellow sign not showing](http://demo.tutorialzine.com/2012/06/quick-tip-fullscreen-backgrounds/) when you make the window narrow enough.
P.P.S.: I've noticed that this behavior can be controlled using plain CSS with, e.g., `background-position: 50% 50%` (putting the focus on the image center in this specific case).

Added the ability to have the scrolling appear to be continuous - when you are at the last section and scroll down, the animation will continue downward but you will end up on the first section. It is similar when you are on the first section - scrolling up will cause the animation to continue upward but you will end up on the last section. Navigation is updated and hashes are maintained. This feature is very similar to the loopTop and loopBottom features but is targeted to make the end of a scroll (when there are many sections) not as jarring. 

Clicking on a navigation dot, or navigating to an anchor directly, will use the normal animation: scroll up if the section is a prior one, scroll down if the animation is a later one. 

And, just to be clear, this does not add horizontal scrolling (i.e. this is not a solution for issue 124).

Now from version 2.4.4 you can combine fullPage.js with any parallax plugin if you use the option `scrollBar:true` as you can see [in this demo](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrollBar.html).

> **scrollBar**: (default false). Determines whether to use scrol bar for the site or not. In case of using scroll bar, the autoScrolling functionallity will still working as expected. The user will also be free to scroll the site with the scroll bar and fullPage.js will fit the section in the screen when scrolling finishes.

This way the plugin will really perform the scroll of the site as all these kind of parallax techniques expect.

The main idea is that once you move to the next slide, you will have to move all the slides of all your site to the same direction. This should be done "in the background" without the user realise about it.

First you would need to modify a bit the plugin and create a function to move the sliders in the background as detailed here:

Then you could add another public function to speed up the animation setting the scrollingSpeed to 0 and then to 700 again.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This is now possible using the [Interlocked Slides extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/interlockedSlides.html) of fullpage.js.

You only have to overwrite the dots navigation styles:
- `#fullPage-nav span, .fullPage-slidesNav span`
- `#fullPage-nav li a, .fullPage-slidesNav li a`
- `#fullPage-nav li, .fullPage-slidesNav li`
- `#fullPage-nav ul, .fullPage-slidesNav ul`
- `#fullPage-nav`
- `.fullPage-tooltip`

If you want to avoid the creation of the current tooltip then you would need to modify the plugin and remove these lines:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

You might also want to check if your css works with `class="active"` for the current active dot or with `class="current"` as it seems to do.

If you want to apply jquery/javascript over them, you would need to add the code inside the `afterRender` callback or perhaps you would need to modify the javascript they provide as these dot elements are generated dynamically.

I don't know how that plugin/script works, but you might want to ask your questions in http://stackoverflow.com/ as this issue is not directly related with fullpage.js but with the scripts you are trying to use.

Works on **IE10** and not on **IE11** there is no `MSPointerMove` on **IE11**

**Note  As of Internet Explorer 11, the Microsoft vendor prefixed version of this event (`MSPointerMove`) is no longer supported and may be removed in a future release. Instead, use the non-prefixed lowercase name, `pointermove`, which is better for standards compliance and future compatibility.**

I tested with `document.addEventListener("MSPointerDown", function(event){alert('e');}, false);` and it works. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8996015/jquery-on-vs-javascript-addeventlistener 

So my suggestion is to use a handler function **touchMoveHandler** for both `document.addEventListener("MSPointerDown", touchMoveHandler, false);` and `$(document).on('touchmove',touchMoveHandler)`

Duplicate post. There's already [an open issue](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/124) treating the same topic.
Possible now through [the fullpage.js extensions](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/).
- Added option to specify sensitivity for touch devices.

You are trying to implement the same solution as I tried on [this commit](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/commit/4d263718a1409e0d74c2d53d5a80a619f51c01b4) which deals with pixels and therefore is not ideal for all devices.

A xThreshold of 100 can be a good value for a retina iPhone 5 and a bad one for an iPhone 4, for example.
This created [another issue](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/134) in the past.
I see what you mean, would this solution be better than having it be overly sensitive like it is at present i.e 1px movement triggers the slide? Or are you looking for a more concrete solution?

The problem is that i you apply a value of 100, for example. You might have troubles trying to slide in devices with low resolutions.

Yes.

What you want is to only have certain animations running when said content is in view. Right now all your animations will fire at once, so you'll have to write a function that determines when animations should fire (you can use the event-hooks to determine when to fire which animation cycle `onLeave` / `afterSlideLoad` / `onSlideLeave`).

I guess what you want is to disable the `autoScrolling`. You can do it by using the method `setAutoScrolling(false);` whenever you want.

You could detect with javascript the size of the window and apply this method under some condition.

If you just want to avoid the plugin to work under some resolutions, then I would recommend you to initialize the plugin just in the case the resolution is bigger than X. 

There's no current way to destroy the plugin structure once it has been created if that's what you are asking for. You can only modify it using methods.

> You could detect with javascript the size of the window and apply this method under some condition.

This is, by don't initializing  fullpage on touch devices.
You will have to deal with the mobile/touch devices detection. Just search a bit on google or even in http://stackoverflow.com/ to find different alternatives.

It is not simple to give you a hint without spending a bit of time looking at the code, but you would need to create the data-anchor in case you use anchors for sliders, you would also need to check whether or not to create the scroll bar in case of using `scrollOverflow`,check whether or not the content should be centered if used `verticalCentered` and deal with the navigation dots and tooltips if using `slidesNavigation`.

Nop, there is no way right now.  
Anchors are needed for it.

You could do a custom implementation with `window.history.pushState()` and some `data-*` attributes on your sections/slides, although you might have some browser compatibility issues.

[pushState() docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/API/DOM/Manipulating_the_browser_history#The_pushState%28%29.C2.A0method)

I used https://github.com/browserstate/history.js/ **History.js gracefully supports the HTML5 History/State APIs (pushState, replaceState, onPopState) in all browsers**. But I didn't have enough time to add it on `fullPage.js`

Could you please tell me, how to hide the address bar in ios 5 and below versions on portrait mode?

No.

Safari in iOS7 has some serious issues with fullscreen pages. The old `window.scrollTo` hack no longer works and the address bar requires the user to scroll before it can be hidden. See here for a more detailed explanation:

http://www.mobilexweb.com/blog/safari-ios7-html5-problems-apis-review

I've set `setAutoscrolling("false")` when a user on iOS/mobile visits the page with fullPage.js.

As @guywithabeard  says, it is not possible.

The issue was already treated before [here](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/79).

With iOS 7.1 you can add "minimal-ui" to the meta to hide most of the address bar stuff in Safari like so: `<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, maximum-scale=1, minimal-ui">`

Not sure how this affects other parts of the script/height calculation etc...
I have no idea. I haven't tested it but that's belong the plugin scope anyway :)

Nope,
It's not `Windows Phone`, it's `Windows 8`
I think you need to test if the device support touch or not, instead of testing the device type, because there are some Win8 device with touch screen and others not.

`var is_touch_device = 'ontouchstart' in document.documentElement;`
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3974827/detecting-touch-screen-devices-with-javascript

Since IE10 there's a `Touch` part to the UA-string, since there are Windows 8, Windows RT and Windows Phone devices that have touchscreens that all run IE10 or higher:

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/hh920767%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

So targeting that might be easier than introducing a new method to detect touch-device, seeing the info is already embedded in the reported UA-strings.

edit: like the source says, this part of the UA is only sent when the device is touchenabled and windows 8 or higher, windows 7 even on a touchscreen will never have this `Touch` part in the UA-string.

Take a look at [this solution](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/46#issuecomment-26509996)

If you still want to use Lazy Load plugin, I would recommend you to ask on its [github issues forum](https://github.com/tuupola/jquery_lazyload/issues) as I donÂ´t personally know how it works.

If you are using fullpage with the `autoScrolling:true` (which is the default option), take into consideration that the site is not scrolling normally, it is changing the `top` property of the site or adding a `translate3d` css3 effect which can be the cause of trouble with plugins which uses the scroll event, which might be the case with Lazy Load.

Yeah, exactly. That's a very similar principle to the solution I proposed in [this topic](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/46#issuecomment-26509996).

That's the way to do it with this plugin. Using callbacks. Lazy load plugins usually use the positions of the elements in the viewport together with the `scroll` event, which won't be fired using fullpage as it doesn't really scroll but it use the `top` or the `translate3d` CSS properties to create the scrolling effect.
Yep, but I needed a solution that works with image tags inside my HTML. :-)
Yeah, and that's a way to do it.

- Converted indentation to spaces
- Consistent code formatting
- Small cleanup

Not so sure about the use of spaces instead of tabs... 
I've always used tabs and the advantages of using spaces is not that clear:
http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/57/tabs-versus-spaceswhat-is-the-proper-indentation-character-for-everything-in-e

Just trying to make it consistent throughout the code, as some documents use tabs, others use spaces. I prefer spaces because it holds the formatting better than tabs across multiple editors, which is ideal for sharing code.
Not sure why you closed this but I hope you consider cleaning up the codebase. There are a lot of inconsistencies and poor formatting and it makes it hard to work with.

@karlcarstensen I make use of tabulation instead. If I want to change something in those files in the future, I will still use tabulation and we would have another conflict again. 

Also, I tent not to separate `){` .

Apart from that, I don't find it so important some minor changes or whitespaces (such as `h1,h2,h3{` vs `h1, h2, h3{`  or the space between the keyboards meta tag or `text-align:center;` vs `text-align: center;`).

Having said that, it would be more than probable than in any modification I do of the plugin I will commit the same _"mistakes"_ again. 
And well, you or someone else would have to change all of that again, and again... which doesn't make much sense.

After all, those little changes don't change anything from the user perspective and functionality. (Well yes, they add some extra white spaces which will increase the size of the file a little bit :P )

By the way, could I ask you why does it make it hard to work? (I'm just wondering as I didn't experiment any trouble with my tools)

It's not so much that spaces or tabs are correct, I'm not saying that one way is right and the other way is wrong - it's more about consistency in the codebase. So it doesn't matter to me which one you prefer, as long as it is consistent. Right now, the code has both spaces and tabs, as well as a few different formatting and indentation styles. It doesn't matter to me which way you decide to do it, but being consistent is very important so that other users are able to easily read and contribute to the repository to make the codebase better. It also makes the code super clean and organized, which is obviously helpful to people, especially new users reading the code.

I prefer spaces over tabs because it translates better to a variety of different text editors across platforms and keeps the indentation the same. So sharing the code is much easier and much more consistent.

As far as separating `){` or putting a space after css declarations, these types of things will make it much easier for other users to read or skim the code. There were inconsistencies with this formatting as well so my suggestion is to pick one and make it consistent. 

The last thing that I cleaned up in this pull request was any instance of `0px` because this is not a proper declaration.

A good code linter or beautifier will catch and fix these things, perhaps that is a good place to start.

- Converted indentation to spaces
- Made indentation consistent
- Made code formatting consistent
- Removed `0px` as part of best practices
Once you change that I will merge it.

Hello.
What is the way to disable its functions :
- Scroll within sections using they mouse wheel scroll
- Scroll within sections and within sliders using the arrow keys and the pageUp and pageDown keys
- Use touch events for mobile and tablet devices
  
  I want to scroll between sections only with a mouse click on a button?
  Thanks.

> Scroll within sections using they mouse wheel scroll

You can initializate the plugin with the option `autoscrolling: false` or make use of the method `$.fn.fullpage.setAutoScrolling(false)`

> Scroll within sections and within sliders using the arrow keys and the pageUp and pageDown keys

There's no way to do it within the plugin. This is consider a good practice for the user interaction. 

> Use touch events for mobile and tablet devices

Again as before, setting `autoScrolling` to false.

Here you have an example you can find in the available online examples:
- http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html

And here you have a couple of examples available in the documentation of the use of fullpage with autoScrolling: false: 
- http://www.jennbeaupre.com/jb/index.html
- http://lawinenstift.com/

If you want to use buttons to move throw the sections or slides, you should make use of the methods available for it:
- moveSectionUp()
- moveSectionDown()
- moveTo(section, slide)

You can see how they work in [the documentation](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#methods).

- Methods such as `moveTo(section, slide)` wouldn't make any sense anymore. You can't move to the 2nd slide of an infinite slider, there wouldn't be a second. It could be in the 4th position.
- `loopHorizontal` wouldn't make sense with this new feature enabled.

my "workaround":
1. when scroll to the last slide, start a `setTimeout()` for the display time, then "fade out" all slides. 
2. when scroll to the first slide, start a `setTimeout()` for the "pull back" action, then "fade in" all slides.

I'm not familiar with rails or Turbolinks either, but if I see your site I might be able to help.

This is happening to me in backbone. Basically when the plugin has autoScrolling:true, it sets the overflow of the body to hidden, when you are using dynamic content and you change the dom content to something else, which is the basic idea behind turbolinks, backbone, ember, and other once page apps, the scroll will remain disabled.

To fix this, you can either stop using autoScrolling or when you load another page verify that the overflow of the body is set to "auto". 

UPDATE: Actually I would recommend staying away from autoScrolling, and possibly the library since it attaches several events to elements like window and document. A $.fn.fullPage().remove() would be nice! :)

You don't need to remove it. You can just change from `autoScrolling: true` to `autoScrolling:false` with the method `$fn.fullPage().setAutoScrolling(false)`;

Of course, it adds events to document or window, its a plugin :)
But I see your problem anyway. You are trying to add sections dynamically, is it right?

No, I'm not trying to add sections dynamically, just trying to use FullPage.js for the homepage. When a user clicks a link on the navbar though, it takes them to a login page, and at that point, can't scroll because of Turbolinks vs. FullPage.js being used in tandem.

Well I'm afraid I can not be of any more help.
The main problem can or can not be related with turbolinks, but as I can not see your site or your code I can not say anything else.

The autoScrolling option is not to automatically scroll over the sections or slides, it is a way to automatically scroll with just one move of the mouse wheel or trackpad rather than the having to scroll manually.

This example is using `autoScrolling: true` as is the value by default:
http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/

And this another one, is using `autroScrolling:false`:
http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/normalScroll.html

@medhi, the padding is applied correctly. The height o the section will be always be the same no matter which padding you apply as the CSS property `box-sizing: border-box;` is applied in each section. 

The section is not shifted down. The content is getting overflowing and therefore hidden.

by using the navigation and/or menu?

In the scrollable sections or not react at all?

And what about others? If what you are suggesting is the following:

An action over the scroll wheel would:
- Scroll to the previos or next slide in a section with no scroll inside the section
- Scroll inside the section BUT not scroll to the next or previous slide if there's an internal section scroll bar.

The user would feel stuck inside a section if this one has an internal scrolling bar as they won't be able to keep making use of the scroll wheel. (which they were very probably using to reach that section)

I have a problem when including jparallax plugin, the problem is that the jparallax plugin only is functional with jquery 1.7 or minor version, and the fullPage plugin need jquery 1.10 someone has achieved integrate parallax and full page ? Which parallax plugin can i use?

fullPage.js doesn't need jquery 1.10. Here you have a living example working with jQuery 1.7.2
http://jsfiddle.net/2dhkR/16/

Don't forget to add the jQuery UI library.

Now from version 2.4.4 you can combine fullPage.js with any parallax plugin if you use the option `scrollBar:true` as you can see [in this demo](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrollBar.html#secondPage).

> **scrollBar**: (default false). Determines whether to use scrol bar for the site or not. In case of using scroll bar, the autoScrolling functionallity will still working as expected. The user will also be free to scroll the site with the scroll bar and fullPage.js will fit the section in the screen when scrolling finishes.

This way the plugin will really perform the scroll of the site as all these kind of parallax techniques expect.
There's now a [parallax extension](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/extensions/parallax.html) to create parallax effects!

Hi @michalcik ,

1 - You can use the option `autoScrolling` setting it to `false` and you will have a free scrolling site with the same functionality.

2 - In this plugin, each section will have the size of your window by default but, of course, you can make it bigger if you are using `autoScrolling:false`. In case you wanted to use big texts by using `autoScrolling:true`, then you could use the option `scrollOverflow:true` which would generate an scrolling bar for those sections with a bigger content than the window's height.

3- I'm not familiar with paralax, but you shouldn't have any problem. You should just initialize the paralax plugin inside the callback `afterRender` as specified [at the documentation](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#afterrender). 

> This is the callback you want to use to initialize other plugins or fire any code which requires the document to be ready (as this plugin modifies the DOM to create the resulting structure).

@linkito: I was having an issue on the iPad where the height of the screen wasn't being calculated correctly in Landscape mode. I found a solution with meta tags...

I did a conditional statement in the `<head>` of my document to add this meta tag for iPads: 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

And now it's working fine. 

Suerte!
add "minimal-ui" in viewport to use a thinner address bar

As posted above 'minimal-ui' in viewport meta tag now eliminates the address bars top and bottom on the iPhone when in landscape, and leaves a minimal bar in portrait. (as of iOS 7.1).

Unfortunately this screws up window positioning in landscape (the main reason for wanting to use minimal-ui in the first place - with the UI in place there is very little usable space), leaving a grey area at the bottom of the screen.

Adding 

afterResize: function(){window.scrollTo(0,0);}

to the full page initialization parameters works around the problem for me.
I only have iPhone/iPad to test against, so would be interested if this causes side affects on other platforms and needs to be made conditional...

Simon

You don't need to destroy anything :)

There's an available method called  `setAutoScrolling` for that purpose.
You can set it to `false` to go back to the normal scrolling mode. ([documentation](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js#setautoscrolling))

Also, you can make use of the option `scrollOverflow` setting it to `true` to create scroll bars for contents bigger than the viewport / browser window.
Here you have an example: 
http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrolling.html

Is up to you which option to choose.

700 seems too long for me, but there is no way to configure it, which is fixed in this commit.

I'm not too sure about creating this option and giving the user control over it. 

The main reason is that users are not probably aware of how the plugin behaves in other machines apart from the one they are using at the moment of testing their site.

This could lead into a big problem if the user believes that the delay is too big, and decides to change it to 50 mile seconds, for  example.
Then, inadvertently for them, their site would be working wrong in laptops, Apple laptos using trackpad, Apple users using the magic mouse wheel... 

I believe the plugin should make sure it behaves correctly in all browsers/devices and giving it as an option breaks this idea.
Related with: https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/18 and https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/5

The guys you call "users" are actually the developers, not sure they so dumb to set this to unreasonably small values, especially if the consequences would be documented. When several people already ask for it maybe it's not so bad to let it be configured?

The people who ask for it doesn't realize how the plugin behaves in a Mac laptop. Even with a value of 400 milliseconds (if i don't remember bad), you can easily scroll more than one slide at a time, which is annoying .

I set it to 700  after trying it on a Mac and seeing this offered the best results. 

I talk about users rather than developers because many people using the plugin don't have a good knowledge of jQuery, but, if we are talking about developers then I guess a solution for this could be setting a global variable in the plugin with this value, for an easy replacement. This way, developers could easily change it but users won't change it randomly that easily.

You can not apply the padding by your own as the plugin does. This is the main reason of adding options to the plugin for it.

Take into account that sections are of a fixed size (same as your window height) and adding a padding would just increase the resulting size of the box. 
For example, i your sections are of 800px height, adding a `paddingTop` of 100px would resulting in sections of 900px which would overflow your window height and therefore break the aesthetic of the plugin.

What the plugin does is taking off the padding size from the sections height when calculating its size and then applying the padding.

I will take a look at the units. 

About the second point, could you elaborate it a bit more? Or better yet, reproduce it in [jsfiddle](jsfiddle.net) or add a link with an example?
Here an example applying paddings: http://jsfiddle.net/7PwsS/47/

Hi .. the artefacts I mentioned seem to be related to using css3 for transitions .. and also using box-sizing: border-box which will change your calculations in regards to padding.  Using border-box is becoming common ... my pages are using bootstrap 3 where it is used ... looks like you need to take into account the box-model when applying padding for layout and might be worth moving to a border-box box-model by default.
http://jsfiddle.net/7PwsS/69/

I also have verticalCentered: false which is making the issue visible without the full screen centering technique that is being used when verticialCentered is turned on.
(Note: I have it turned off because I am not sure how it is supposed to work .. I would assume vertical centering would mean the section header on the 2nd page of the above fiddle would be in the middle of the page .. but it still appears near the top ... I am not sure it is worth doing if you are going to apply 100% width and height .. seems to be more about forcing the content to be fullscreen and may be redundant when you set the height elsewhere).

Really great component. Should become a classic in no time.
1. When the browser window is resized, the current page should update instantly along with the window resize. Currently, there is a delay, then a slow animation to reset the current page properly. It looks terrible. Can you please change this, or add an option (and make it default) FastResizeUpdate = true. Meaning, no animations to reset the current page/slide when resizing --- just do it instantly. It is one of the few missing features keeping me from building 2 client sites using this awesome plugin. I see some improvement by by changing 500 to 100 on line 658 ... in $(window).resize(function() ...
2. The other issue relates to resizing the background image proportionately. I use full page background images, but when the browser window is resized, the plugin fails to recalculate whether to use the height or the width of the image at 100% to properly fill the screen. This should be updated upon an window resizing, and re-focus (as you tab between other web sites, resize the window, the return to your site that has this component, the "current" div/page has to be reset instantly). 

To test what im saying, open your demo, go to section 2 (any section other than the 1st/top one), then resize your browser, you will see the messy animations struggling to update. I should not see other pages/slides -- i should only see my current page/slide being updated. It should be instant -- no animations. Animations should be used only when a user clicks a link, or performs a distinct movement (up arrow, etc.). That is, you animate his intentions to move/jump etc. All other updates and refreshes (non-user initiated) should be instant.

Seems both should be very doable.
Keep up the GREAT work. Thanks.

When i tried to use a BW filter on a div, the scroll on the page became too slow
you could check it out here http://andersen.puntoycoma.mx

I would say it is not only because of the filter but mainly because you are trying to move 6 big images at a time.
Images such as this one: http://andersen.puntoycoma.mx/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/21andersen.jpg

What you should do, not only or a more fluid scrolling of the site, but also for speed up the load of the site as well as improving SEO and offering a better user experience for old browsers or low computers, is cropping those images to the size you want to display them, and, if possible, even converting them to black and white rather than using a filter for it.

You are giving much work to the client side. Cropping would be my main advice. 

Cheers.

Now from version 2.4.4 you can combine fullPage.js with any parallax plugin if you use the option `scrollBar:true` as you can see [in this demo](http://alvarotrigo.com/fullPage/examples/scrollBar.html#secondPage).

> **scrollBar**: (default false). Determines whether to use scrol bar for the site or not. In case of using scroll bar, the autoScrolling functionallity will still working as expected. The user will also be free to scroll the site with the scroll bar and fullPage.js will fit the section in the screen when scrolling finishes.

This way the plugin will really perform the scroll of the site as all these kind of parallax techniques expect.

Ok i found a solution that works fine for me.

I named the sections id "section_`anchorName`" and added a data attribute to the slides that should be loaded later called `data-url` to store the url.
- `onSlideLeave` to preload the next slide
- `afterSlideLoad` to load the slide if its called direct via url `#section/slide`
- `afterRender` to add a class (in my case `loading`) to all slides with `data-url`

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I know it's not really a dynamic adding of slides but it helps you to keep the traffic low by loading the slices when they are needed.

@painis just be careful with loading data into the section dynamically. You will probably have problems if you are using the option `scrollOverflow`. The feature won't work correctly with those slides. 

If you are just avoiding the load of background images, I would recommend dealing with CSS to solve the problem.

The feature of adding or deleting sections won't be done. 
Content can be loaded into them by using callbacks and AJAX. Also, now a function `reBuild` is available to solve problems with things such as `scrollOverflow`.

A future function to avoid scrolling right or left, up or down, [might be created](https://github.com/alvarotrigo/fullPage.js/issues/630) so you will be able to have empty sections / slides which would be able to be filled with content whenever you want.

This way, although the addition or deletion of sections or slides won't be implemented, the same behavior for the final user could be accomplish.

When I enabled the slimScroll feature on my project, I noticed that it pretty sucks when you reach the scrollable area's end, the fullPage automatically slides down.
So I added the scrollResistance option. With this option you can regulate at which "strength" of scrolling the section-slide occurs.
The default is one and each +120 is +1 'click' on the mousewheel.
Please review and pull ;)
@janizde thanks! I will take a look from Monday!

I don't understand how it works.

I have tried it with `scrollResistance:100` and I don't notice any difference. 
Then I tried it with `scrollResistance:120` and it doesn't scroll to the next slide when scrolling with the mouse wheel. 

Am I doing something wrong?

Try scrolling with two 'clicks' on your mousewheel. The scrollResistance feature is actually only makes sense for Trackpads and stepless mousewheels (like the Apple Magic Mouse). I use the Magic Mouse and it works for me. So the higher the Resistance is, the 'stronger' I have to scroll on my Mouse to slide to the next section

I will try it at home later. I have no trackpad here right now.
Have you tried it with a mouse wheel? Does it still working normally with it?

The thing is, when you 'click' once on your mouse wheel it reports a delta of 120. So at a scrollResistance of less than 120 it still slides the normal way and you don't notice any difference, but at a delta of 120 and above you need to 'click' twice, and at a delta of 240 and above three times and so on.
I see that it doesn't make sense for conventional mouse wheels, so it would be better to give the scrollResistance a value of 0 to 1 which is a delta from 1 to 120 or so, so there won't be any conflict with conventional mouse wheels.

I've noticed delta value is `120` in Chrome, but `360` in Firefox using a mouse wheel and is always the same value on every scroll. 
I haven't tested it yet on trackpads, but I guess it will happen more of the same depending on the browser, the OS or the used device. 

Wouldn't it be better to add a counter rather than relaying on the delta value? 
Take a look a the answer of this question: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19513065/fire-scroll-event-after-a-certain-scroll-offset-or-scrolling-time/19515170#19515170

It's a known "problem" that different browsers use different values for delta, which means you need to unify them somehow, or ... use a counter...
I don't have a magic mouse (or an apple product for the matter), but if the magic mouse reports only 1 event with a different delta for 2 clicks (instead of 2 events like every mouse I tested yet), then the counter variant is kinda problematic for the magic mouse.

seriously after a bit of thinking... I think you shouldn't... in the end people can change scroll behaviour of the OS

also you got those flick movements on touch devices, where you can hardly decide if he just wanted to flick down a long text in a contained scoll area, or wanted to flick down to a different slide

you could probably go something like, on each scroll check if the contained scroll area is already at the bottom/top and the user is scrolling towards that direction (ignoring delta) switch pages, if not block page switching for a fraction of a second, but do not block scrolling

if you want to unify the delta... just log it on a couple of different OS and browser combinations with a real mousewheel and compare the values... the math is/should be easy
basic usage is done here and is rather easily achievable
then, if you feel like it change scrolling behaviour of the OS (for example windows lets youset how many lines of text to scroll on a mousewheel "click")
compare again to previous values, see if it affects the delta, if it does you probably have a hard time to provide a solution for people who in fact did change this setting
then get a mouse with a "flywheel" and check if the delta stays constant, or if they did something like mouse acceleration for the mousewheel
furthermore test if smooth scrolling options have any effect
maybe some of this is overkill... but there's probably no way to know for sure untill checked

luckily, by now touchpad scroll events should be taken care of because they kinda simulate a scrollwheel ;)

if you manage to find patterns for all of these things, congrats you're probably the first one to achieve this feat
then again there is a jquery mousewheel plugin, of which I don't know if it maybe already did all the necessary work

oh it would be so much easier if one could work with the scroll event ^^

@medeish the option `autoScrolling` is only related with the way the site is scrolled. Not with the overflow of the sections.

If `scrollOverflow` is set to `false`, then `slimScroll` wouldn't be needed. 

The option `touchScrolling` doesn't exist anymore. I changed it for `autoScrolling` in some of the last commits. This way is not restricted to touch devices but can also be configured in desktop computers. 

Let me know if with the last version you still having the same problem. And, if so, if  the sections `heights` are ok  but the scrolling of the site doesn't readjust.

I committed another version of the plugin.
Now, by default `scrollOverflow` is set to `false` and in case of wanted to make use of this feature, it will requiere the previous inclusion of the vendors dependency (`jquery.slimscroll.min.js`).

I also updated the documentation for this option.

Scrolling horizontally with a touchpad will trigger vertical scrolls.

This is because of `function MouseWheelHandler` only compensating for vertical transitions. This can be achieved by differentiating between `e.wheelDeltaX` and `e.wheelDeltaY`.

The damned macbook trackpad has the same gesture for horizontal scrolling as it does for history back/forward. @kingk1974 In case there's any conflict between bootstrap and jquery is nothing to do with fullPage.js. (but i really doubt there's any conflict at all)

Also, fullPage.js doesn't require the UI library, that's an optional library to use if you want to use certain jQuery animations in case css3 animations can not be applied (such as in IE 8 or IE 9)

@kingk1974 you should better ask in other places such as stackoverflow.com. Your problem is not about fullPage.js but probably about knowledge of jQuery, CSS or HTML.
You are not even including the jQuery library and fullPage.js is a plugin for jQuery...
